Whereas when you run the program natively in cmd.exe it works nicely. For the same reason that your program blows up on Mac and Linux terminals.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But I guess if you're going to be using this specifically for windows, more power to ya." But once I tried it in DOS (er, CMD.exe), as a real program, then it ran fine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;No one try it in IDLE, unless you have Task Manager handy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've already forgotten how I lived with menus that arn't super-instant responsive."   <row Id="2176" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1894" RevisionGUID="bd577f09-6c49-412f-8308-49641535e12e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:36:13.340" UserId="160" Text="I create folders named after the build versions and put upgrade and downgrade scripts in there. For example, you could have the following folders: 1.0.0, 1.0.1 and 1.0.2. Each one contains the script that allows you to upgrade or downgrade your database between versions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Should a client or customer call you with a problem with version 1.0.1 and you are using 1.0.2, bringing the database back to his version will not be a problem.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In your database, create a table called &quot;schema&quot; where you put in the current version of the database. Then writing a program that can upgrade or downgrade your database for you is easy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Just like Joey said, if you are in a Rails world, use Migrations. :)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2179" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1886" RevisionGUID="78f8834f-ef0a-421c-9a33-b1c4141ae20c" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:32:29.480" UserId="275" Text="I had recently similar problem and the only way to solve it was to use plain old HTML codes for single (`&amp;#34;`) and double quotes (`&amp;#39;`).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Source code was total mess of course but it worked.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't know if I correctly understand your example, but try&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a id=&quot;aShowHide&quot; onclick='ToggleDisplay(&amp;#34;&lt;%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, &quot;JobCode&quot;) %&gt;&amp;#34;);'&gt;Show/Hide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;or&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a id=&quot;aShowHide&quot; onclick='ToggleDisplay(&amp;#39;&lt;%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, &quot;JobCode&quot;) %&gt;&amp;#39;);'&gt;Show/Hide&lt;/a&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2190" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1873" RevisionGUID="1497c756-5aef-43f4-86e2-84d90994a2df" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:05:53.230" UserId="242" Text="How do I delimit a Javascript databound string parameter in an anchor OnClick event?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have an anchor tag in an ASP.NET Repeater control.  &#xD;&#xA;The OnClick event of the anchor contains a call to a Javascript function.  &#xD;&#xA;The Javascript funciton takes a string for it's input parameter.  &#xD;&#xA;The string parameter is populated with a databound value from the Repeater.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I need the 'double quotes' for the Container.DataItem.  &#xD;&#xA;I need the 'single quotes' for the OnClick.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And I still need *one more delimiter* (triple quotes?) for the input string parameter of the Javascript function call.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since I can't use 'single quotes' again, how do I ensure the Javascript function knows the input parameter is a string and not an integer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Without the extra quotes around the input string parameter, the Javascript function thinks I'm passing in an integer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Cheers in advance for any knowledge you can drop.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The anchor:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a id=&quot;aShowHide&quot; onclick='ToggleDisplay(&lt;%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, &quot;JobCode&quot;) %&gt;);' &gt;Show/Hide&lt;/a&gt;    &#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;and  &#xD;&#xA; here is the Javascript:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;script language=&quot;JavaScript&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    /* Shows/Hides the Jobs Div */&#xD;&#xA;      function ToggleDisplay(jobCode)&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;      /* Each div has it's ID set dynamically ('d' plus the JobCode) */&#xD;&#xA;        var elem = document.getElementById('d' + jobCode);&#xD;&#xA;        if (elem) &#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;          if (elem.style.display != 'block') &#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'block';&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.visibility = 'visible';&#xD;&#xA;          } &#xD;&#xA;          else&#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'none';&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.visibility = 'hidden';&#xD;&#xA;          }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;	&lt;/script&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2193" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1873" RevisionGUID="b8ceec9b-0523-4baa-b2c7-14d55f616425" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:42:14.873" UserId="1" Text="How do I delimit a Javascript databound string parameter in an anchor OnClick event?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- I have an anchor tag in an ASP.NET Repeater control.  &#xD;&#xA;- The OnClick event of the anchor contains a call to a Javascript function.  &#xD;&#xA;- The Javascript funciton takes a string for it's input parameter.  &#xD;&#xA;- The string parameter is populated with a databound value from the Repeater.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I need the 'double quotes' for the Container.DataItem.  &#xD;&#xA;I need the 'single quotes' for the OnClick.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And I still need *one more delimiter* (triple quotes?) for the input string parameter of the Javascript function call.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since I can't use 'single quotes' again, how do I ensure the Javascript function knows the input parameter is a string and not an integer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Without the extra quotes around the input string parameter, the Javascript function thinks I'm passing in an integer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Cheers in advance for any knowledge you can drop.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The anchor:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a id=&quot;aShowHide&quot; onclick='ToggleDisplay(&lt;%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, &quot;JobCode&quot;) %&gt;);' &gt;Show/Hide&lt;/a&gt;    &#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;and  &#xD;&#xA; here is the Javascript:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;script language=&quot;JavaScript&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    /* Shows/Hides the Jobs Div */&#xD;&#xA;      function ToggleDisplay(jobCode)&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;      /* Each div has it's ID set dynamically ('d' plus the JobCode) */&#xD;&#xA;        var elem = document.getElementById('d' + jobCode);&#xD;&#xA;        if (elem) &#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;          if (elem.style.display != 'block') &#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'block';&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.visibility = 'visible';&#xD;&#xA;          } &#xD;&#xA;          else&#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'none';&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.visibility = 'hidden';&#xD;&#xA;          }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;	&lt;/script&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2194" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1873" RevisionGUID="a1cc81c1-93e6-48dd-b381-aa8ec65ce8ef" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:45:39.063" UserId="1" Text="How do I delimit a Javascript databound string parameter in an anchor OnClick event?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- I have an anchor tag in an ASP.NET Repeater control.  &#xD;&#xA;- The OnClick event of the anchor contains a call to a Javascript function.  &#xD;&#xA;- The Javascript funciton takes a string for it's input parameter.  &#xD;&#xA;- The string parameter is populated with a databound value from the Repeater.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I need the 'double quotes' for the Container.DataItem.  &#xD;&#xA;I need the 'single quotes' for the OnClick.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And I still need *one more delimiter* (triple quotes?) for the input string parameter of the Javascript function call.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since I can't use 'single quotes' again, how do I ensure the Javascript function knows the input parameter is a string and not an integer?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Without the extra quotes around the input string parameter, the Javascript function thinks I'm passing in an integer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Cheers in advance for any knowledge you can drop.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The anchor:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a id=&quot;aShowHide&quot; onclick='ToggleDisplay(&lt;%# DataBinder.Eval(Container.DataItem, &quot;JobCode&quot;) %&gt;);' &gt;Show/Hide&lt;/a&gt;    &#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;and here is the Javascript:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;script language=&quot;JavaScript&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    /* Shows/Hides the Jobs Div */&#xD;&#xA;      function ToggleDisplay(jobCode)&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;      /* Each div has it's ID set dynamically ('d' plus the JobCode) */&#xD;&#xA;        var elem = document.getElementById('d' + jobCode);&#xD;&#xA;        if (elem) &#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;          if (elem.style.display != 'block') &#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'block';&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.visibility = 'visible';&#xD;&#xA;          } &#xD;&#xA;          else&#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;            elem.style.display = 'none';&#xD;&#xA;   <row Id="2198" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1904" RevisionGUID="0a69b248-9661-4709-a72b-6549b5215f61" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:49:15.030" UserId="172" Text="Extending on what [Mike Powell][1] has to say, I am actually a big fan of almost all of the podcasts at [http://www.twit.tv][2].   <row Id="2201" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1909" RevisionGUID="f2ec1902-63d6-4845-ad7e-28beee982a59" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:56:30.210" UserId="363" Text="Chris' probably has the best pure answer to the question:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1104/#1109&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, I'm curious about the root of the question.  If the user should *always* wrap the call in a try/catch block, should the user-called function really be throwing exceptions in the first place?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a difficult question to answer without more context regarding the code-base in question.  Shooting from the hip, I think the best answer here is to wrap the function up such that the recommended (if not only, depending on the overall exception style of the code) public interface does the try/catch *for* the user.  If you're just trying to ensure that there are no unhandled exceptions in your code, unit tests and code review are probably the best solution." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2202" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1910" RevisionGUID="8ecf81a2-a9af-4a04-a59f-3e4d2bfa8f5e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T04:57:52.987" UserId="157" Text="You are going to get a lot of strings, that's for sure...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;![\sum_{i=x}^y{\frac{r!}{{(r-i)}!}}][1]  &#xD;&#xA;Where, x and y is how you define them and r is the number of characters we are selecting from --if I am understanding you correctly. You should definitely generate these as needed and not get sloppy and say, generate a powerset and then filter the length of strings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The following definitely isn't the best way to generate these, but it's an interesting aside, none-the-less.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Knuth (volume 4, fascicle 2, 7.2.1.3) tells us that (s,t)-combination is equivalent to s+1 things taken t at a time with repetition -- an (s,t)-combination is notation used by Knuth that is equal to ![{t \choose {s+t}][2]. We can figure this out by first generating each (s,t)-combination in binary form (so, of length (s+t)) and counting the number of 0's to the left of each 1.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;10001000011101 --&gt; becomes the permutation: {0, 3, 4, 4, 4, 1}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.codecogs.com/eq.latex?\sum_{i=x}^y%20{%20\frac{r!}{{(r-i)}!}%20}&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.codecogs.com/eq.latex?{t%20\choose%20{s+t}}&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://beta.stackoverflow.com/questions/561/using-combinations-of-sets-as-test-data" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2205" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1912" RevisionGUID="79e664fb-b314-4b08-8950-9fe6db869a00" CreationDate="2008-08-05T05:02:37.640" UserId="122" Text="If you can guarantee that there are no commas in the data, then the simplest way would probably be to use [String.split][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    String[] values = myString.Split(',');&#xD;&#xA;    myObject.StringField = values[0];&#xD;&#xA;    myObject.IntField = Int32.Parse(values[1]);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There may be libraries you could use to help, but that's probably as simple as you can get.  Just make sure you can't have commas in the data, otherwise you will need to parse it better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.string.split(VS.71).aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2228" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1934" RevisionGUID="6107ded7-4c71-4b9e-9d15-08afda74645b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T05:30:41.297" UserId="328" Text="I'm not clear on whether or not you're wanting to add the asynchronous bits to the server in C# or the client in C++.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you're talking about doing this in C++, desktop Windows platforms can do socket I/O asynchronously through the API's that use overlapped I/O.  For sockets, WSASend, WSARecv both allow async I/O (read the documentation on their LPOVERLAPPED parameters, which you can populate with events that get set when the I/O completes).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't know if Windows Mobile platforms support these functions, so you might have to do some additional digging."   <row Id="2254" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1957" RevisionGUID="9f501ae9-345b-42e4-80c2-7e7b252006eb" CreationDate="2008-08-05T06:00:46.417" UserId="46" Text="recognizing text inside an image is indeed a hot topic for researchers in that field, but only begun to grow out of control when [captcha's][1] became the &quot;norm&quot; in terms of defense against spam bots. Why use captcha's as protection? well because it is/was very hard to locate (and read) text inside an image!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reason why I mention captcha's is because the most advancement* is made within that tiny area, and I think that your solution could be best found there.&#xD;&#xA;especially because captcha's are indeed about locating text (or something that resembles text) inside a cluttered image and afterwards trying to read the letters correctly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so if you can find yourself [a good open source captcha breaking tool][2] you probably have all you need to continue your quest...  &#xD;&#xA;You could probably even throw away the most dificult code that handles the character recognition itself, because those OCR's are used to read distorted text, something you don't have to do.&#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*: advancement in terms of visible, usable, and **practical** information for a &quot;non-researcher&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captcha&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://libcaca.zoy.org/wiki/PWNtcha" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2261" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="1949" RevisionGUID="5d76790b-d441-4534-9aa0-dcb4667483d1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T05:54:34.697" UserId="51" Text="|.net|asp.net|datacontext|database|linq-to-sql|visual-studio|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2262" PostHistoryTypeId="4" PostId="1949" RevisionGUID="b518aef4-5a2b-486d-b9b1-fe97229fd12a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T06:12:31.337" UserId="51" Text="Are Multiple DataContext classes ever appropriate?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2263" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="1949" RevisionGUID="b518aef4-5a2b-486d-b9b1-fe97229fd12a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T06:12:31.337" UserId="51" Text="|.net|asp.net|visual-studio|database|linq-to-sql|datacontext|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2264" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1949" RevisionGUID="5d76790b-d441-4534-9aa0-dcb4667483d1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T05:54:34.697" UserId="51" Text="In order to fully use LinqToSql in an ASP.net 3.5 application, it is necessary to create [DataContext][1] [classes][2] (which is usually done using the designer in VS 2008). From the UI perspective, the DataContext is a design of the sections of your database that you would like to expose to through LinqToSql and is integral in setting up the ORM features of LinqToSql.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question is: I am setting up a project that uses a large database where all tables are interconnected in some way through Foreign Keys. My first inclination is to make one huge DataContext class that models the entire datbase. That way I could in theory (though I don't know if this would be needed in practice) use the Foreign Key connections that are generated through LinqToSql to easily go between related objects in my code, insert related objects, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, after giving it some thought, I am now thinking that it may make more sense to create multiple DataContext classes, each one relating to a specific namespace or logical interrelated section within my database. My main concern is that instantiating and disposing one huge DataContext class all the time for individual operations that relate to specific areas of the Database would be impose an unnecessary imposition on application resources. Additionally, it is easier to create and manage smaller DataContext files than one big one. The thing that I would lose is that there would be some distant sections of the database that would not be navigable through LinqToSql (even though a chain of relationships connects them in the actual database). Additionally, there would be some table classes that would exist in more than one DataContext.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any thoughts or experience on whether multiple DataContexts (corresponding to DB namespaces) are appropriate in place of (or in addition to) one very large DataContext class (corresponding to the whole DB)?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.data.linq.datacontext.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://dotnetslackers.com/articles/csharp/InsideTheLINQToSQLDataContextClass.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2265" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1949" RevisionGUID="b518aef4-5a2b-486d-b9b1-fe97229fd12a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T06:12:31.337" UserId="51" Text="In order to fully use LinqToSql in an ASP.net 3.5 application, it is necessary to create [DataContext][1] [classes][2] (which is usually done using the designer in VS 2008). From the UI perspective, the DataContext is a design of the sections of your database that you would like to expose to through LinqToSql and is integral in setting up the ORM features of LinqToSql.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My question is: I am setting up a project that uses a large database where all tables are interconnected in some way through Foreign Keys. My first inclination is to make one huge DataContext class that models the entire database. That way I could in theory (though I don't know if this would be needed in practice) use the Foreign Key connections that are generated through LinqToSql to easily go between related objects in my code, insert related objects, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, after giving it some thought, I am now thinking that it may make more sense to create multiple DataContext classes, each one relating to a specific namespace or logical interrelated section within my database. My main concern is that instantiating and disposing one huge DataContext class all the time for individual operations that relate to specific areas of the Database would be impose an unnecessary imposition on application resources. Additionally, it is easier to create and manage smaller DataContext files than one big one. The thing that I would lose is that there would be some distant sections of the database that would not be navigable through LinqToSql (even though a chain of relationships connects them in the actual database). Additionally, there would be some table classes that would exist in more than one DataContext.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any thoughts or experience on whether multiple DataContexts (corresponding to DB namespaces) are appropriate in place of (or in addition to) one very large DataContext class (corresponding to the whole DB)?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.data.linq.datacontext.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://dotnetslackers.com/articles/csharp/InsideTheLINQToSQLDataContextClass.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2287" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="1982" RevisionGUID="d38cde2c-16b3-4e45-835c-dbce8e7c3ef5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:11:08.427" UserId="2090742" Text="CPU throttling in C++" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2288" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="1982" RevisionGUID="d38cde2c-16b3-4e45-835c-dbce8e7c3ef5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:11:08.427" UserId="2090742" Text="|c++|cpu|throttling|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2289" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1982" RevisionGUID="d38cde2c-16b3-4e45-835c-dbce8e7c3ef5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:11:08.427" UserId="2090742" Text="I was just wandering if there is an elegant way to set the maximum CPU load for a particular thread doing intensive calculations. Right now I have located the most time consuming loop in the thread (it does only compression) and use GetTickCount() and Sleep() with hardcoded values. It makes sure that the loop continues for a certain period of time and than sleeps for a certain minimal time. It more or less does the job i.e. guarantees that the thread will not use more than 50% of CPU. However behavior is dependent on the number of CPU cores (huge disadvantage) and simply ugly (smaller disadvantage :)). Any ideas?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2292" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1986" RevisionGUID="c605b2fc-d0dd-4429-a96b-6882bb06d265" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:23:45.390" UserId="269" Text="I can't think of any cross platform way of what you want (or any guaranteed way full stop) but as you are using GetTickCount perhaps you aren't interested in cross platform :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd use interprocess communications and set the intensive processes nice levels to get what you require but I'm not sure that's appropriate for your situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT:&#xD;&#xA;I agree with [Bernard][1] which is why I think a process rather than a thread might be more appropriate but it just might not suit your purposes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1982/#1984" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2310" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2002" RevisionGUID="35b2fcb7-3521-462e-9c7f-46dcde73dc8a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:56:53.140" UserId="192" Text="As I don't have a test case to go from I can't guarantee this solution, but it seems to me that a scenario similar to the one used to update progress bars in different threads (use a delegate) would be suitable here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public delegate void DataBindDelegate();&#xD;&#xA;    public DataBindDelegate BindData = new DataBindDelegate(DoDataBind);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public void DoDataBind()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        DataBind();&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the data binding needs to be done by a particular thread, then let that thread do the work!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2311" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1998" RevisionGUID="6c94ebc5-4519-45e1-8e18-51c871e31cd4" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:51:54.727" UserId="122" Text="You should be able to do something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    if (control.InvokeRequired)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        control.Invoke(delegateWithMyCode);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    else&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        delegateWithMyCode();&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;InvokeRequired is a property on Controls to see if you are on the correct thread, then Invoke will invoke the delegate on the correct thread." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2312" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1998" RevisionGUID="7c1cb05d-8d3a-438f-b9c7-af1c00def4d1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T07:58:06.727" UserId="122" Text="You should be able to do something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    if (control.InvokeRequired)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        control.Invoke(delegateWithMyCode);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    else&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        delegateWithMyCode();&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;InvokeRequired is a property on Controls to see if you are on the correct thread, then Invoke will invoke the delegate on the correct thread.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;UPDATE: Actually, at my last job we did something like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    private void SomeEventHandler(Object someParam)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        if (this.InvokeRequired)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            this.Invoke(new SomeEventHandlerDelegate(SomeEventHandler), someParam);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        // Regular handling code&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;which removes the need for the else block and kind of tightens up the code." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2320" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2005" RevisionGUID="57eb798f-760e-47d5-b9dc-a032902c4624" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:02:01.087" UserId="232" Text="I'd personally use int.tryparse, then double.tryparse.  Performance on those methods is quite fast.  They both return a Boolean.  If both fail then you have a string, per how you defined your data." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2321" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2006" RevisionGUID="03a2046a-d6d8-4e07-9f24-f2f47560e38e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:03:01.397" UserId="116" Text="On linux, you can change the scheduling priority of a thread with nice()." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2324" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2009" RevisionGUID="c389f59b-0e24-4e6a-910e-bc9fdd16f224" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:04:22.093" UserId="122" Text="I would say, don't worry so much about such micro performance.  It is much better to just get something to work, and then make it as clear and concise and easy to read as possible.  The worst thing you can do is sacrifice readability for an insignificant amount of performance.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the end, the best way to deal with performance issues is to save them for when you have data that indicates there is an actual performance problem... otherwise you will spend a lot of time micro-optimizing and actually cause higher maintenance costs for later on.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you find this parsing situation is really the bottleneck in your application, THEN is the time to try and figure out what the fastest way to solve the problem is.  I think Jeff (and many others) have blogged about this sort of thing a lot." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2327" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2013" RevisionGUID="767cf717-5e9d-4986-855d-9bd22a204949" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:06:42.840" UserId="192" Text="If the thread call is &quot;illegal&quot; (i.e. the DataBind call affects controls that were not created in the thread it is being called from) then you need to create a delegate so that even if the decision / preparation for the DataBind is not done in the control-creating thread, any resultant modification of them (i.e. DataBind()) will be.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You would call my code from the worker thread like so:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    this.BindData.Invoke();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This would then cause the original thread to do the binding, which (presuming it is the thread that created the controls) should work." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2331" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2017" RevisionGUID="4287e35d-d84f-436b-a11e-fd248635f7dd" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:22:05.943" UserId="48" Text="This is more or less the perfect use case for [SVK][1].  SVK is a command line front end for subversion that works with an entire local copy of the repository.  So your commits, updates, etc. work on the local repository and you can then sync with a master.  I would generally recommend SVK over plain subversion anyway as it makes a lot of things nicer.  No .svn folders, better branching and merging, better conflict resolution.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://http://svk.bestpractical.com/view/HomePage" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2338" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2025" RevisionGUID="7a6f5558-f632-462f-9f78-aecfd9ab001b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:43:05.667" UserId="298" Text="Also make sure you don't miss the [dnrTV webcast show][1] that Carl Franklin (the man behind .NET rocks) publishes. Even if it's a not a podcast and requires a more attention while watching it it's really informative and if you're into .NET and Microsoft related techniques you'll learn a lot.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.dnrtv.com/default.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2340" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2028" RevisionGUID="c01b2dbf-76f2-4a00-84bb-50dc5b5ea632" CreationDate="2008-08-05T08:56:35.530" UserId="46" Text="Here is my own contribution for the [Java programming language][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;first some code:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public void swap(int x, int y)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;      int tmp = x;&#xD;&#xA;      x = y;&#xD;&#xA;      y = tmp;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;calling this method will result in this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    int pi = 3;&#xD;&#xA;    int everything = 42;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    swap(pi, everything);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    System.out.println(&quot;pi: &quot; + pi);&#xD;&#xA;    System.out.println(&quot;everything: &quot; + everything);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &quot;Output:&#xD;&#xA;    pi: 3&#xD;&#xA;    everything: 42&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;even using 'real' objects will show a similar result:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	public class MyObj {&#xD;&#xA;		private String msg;&#xD;&#xA;		private int number;&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;		//getters and setters&#xD;&#xA;		public String getMsg() {&#xD;&#xA;			return this.msg;&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;		public void setMsg(String msg) {&#xD;&#xA;			this.msg = msg;&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;		public int getNumber() {&#xD;&#xA;			return this.number;&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;		public void setNumber(int number) {&#xD;&#xA;			this.number = number;&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;		//constructor&#xD;&#xA;		public MyObj(String msg, int number) {&#xD;&#xA;			setMsg(msg);&#xD;&#xA;			setNumber(number);&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	public static void swap(MyObj x, MyObj y)&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		MyObj tmp = x;&#xD;&#xA;		x = y;&#xD;&#xA;		y = tmp;&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	public static void main(String args[]) {&#xD;&#xA;	    MyObj x = new MyObj(&quot;Hello world&quot;, 1);&#xD;&#xA;		MyObj y = new MyObj(&quot;Goodbye Cruel World&quot;, -1); &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		swap(x, y);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		System.out.println(x.getMsg() + &quot; -- &quot;+  x.getNumber());&#xD;&#xA;		System.out.println(y.getMsg() + &quot; -- &quot;+  y.getNumber());&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &quot;Output:&#xD;&#xA;    Hello world -- 1&#xD;&#xA;    Goodbye Cruel World -- -1&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;thus it is clear that Java passes its parameters **by value**, as the value for *pi* and *everything* and the *MyObj objects* aren't swapped.&#xD;&#xA;be aware that &quot;by value&quot; is the *only way* in java to pass parameters to a method. (for example a language like c++ allows the developer to pass a parameter by reference using '**&amp;**' after the parameter's type)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;now the **tricky part**, or at least the part that will confuse most of the new java developers: (borrowed from [javaworld][2])  &#xD;&#xA;Original author: Tony Sintes&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public void tricky(Point arg1, Point arg2)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;    	arg1.x = 100;&#xD;&#xA;    	arg1.y = 100;&#xD;&#xA;    	Point temp = arg1;&#xD;&#xA;    	arg1 = arg2;&#xD;&#xA;    	arg2 = temp;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    public static void main(String [] args)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;    	Point pnt1 = new Point(0,0);&#xD;&#xA;    	Point pnt2 = new Point(0,0);&#xD;&#xA;    	System.out.println(&quot;X: &quot; + pnt1.x + &quot; Y: &quot; +pnt1.y); &#xD;&#xA;    	System.out.println(&quot;X: &quot; + pnt2.x + &quot; Y: &quot; +pnt2.y);&#xD;&#xA;    	System.out.println(&quot; &quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    	tricky(pnt1,pnt2);&#xD;&#xA;    	System.out.println(&quot;X: &quot; + pnt1.x + &quot; Y:&quot; + pnt1.y); &#xD;&#xA;    	System.out.println(&quot;X: &quot; + pnt2.x + &quot; Y: &quot; +pnt2.y);  &#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &quot;Output&#xD;&#xA;    X: 0 Y: 0&#xD;&#xA;    X: 0 Y: 0&#xD;&#xA;    X: 100 Y: 100&#xD;&#xA;    X: 0 Y: 0&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*tricky* successfully changes the value of pnt1!&#xD;&#xA;This would imply that Objects are passed by reference, this is not the case!&#xD;&#xA;A correct statement would be: **the *Object references* are passed by value.**  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;more from Tony Sintes:  &#xD;&#xA;&gt; The method successfully alters the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; value of pnt1, even though it is&#xD;&#xA;&gt; passed by value; however, a swap of&#xD;&#xA;&gt; pnt1 and pnt2 fails! This is the major&#xD;&#xA;&gt; source of confusion. In the main()&#xD;&#xA;&gt; method, pnt1 and pnt2 are nothing more&#xD;&#xA;&gt; than object references. When you pass&#xD;&#xA;&gt; pnt1 and pnt2 to the tricky() method,&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Java passes the references by value&#xD;&#xA;&gt; just like any other parameter. This&#xD;&#xA;&gt; means the references passed to the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; method are actually copies of the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; original references. Figure 1 below&#xD;&#xA;&gt; shows two references pointing to the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; same object after Java passes an&#xD;&#xA;&gt; object to a method.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;![figure 1][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Conclusion** or a long story short:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Java passes it parameters **by value**&#xD;&#xA;  - *&quot;by value&quot;* is the **only way** in java to pass a parameter to a method&#xD;&#xA;  - using *methods from the object* given as parameter **will alter** the object as the references point to the original objects. (if that method itself alters some values)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;useful links:  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/javaqa/2000-05/03-qa-0526-pass.html][2]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-passbyval/][4]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-praxis/pr1.html][5]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://javadude.com/articles/passbyvalue.htm][6]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language)&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/javaqa/2000-05/03-qa-0526-pass.html&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/javaqa/2000-05/images/03-qa-0512-pass2b.gif&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-passbyval/&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-praxis/pr1.html&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://javadude.com/articles/passbyvalue.htm" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2345" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2033" RevisionGUID="38efcf3a-fdad-42bf-990d-d75808a3ab35" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:10:58.933" UserId="370" Text="**by value** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - is slower than by reference since the system has to copy the parameter&#xD;&#xA;  - used for input only  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**by reference**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; - faster since only a pointer is passed&#xD;&#xA; - used for input **and** output&#xD;&#xA; - can be very dangerous if used in conjunction with global variables" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2347" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1479" RevisionGUID="6bbce548-4a9f-4d4d-94db-843a1f5229e3" CreationDate="2008-08-04T18:27:26.627" UserId="269" Text="I am pretty sure this is one of the things due to change in python 3.0 with perhaps bin() to go with hex() and oct().&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At the moment AFAIK eval('01010101101') does what you'd expect it to.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT:&#xD;&#xA;checked eval appears to work correctly :)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2354" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2042" RevisionGUID="7cf2b5b9-cfee-4a96-bab4-2970f87b1e6a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:25:40.510" UserId="269" Text="Subversion makes it easy (some think too easy) to create a new branch using the svn copy command.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $ svn copy svn+ssh://host.example.com/repos/project/trunk \&#xD;&#xA;               svn+ssh://host.example.com/repos/project/branch \&#xD;&#xA;          -m &quot;Creating a branch of project&quot;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2355" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2044" RevisionGUID="61cee3ec-f8b0-415f-9a99-c38ad6c430ad" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:37:13.577" UserId="91" Text="I think you're looking for GetModuleFileName.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[http://www.swissdelphicenter.ch/torry/showcode.php?id=143][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;      If you are working on a DLL and are interested in the filename of the&#xD;&#xA;      DLL rather than the filename of the application, then you can use this function:&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    function GetModuleName: string;&#xD;&#xA;    var&#xD;&#xA;      szFileName: array[0..MAX_PATH] of Char;&#xD;&#xA;    begin&#xD;&#xA;      FillChar(szFileName, SizeOf(szFileName), #0);&#xD;&#xA;      GetModuleFileName(hInstance, szFileName, MAX_PATH);&#xD;&#xA;      Result := szFileName;&#xD;&#xA;    end;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, look at [http://delphi.newswhat.com/geoxml/forumhistorythread?groupname=borland.public.delphi.internet.isapi-webbroker&amp;messageid=3fbe1256@newsgroups.borland.com][2] which contains pretty much the same code but some additional information that may or may not be useful.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Untested though, been some time since I worked with Delphi :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.swissdelphicenter.ch/torry/showcode.php?id=143&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://delphi.newswhat.com/geoxml/forumhistorythread?groupname=borland.public.delphi.internet.isapi-webbroker&amp;messageid=3fbe1256@newsgroups.borland.com" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2357" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2047" RevisionGUID="d2f7e42a-1896-4e1b-a905-cf4127caf8de" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:43:55.000" UserId="358" Text="This looks like an excellent opportunity to have a look at Aspect Oriented Programming. Here is a good article on [AOP in .NET][1]. The general idea is that you'd extract the cross-functional concern (i.e. Retry for x hours) into a separate class and then you'd annotate any methods that need to modify their behaviour in that way. Here's how it might look (with a nice extension method on Int32)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [RetryFor( 10.Hours() )]&#xD;&#xA;    public void DeleteArchive()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;      //.. code to just delete the archive&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.msdn.com/simonince/archive/2008/06/24/aspect-oriented-interception.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2360" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2048" RevisionGUID="5cac1914-7597-4438-8b86-24a407ec7a19" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:45:41.377" UserId="298" Text="For all the RSS feeds I subscribe to I use [Google Reader][1] which I love.   <row Id="2361" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2049" RevisionGUID="fcfae975-2574-4fc2-8014-c55d3728971d" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:47:41.013" UserId="266" Text="You do the unit testing by mocking out the database connection. This way, you can build scenarios where specific queries in the flow of a method call succeed or fail. I usually build my mock expectations so that the actual query text is ignored, because I really want to test the fault tolerance of the method and how it handles itself -- the specifics of the SQL are irrelevant to that end. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Obviously this means your test won't actually verify that the method *works*, because the SQL may be wrong. This is where integration tests kick in. For that, I expect someone else will have a more thorough answer, as I'm just beginning to get to grips with those myself." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2362" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2050" RevisionGUID="a5b05452-f516-41a3-a874-46d08145a7d3" CreationDate="2008-08-05T09:57:03.333" UserId="200" Text="In my experience with LINQ to SQL and LINQ to Entities a DataContext is synonymous to a connection to the database. So if you were to use multiple data stores you would need to use multiple DataContexts. My gut reaction is you wouldn't notice to much of a slow down with a DataContext that encompasses a large number of tables. If you did however you could always split the database logically at points where you can isolate tables that don't have any relationship to other sets of tables and create multiple contexts." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2363" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2051" RevisionGUID="6eee0314-2f81-491c-a729-e85e14b38b0d" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:00:46.930" UserId="188" Text="Don't forget there is also **pass by name**, and **pass by value-result**.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Pass by value-result is similar to pass by value, with the added aspect that the value is set in the original variable that was passed as the parameter.  It can, to some extent, avoid interference with global variables.  It is apparently better in partitioned memory, where a pass by reference could cause a page fault ([Reference][1]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Pass by name means that the values are only calculated when they are actually used, rather than at the start of the procedure.  Algol used pass-by-name, but an interesting side effect is that is it very difficult to write a swap procedure ([Reference][2]).  Also, the expression passed by name is re-evaluated each time it is accessed, which can also have side effects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://logos.cs.uic.edu/476/notes/PassByRefOrValResult.html&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.cs.sfu.ca/~cameron/Teaching/383/PassByName.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2365" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1940" RevisionGUID="f3a4e63e-29c7-4d22-b32e-26e274e57f76" CreationDate="2008-08-05T05:43:27.900" UserId="364" Text="The solution is to use the TempData property to store the desired Request components.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For instance:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public ActionResult Send()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;       TempData[&quot;form&quot;] = Request.Form;&#xD;&#xA;       return this.RedirectToAction(a =&gt; a.Form());&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then in your &quot;Form&quot; action you can go:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            public ActionResult Form()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                ... /* Declare viewData etc. */&#xD;&#xA;                if (TempData[&quot;form&quot;] != null)&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                    viewData.Form.SetValues((System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection)TempData[&quot;form&quot;]);&#xD;&#xA;                    viewData.Form.Validate();&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;                return View(&quot;Form&quot;, viewData);&#xD;&#xA;            }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2366" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1940" RevisionGUID="2c666a4d-9716-4704-ad92-a9c21652faab" CreationDate="2008-08-05T06:10:56.083" UserId="364" Text="The solution is to use the TempData property to store the desired Request components.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For instance:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public ActionResult Send()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;       TempData[&quot;form&quot;] = Request.Form;&#xD;&#xA;       return this.RedirectToAction(a =&gt; a.Form());&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then in your &quot;Form&quot; action you can go:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;         public ActionResult Form()&#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;            /* Declare viewData etc. */&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            if (TempData[&quot;form&quot;] != null)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;               /* Cast TempData[&quot;form&quot;] to &#xD;&#xA;               System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection &#xD;&#xA;               and use it */&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;            return View(&quot;Form&quot;, viewData);&#xD;&#xA;         }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2367" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1940" RevisionGUID="5d036013-dc44-4489-8114-5884a2cd611b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:04:52.913" UserId="364" Text="The solution is to use the TempData property to store the desired Request components.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For instance:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public ActionResult Send()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        TempData[&quot;form&quot;] = Request.Form;&#xD;&#xA;        return this.RedirectToAction(a =&gt; a.Form());&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then in your &quot;Form&quot; action you can go:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public ActionResult Form()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        /* Declare viewData etc. */&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        if (TempData[&quot;form&quot;] != null)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            /* Cast TempData[&quot;form&quot;] to &#xD;&#xA;            System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection &#xD;&#xA;            and use it */&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;         return View(&quot;Form&quot;, viewData);&#xD;&#xA;     }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2368" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2054" RevisionGUID="e594e8ba-473d-486b-bc87-375a8ba3404e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:05:07.187" UserId="188" Text="RSS isn't &quot;push&quot;, which means that you need to have something that polls the website.  It's much less traffic than getting the whole site or front page (for instance, you can say &quot;Give me all articles newer than the last time I asked&quot;), but it's traffic nonetheless.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It's generally understood you shouldn't have a refresh of more than 30 minutes in an automated client. (Citation required).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Having said that, you may find a client which allows you to set a more frequent refresh." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2376" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2068" RevisionGUID="2a5b9508-1126-4574-8f2d-34650a1c5f49" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:21:13.783" UserId="372" Text="I blogged about this a while back, quoting on [Todd Snyder's excellent post on the difference between the two][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Here are the key differences between&#xD;&#xA;&gt; the patterns:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; MVP Pattern&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; - View is more loosely coupled to the model. The presenter is&#xD;&#xA;&gt; responsible for binding the model to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; the view.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - Easier to unit test because interaction with the view is through&#xD;&#xA;&gt; an interface&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - Usually view to presenter map one to one. Complex views may have&#xD;&#xA;&gt; multi presenters.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; MVC Pattern&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; - Controller are based on behaviors and can be shared across&#xD;&#xA;&gt; views&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - Can be responsible for determining which view to display&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Best explanation on the web I could find.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.infragistics.com/blogs/tsnyder/archive/2007/10/17/mvc-or-mvp-pattern-whats-the-difference.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2377" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2070" RevisionGUID="f5d01307-a8ec-4244-acb0-024bb36698c2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:24:08.367" UserId="377" Text="You could always knock something up yourself...  I've done it in the past and it really isn't too difficult a job to write an RSS parser.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course, as others have mentioned, there's an etiquette question as to how much of the website's valuable bandwidth you want to hog for yourself in RSS request traffic.  That's a matter for your own conscience. ;)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2379" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2067" RevisionGUID="4e3ed8e1-97ad-47b1-aada-cd438920a148" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:20:20.340" UserId="364" Text="Both of these frameworks aim to seperate concerns - for instance, interaction with a data source (model), application logic (or turning this data into useful information) (Controller/Presenter) and display code (View).  In some cases the model can also be used to turn a data source into a higher level abstraction as well.  A good example of this is the [MVC Storefront project][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a discussion [here][2] regarding the differences between MVC vs MVP.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The distinction made is that in an MVC application traditionally has the view and the controller interact with the model, but not with each other.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MVP designs have the Presenter access the model and interact with the view.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Having said that, ASP.NET MVC is by these definitions an MVP framework because the Controller accesses the Model to populate the View which is meant to have no logic (just  displays the variables provided by the Controller).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To perhaps get an idea of the ASP.NET MVC distinction from MVP, check out [this early MIX presentation][3] (Silverlight) by Scott Gu on ASP.NET MVC (accessed from [this][4] Scott Hanselman's blog post).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blog.wekeroad.com/mvc-storefront/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://codebetter.com/blogs/jeremy.miller/archive/2007/10/31/development-trivial-pursuit-the-difference-between-mvc-and-the-different-flavors-of-mvp.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.hanselman.com/silverlight/ScottGuAtAltnetConf/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://www.hanselman.com/blog/ScottGuMVCPresentationAndScottHaScreencastFromALTNETConference.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2380" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2067" RevisionGUID="edf3dc63-3ad0-49c4-8634-9731112bf8a0" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:24:58.177" UserId="364" Text="Both of these frameworks aim to seperate concerns - for instance, interaction with a data source (model), application logic (or turning this data into useful information) (Controller/Presenter) and display code (View).  In some cases the model can also be used to turn a data source into a higher level abstraction as well.  A good example of this is the [MVC Storefront project][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There is a discussion [here][2] regarding the differences between MVC vs MVP.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The distinction made is that in an MVC application traditionally has the view and the controller interact with the model, but not with each other.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;MVP designs have the Presenter access the model and interact with the view.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Having said that, ASP.NET MVC is by these definitions an MVP framework because the Controller accesses the Model to populate the View which is meant to have no logic (just  displays the variables provided by the Controller).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To perhaps get an idea of the ASP.NET MVC distinction from MVP, check out [this MIX presentation][3] by Scott Hanselman.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blog.wekeroad.com/mvc-storefront/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://codebetter.com/blogs/jeremy.miller/archive/2007/10/31/development-trivial-pursuit-the-difference-between-mvc-and-the-different-flavors-of-mvp.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.hanselman.com/blog/ASPNETMVCSessionAtMix08TDDAndMvcMockHelpers.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://www.hanselman.com/blog/ScottGuMVCPresentationAndScottHaScreencastFromALTNETConference.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2382" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2069" RevisionGUID="e99f6346-93a3-4a6f-be3e-5fccbceb4674" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:22:55.653" UserId="307" Text="MVP = Model-View-Presenter&#xD;&#xA;MVC = Model-View-Controller&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1.  Both presentation patterns.  They separate the dependencies between a Model (think Domain objects), your screen/web page (the View), and how your UI is supposed to behave (Presenter/Controller)&#xD;&#xA;2.  They are fairly similar in concept, folks initialize the Presenter/Controller differently depending on taste.&#xD;&#xA;3.  A great article on the differences is [here][1].  Most notable is that MVC pattern has the Model updating the View.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.infragistics.com/blogs/tsnyder/archive/2007/10/17/mvc-or-mvp-pattern-whats-the-difference.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2383" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2069" RevisionGUID="ebce4029-5ee8-4183-8760-67827bb02a60" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:26:29.080" UserId="307" Text="- MVP = Model-View-Presenter&#xD;&#xA;  - MVC = Model-View-Controller&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1.  Both presentation patterns.  They separate the dependencies between a Model (think Domain objects), your screen/web page (the View), and how your UI is supposed to behave (Presenter/Controller)&#xD;&#xA;2.  They are fairly similar in concept, folks initialize the Presenter/Controller differently depending on taste.&#xD;&#xA;3.  A great article on the differences is [here][1].  Most notable is that MVC pattern has the Model updating the View.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.infragistics.com/blogs/tsnyder/archive/2007/10/17/mvc-or-mvp-pattern-whats-the-difference.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2384" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2073" RevisionGUID="456a4eee-e16c-45f6-971a-228904a3f029" CreationDate="2008-08-05T10:29:42.880" UserId="198" Text="The problem I experienced when unit testing persistence, especially without an ORM and thus mocking your database (connection), is that you don't really know if your queries succeed. It could be that you your queries are specifically designed for a particular database version and only succeed with that version. You'll never find that out if you mock your database. So in my opinion, unit testing persistence is only of limited use. You should always add tests running against the targeted database." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2423" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2099" RevisionGUID="09136756-f3c7-4762-ac50-428307885cd9" CreationDate="2008-08-05T11:27:08.550" UserId="230" Text="Technically unit tests of persistance are not Unit tests the are Integration tests.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With C# using mbUnit, you simply use the SqlRestoreInfo and RollBack attributes&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [TestFixture]&#xD;&#xA;        [SqlRestoreInfo(&lt;connectionsting&gt;, &lt;name&gt;,&lt;backupLocation&gt;]&#xD;&#xA;        public class Tests&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;          &#xD;&#xA;            [SetUp]&#xD;&#xA;            public void Setup()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;            &#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            [Test]&#xD;&#xA;            [RollBack]&#xD;&#xA;            public void TEST()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;               //test insert. &#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The same can be done in NUnit, excpet the attribute names differ slighty.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for checking if your query was succeful, you normally need to follow if was a second query to see if the database has been changed as you expect." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2424" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2099" RevisionGUID="68a74eea-5bac-445c-bbc5-78a3311ac9a2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T11:39:20.273" UserId="230" Text="Technically unit tests of persistance are not Unit tests they are Integration tests.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With C# using mbUnit, you simply use the SqlRestoreInfo and RollBack attributes&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        [TestFixture]&#xD;&#xA;        [SqlRestoreInfo(&lt;connectionsting&gt;, &lt;name&gt;,&lt;backupLocation&gt;]&#xD;&#xA;        public class Tests&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;          &#xD;&#xA;            [SetUp]&#xD;&#xA;            public void Setup()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;            &#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            [Test]&#xD;&#xA;            [RollBack]&#xD;&#xA;            public void TEST()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;               //test insert. &#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The same can be done in NUnit, excpet the attribute names differ slighty.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for checking if your query was succeful, you normally need to follow it with a second query to see if the database has been changed as you expect."   <row Id="2430" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2118" RevisionGUID="ddb86628-6f5a-4ad7-8b6e-3d71252f25f2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T11:44:29.687" UserId="389" Text="i built myself a pc with 4gb ram, dual core 1.8ghz 40gb pata drive primary, and 250gb sata drive secondary and installed vista business edition. when i had to copy 120gb of data from my old pata disk, vista failed miserably and kept crashing. i definately recommend teracopy free edition."   <row Id="2435" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2126" RevisionGUID="ce00b428-9e75-406f-be02-ab67e11815fb" CreationDate="2008-08-05T11:54:16.453" UserId="120" Text="I would definitely prefer:  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1) [Teracopy][1] - GUI based, replaces the default Windows copy/move UI and adds itself to context menu. Basic version is free (for home use I guess).  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2) [Robocopy][2] - CLI based, useful when scripting. Free tool from MS and is included in Vista/Windows 2008. MS Technet has a GUI for robocopy as well - useful to create statements that you can later embed in scripts or on the command prompt.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PS: I know these have been already suggested here and I would have voted on them, if I could.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.codesector.com/teracopy.asp&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robocopy" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2437" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1096" RevisionGUID="717a5ca7-264b-438d-ae3a-e0898bf08aec" CreationDate="2008-08-04T09:12:37.543" UserId="41" Text="You say you have enough trouble getting one cube to display... so I am not sure if you have got one to display or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically... put your code for writing a cube in one function, then just call that function 100 times.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void DrawCube()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        //code to draw the cube&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void DisplayCubes()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        for(int i = 0; i &lt; 10; ++i)&#xD;&#xA;        {   &#xD;&#xA;             for(int j = 0; j &lt; 10; ++j)&#xD;&#xA;             {&#xD;&#xA;                 glPushMatrix();&#xD;&#xA;                 //alter these values depending on the size of your cubes.&#xD;&#xA;                 //This call makes sure that your cubes aren't drawn overtop of each other&#xD;&#xA;                 glTranslatef(i*5.0, j*5.0, 0);&#xD;&#xA;                 DrawCube();&#xD;&#xA;                 glPopMatrix();&#xD;&#xA;             }&#xD;&#xA;        }              &#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That is the basic outline for how you could go about doing this." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2438" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="1096" RevisionGUID="48ceee83-cc04-4d58-beb8-815386f63ca3" CreationDate="2008-08-05T11:54:57.573" UserId="41" Text="You say you have enough trouble getting one cube to display... so I am not sure if you have got one to display or not.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically... put your code for writing a cube in one function, then just call that function 100 times.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void DrawCube()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        //code to draw the cube&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void DisplayCubes()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        for(int i = 0; i &lt; 10; ++i)&#xD;&#xA;        {   &#xD;&#xA;             for(int j = 0; j &lt; 10; ++j)&#xD;&#xA;             {&#xD;&#xA;                 glPushMatrix();&#xD;&#xA;                 //alter these values depending on the size of your cubes.&#xD;&#xA;                 //This call makes sure that your cubes aren't drawn overtop of each other&#xD;&#xA;                 glTranslatef(i*5.0, j*5.0, 0);&#xD;&#xA;                 DrawCube();&#xD;&#xA;                 glPopMatrix();&#xD;&#xA;             }&#xD;&#xA;        }              &#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That is the basic outline for how you could go about doing this. If you want something more efficient take a look into Display Lists sometime once you have the basics figured out :)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2450" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2142" RevisionGUID="3f211ac3-4921-4785-827d-19f3c7176ead" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:04:41.127" UserId="371" Text="The .Net 2.0 framework namespace System.IO.Compression supports GZip and Deflate algorithms. Here are two methods that compress and decompress a byte stream which you can get from your file object. You can subsitute GZipStream for DefaultStream in the methods below to use that algorithm. This still leaves the problem of handling files compressed with different algorithms though.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public static byte[] Compress(byte[] data)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        MemoryStream output = new MemoryStream();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        GZipStream gzip = new GZipStream(output, CompressionMode.Compress, true);&#xD;&#xA;        gzip.Write(data, 0, data.Length);&#xD;&#xA;        gzip.Close();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        return output.ToArray();&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    public static byte[] Decompress(byte[] data)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        MemoryStream input = new MemoryStream();&#xD;&#xA;        input.Write(data, 0, data.Length);&#xD;&#xA;        input.Position = 0;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        GZipStream gzip = new GZipStream(input, CompressionMode.Decompress, true);&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        MemoryStream output = new MemoryStream();&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        byte[] buff = new byte[64];&#xD;&#xA;        int read = -1;&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        read = gzip.Read(buff, 0, buff.Length);&#xD;&#xA;		&#xD;&#xA;        while (read &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            output.Write(buff, 0, read);&#xD;&#xA;            read = gzip.Read(buff, 0, buff.Length);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        gzip.Close();&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        return output.ToArray();&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2453" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2146" RevisionGUID="6aea729d-073d-4f6a-bac5-72d222df69f0" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:07:39.000" UserId="372" Text="No, because while you thought LINQ is really just syntactic sugar, it actually heavily used expression trees -- a feature absent in .NET 2.0.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That being said .NET 3.5 only builds up on top of .NET 2.0, and that's the reason why the IL doesn't look &quot;different&quot; or &quot;special&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I do not see a reason why you shouldn't just install the .NET 3.5 Framework. Everything .NET 2.0 will work fine on it, promise :)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2454" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2147" RevisionGUID="61911825-5ab0-481a-9660-f58f06c700f9" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:07:41.603" UserId="91" Text="There are some &quot;Hacks&quot; that involve using a System.Core.dll from the 3.5 Framework to make it run with .net 2.0, but personally I would not want use such a somewhat shaky foundation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See here: [http://weblogs.asp.net/fmarguerie/archive/2007/09/05/linq-support-on-net-2-0.aspx][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   1. Create a new console application&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   2. Keep only System and System.Core as referenced assemblies&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   3. Set Copy Local to true for System.Core, because it does not exist in .NET 2.0&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   4. Use a LINQ query in the Main method. For example the one below.&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   5. Build&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   6. Copy all the bin output to a machine where only .NET 2.0 is installed&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   7. Run&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Requires .net 2.0 SP1 and I have no idea if bundling the System.Core.dll violates the EULA)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://weblogs.asp.net/fmarguerie/archive/2007/09/05/linq-support-on-net-2-0.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2460" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2133" RevisionGUID="f410bff9-e091-433a-92d2-3de05bcc4ff7" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:00:03.367" UserId="383" Text="If you correctly markup your HTML code, there is no need for javascript. The following code will allow the user to click on the label text to tick the checkbox.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;label for=&quot;surname&quot;&gt;Surname&lt;/label&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;checkbox&quot; name=&quot;surname&quot; id=&quot;surname&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The *for* attribute on the label element links to the *id* attribute on the input element and the browser does the rest."   <row Id="2461" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2133" RevisionGUID="2ad86d65-612d-4512-9894-93ff84d2de67" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:09:18.543" UserId="383" Text="If you correctly markup your HTML code, there is no need for javascript. The following code will allow the user to click on the label text to tick the checkbox.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;label for=&quot;surname&quot;&gt;Surname&lt;/label&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;checkbox&quot; name=&quot;surname&quot; id=&quot;surname&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The *for* attribute on the label element links to the *id* attribute on the input element and the browser does the rest.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This has been testing to work in:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - IE6&#xD;&#xA;  - IE7&#xD;&#xA;  - Firefox" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2497" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2183" RevisionGUID="fb03b6f5-d00a-4fcc-a7a7-3920f2194ab9" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:32:40.510" UserId="267" Text="The JITter will sometimes use non-virtual calls to methods in sealed classes since there is no way they can be extended further.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are complex rules regarding calling type, virtual/nonvirtual, and I don't know them all so I can't really outline them for you, but if you google for sealed classes and virtual methods you might find some articles on the topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that any kind of performance benefit you would obtain from this level of optimization should be regarded as last-resort, always optimize on the algorithmic level before you optimize on the code-level." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2498" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2183" RevisionGUID="a5af15be-9f40-4b21-abbf-6b08049fc49b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:37:05.757" UserId="267" Text="The JITter will sometimes use non-virtual calls to methods in sealed classes since there is no way they can be extended further.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are complex rules regarding calling type, virtual/nonvirtual, and I don't know them all so I can't really outline them for you, but if you google for sealed classes and virtual methods you might find some articles on the topic.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that any kind of performance benefit you would obtain from this level of optimization should be regarded as last-resort, always optimize on the algorithmic level before you optimize on the code-level.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's one link mentioning this: [Rambling on the sealed keyword](http://codebetter.com/blogs/patricksmacchia/archive/2008/01/05/rambling-on-the-sealed-keyword.aspx)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2499" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2189" RevisionGUID="bc4f6212-f22e-46b0-a0b0-e3bd5ee43026" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:37:07.067" UserId="34" Text="Sealed classes *should* provide a performance improvement. Since a sealed class cannot be derived, any virtual members can be turned into non-virtual members.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of course, we're talking really small gains. I wouldn't mark a class as sealed just to get a performance improvement unless profiling revealed it to be a problem." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2519" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2213" RevisionGUID="e301bbf9-70a2-415d-a96f-f5bd7beb5d61" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:49:44.517" UserId="72" Text="This will allow you to pass a weight of 0 and still work properly.  Notice the === operator, this checks to see if weight matches &quot;null&quot; in both value and type (as opposed to ==, which is just value, so 0 == null == false).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;PHP:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public function createShipment($startZip, $endZip, $weight=null){&#xD;&#xA;        if ($weight === null)&#xD;&#xA;            $weight = $this-&gt;getDefaultWeight();&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
