  <row Id="2530" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2219" RevisionGUID="eb8d7ef9-0c95-4054-bed4-6bde45748939" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:51:16.430" UserId="227" Text="Quick'n Dirty:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First create your **ConfigurationSection** and **ConfigurationElement** classes:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class MyStuffSection : ConfigurationSection&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        ConfigurationProperty _MyStuffElement;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public MyStuffSection()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            _MyStuffElement = new ConfigurationProperty(&quot;MyStuff&quot;, typeof(MyStuffElement), null);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            this.Properties.Add(_MyStuffElement);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public MyStuffElement MyStuff&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            get&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                return this[_MyStuffElement] as MyStuffElement;&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class MyStuffElement : ConfigurationElement&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        ConfigurationProperty _SomeStuff;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public MyStuffElement()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            _SomeStuff = new ConfigurationProperty(&quot;SomeStuff&quot;, typeof(string), &quot;&lt;UNDEFINED&gt;&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            this.Properties.Add(_SomeStuff);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public string SomeStuff&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            get&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                return (String)this[_SomeStuff];&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then let the framework know how to handle your configuration classes in **web.config**:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;configuration&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      &lt;configSections&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;section name=&quot;MyStuffSection&quot; type=&quot;MyWeb.Configuration.MyStuffSection&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      &lt;/configSections&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      ...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And actually add your own section below:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;      &lt;MyStuffSection&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;MyStuff SomeStuff=&quot;Hey There!&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      &lt;/MyStuffSection&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then you can use it in your code thus:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    MyWeb.Configuration.MyStuffSection configSection = ConfigurationManager.GetSection(&quot;MyStuffSection&quot;) as MyWeb.Configuration.MyStuffSection;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    if (configSection != null &amp;&amp; configSection.MyStuff != null)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        Response.Write(configSection.MyStuff.SomeStuff);&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2531" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2210" RevisionGUID="36e91490-05f6-444b-aa4b-2f90248a4a41" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:47:17.967" UserId="246" Text="You could always try the Synth look &amp; feel. You provide an xml file that acts as a sort of stylesheet, along with any images you want to use. The code might look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    try {&#xD;&#xA;        SynthLookAndFeel synth = new SynthLookAndFeel();&#xD;&#xA;        Class aClass = MainFrame.class;&#xD;&#xA;        InputStream stream = aClass.getResourceAsStream(&quot;\\default.xml&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        if (stream == null) {&#xD;&#xA;            System.err.println(&quot;Missing configuration file&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;            System.exit(-1);				&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        synth.load(stream, aClass);&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        UIManager.setLookAndFeel(synth);&#xD;&#xA;    } catch (ParseException pe) {&#xD;&#xA;        System.err.println(&quot;Bad configuration file&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        pe.printStackTrace();&#xD;&#xA;        System.exit(-2);&#xD;&#xA;    } catch (UnsupportedLookAndFeelException ulfe) {&#xD;&#xA;        System.err.println(&quot;Old JRE in use. Get a new one&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        System.exit(-3);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And the xml file might look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;synth&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;style id=&quot;button&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;font name=&quot;DIALOG&quot; size=&quot;12&quot; style=&quot;BOLD&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;state value=&quot;MOUSE_OVER&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;imagePainter method=&quot;buttonBackground&quot; path=&quot;dirt.png&quot; sourceInsets=&quot;2 2 2 2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;insets top=&quot;2&quot; botton=&quot;2&quot; right=&quot;2&quot; left=&quot;2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;/state&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;state value=&quot;ENABLED&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;imagePainter method=&quot;buttonBackground&quot; path=&quot;dirt.png&quot; sourceInsets=&quot;2 2 2 2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;insets top=&quot;2&quot; botton=&quot;2&quot; right=&quot;2&quot; left=&quot;2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;/state&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/style&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;bind style=&quot;button&quot; type=&quot;name&quot; key=&quot;dirt&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/synth&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And a couple of useful links:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://javadesktop.org/articles/synth/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/lookandfeel/synth.html&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2532" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2210" RevisionGUID="da908971-7d03-425f-b3fe-2f822b8961ab" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:51:38.647" UserId="246" Text="You could always try the Synth look &amp; feel. You provide an xml file that acts as a sort of stylesheet, along with any images you want to use. The code might look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    try {&#xD;&#xA;        SynthLookAndFeel synth = new SynthLookAndFeel();&#xD;&#xA;        Class aClass = MainFrame.class;&#xD;&#xA;        InputStream stream = aClass.getResourceAsStream(&quot;\\default.xml&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        if (stream == null) {&#xD;&#xA;            System.err.println(&quot;Missing configuration file&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;            System.exit(-1);				&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        synth.load(stream, aClass);&#xD;&#xA;			&#xD;&#xA;        UIManager.setLookAndFeel(synth);&#xD;&#xA;    } catch (ParseException pe) {&#xD;&#xA;        System.err.println(&quot;Bad configuration file&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        pe.printStackTrace();&#xD;&#xA;        System.exit(-2);&#xD;&#xA;    } catch (UnsupportedLookAndFeelException ulfe) {&#xD;&#xA;        System.err.println(&quot;Old JRE in use. Get a new one&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        System.exit(-3);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From there, go on and add your JButton like you normally would. The only change is that you use the setName(string) method to identify what the button should map to in the xml file.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The xml file might look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;synth&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;style id=&quot;button&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;font name=&quot;DIALOG&quot; size=&quot;12&quot; style=&quot;BOLD&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;state value=&quot;MOUSE_OVER&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;imagePainter method=&quot;buttonBackground&quot; path=&quot;dirt.png&quot; sourceInsets=&quot;2 2 2 2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;insets top=&quot;2&quot; botton=&quot;2&quot; right=&quot;2&quot; left=&quot;2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;/state&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;state value=&quot;ENABLED&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;imagePainter method=&quot;buttonBackground&quot; path=&quot;dirt.png&quot; sourceInsets=&quot;2 2 2 2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;                &lt;insets top=&quot;2&quot; botton=&quot;2&quot; right=&quot;2&quot; left=&quot;2&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;/state&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/style&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;bind style=&quot;button&quot; type=&quot;name&quot; key=&quot;dirt&quot;/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/synth&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The bind element there specifies what to map to (in this example, it will apply that styling to any buttons whose name property has been set to &quot;dirt&quot;).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And a couple of useful links:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://javadesktop.org/articles/synth/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/lookandfeel/synth.html&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2533" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2220" RevisionGUID="ecde78ce-da87-4dd0-a8d1-e5a55bebcdbf" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:51:47.990" UserId="17" Text="NUnit is always a favorite of mine.  However if you are using TFS as your source control I suggest you stick with the Microsoft Stack." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2535" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2223" RevisionGUID="6870abcb-822c-4b4d-917a-9efbef6dead3" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:52:50.047" UserId="48" Text="Set the CSS &quot;display&quot; property for the label to be a block element and use that instead of your div - it keeps the semantic meaning of a label while allowing whatever styling you like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;     &lt;label for=&quot;test&quot; style=&quot;width: 100px; height: 100px; display: block; background-color: #e0e0ff;&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;       A ticky box! &lt;input type=&quot;checkbox&quot; id=&quot;test&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;     &lt;/label&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2537" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2225" RevisionGUID="a15b8dfb-1c61-415e-ac55-a559e0119b02" CreationDate="2008-08-05T12:53:35.990" UserId="304" Text="Yes, this is possible. One of the main pros for using Swing is the ease with which the abstract controls can be created and manipulates.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a quick and dirty way to extend the existing JButton class to draw a circle to the right of the text.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    package test;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    import java.awt.Color;&#xD;&#xA;    import java.awt.Container;&#xD;&#xA;    import java.awt.Dimension;&#xD;&#xA;    import java.awt.FlowLayout;&#xD;&#xA;    import java.awt.Graphics;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    import javax.swing.JButton;&#xD;&#xA;    import javax.swing.JFrame;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    public class MyButton extends JButton {&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    	private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    	private Color circleColor = Color.BLACK;&#xD;&#xA;    	&#xD;&#xA;    	public MyButton(String label) {&#xD;&#xA;    		super(label);&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    	&#xD;&#xA;    	@Override&#xD;&#xA;    	protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {&#xD;&#xA;    		super.paintComponent(g);&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		Dimension originalSize = super.getPreferredSize();&#xD;&#xA;    		int gap = (int) (originalSize.height * 0.2);&#xD;&#xA;    		int x = originalSize.width + gap;&#xD;&#xA;    		int y = gap;&#xD;&#xA;    		int diameter = originalSize.height - (gap * 2);&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		g.setColor(circleColor);&#xD;&#xA;    		g.fillOval(x, y, diameter, diameter);&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    	&#xD;&#xA;    	@Override&#xD;&#xA;    	public Dimension getPreferredSize() {&#xD;&#xA;    		Dimension size = super.getPreferredSize();&#xD;&#xA;    		size.width += size.height;&#xD;&#xA;    		return size;&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    	&#xD;&#xA;    	/*Test the button*/&#xD;&#xA;    	public static void main(String[] args) {&#xD;&#xA;    		MyButton button = new MyButton(&quot;Hello, World!&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		JFrame frame = new JFrame();&#xD;&#xA;    		frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);&#xD;&#xA;    		frame.setSize(400, 400);&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		Container contentPane = frame.getContentPane();&#xD;&#xA;    		contentPane.setLayout(new FlowLayout());&#xD;&#xA;    		contentPane.add(button);&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		frame.setVisible(true);&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that by overriding **paintComponent** that the contents of the button can be changed, but that the border is painted by the **paintBorder** method. The **getPreferredSize** method also needs to be managed in order to dynamically support changes to the content. Care needs to be taken when measuring font metrics and image dimensions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For creating a control that you can rely on, the above code is not the correct approach. Dimensions and colours are dynamic in Swing and are dependent on the look and feel being used. Even the default *Metal* look has changed across JRE versions. It would be better to implement **AbstractButton** and conform to the guidelines set out by the Swing API. A good starting point is to look at the **javax.swing.LookAndFeel** and **javax.swing.UIManager** classes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/javax/swing/LookAndFeel.html&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/javax/swing/UIManager.html&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Understanding the anatomy of LookAndFeel is useful for writing controls:&#xD;&#xA;[Creating a Custom Look and Feel][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://java.sun.com/products/jfc/tsc/articles/sce/index.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2561" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2254" RevisionGUID="831add7a-6370-43d0-a526-41ee0911e6f5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:10:26.487" UserId="34" Text="in 1.x there used to be things DataTables couldn't do which DataSets could (don't remember exactly what). All that was changed in 2.x.  My guess is that's why a lot of examples still use DataSets.  DataTables should be quicker as they are more lightweight. If you're only pulling a single resultset, its your best choice between the two." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Since a DataSet is (in effect) just a collection of DataTable objects, you can return multiple distinct sets of data into a single, and therefore more manageable, object.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Performance-wise, you're more likely to get innefficiency from unoptimised queries than from the &quot;wrong&quot; choice of .NET construct.  At least, that's been my experience." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2588" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2277" RevisionGUID="53bb6c26-5dc1-4816-a12a-b916368bf4d2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:22:43.030" UserId="156" Text="From the [Python FAQ][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Lists and tuples, while similar in many respects, are generally used in fundamentally different ways. Tuples can be thought of as being similar to Pascal records or C structs; they're small collections of related data which may be of different types which are operated on as a group. For example, a Cartesian coordinate is appropriately represented as a tuple of two or three numbers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Lists, on the other hand, are more like arrays in other languages. They tend to hold a varying number of objects all of which have the same type and which are operated on one-by-one.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Generally by convention you wouldn't choose a list or a tuple just based on its (im)mutability.  You would choose a tuple for small collections of completely different pieces of data in which a full-blown class would be too heavyweight, and a list for collections of any reasonable size where you have a homogeneous set of data.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.python.org/doc/faq/general/#why-are-there-separate-tuple-and-list-data-types" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2632" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2310" RevisionGUID="be4de725-0fda-42d4-8c74-64dc2a72bba1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:40:20.777" UserId="193" Text="Subversion doesn't really support branches or tags. What it allows instead is a very very light and efficient copying facility.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Branching and Tagging are, effectively the same. Just copy a whole folder in the repository to somewhere else in the repository.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically this means that it is by convention what copying a folder means - whether it be a backup, tag, branch or whater. Depending upon how you want to think about things (normally depending upon which SCM tool you have used in the past) you need to set up a folder structure within your repository to support your style.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Common styles are to have a bunch of folders at the top of your repository called 'tags', 'branches' and 'trunk' etc. - that allows you to copy your whole 'trunk' (or sub-sets) into the tags and/or branches folders. If you have more than one project you might want to replicate this kind of structure under each project:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It can take a while to get used to the concept - but it works - just make sure you (and your team) are clear on the conventions that you are going to use. It is also a good idea to have a good naming convention - something that tells you why the branch/tag was made and whether it is still apropriate - consider ways of archiving branches that are obsolete." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2633" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="2311" RevisionGUID="081ebed7-ba73-46d2-9fd2-3db811d4ccc8" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:40:47.470" UserId="394" Text="File size differences after copying a file to a server vía FTP" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2634" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="2311" RevisionGUID="081ebed7-ba73-46d2-9fd2-3db811d4ccc8" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:40:47.470" UserId="394" Text="|python|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2635" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2311" RevisionGUID="081ebed7-ba73-46d2-9fd2-3db811d4ccc8" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:40:47.470" UserId="394" Text="I had an PHP script to update the webserver from a local directory.&#xD;&#xA;I'm migrating the script into Python, it works almost OK but after a PUT command the size of the file&#xD;&#xA;in the server isn't the same as the local file. Once I download again the file from the FTP server,&#xD;&#xA;the only difference is the CR/LF mark. It annoys me because the same script is comparing the size of the&#xD;&#xA;files to update. Also, it works perfectly in PHP vía ftp_put.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    from ftplib import FTP&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ftpserver = &quot;myserver&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    ftpuser = &quot;myuser&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    ftppass = &quot;mypwd&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    locfile =  &quot;g:/test/style.css&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    ftpfile =  &quot;/temp/style.css&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    try:&#xD;&#xA;        ftp = FTP(ftpserver, ftpuser, ftppass)&#xD;&#xA;    except:&#xD;&#xA;        exit (&quot;Cannot connect&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    f = open (locfile, &quot;r&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    try:&#xD;&#xA;        ftp.delete (ftpfile)&#xD;&#xA;    except:&#xD;&#xA;        pass&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # ftp.sendcmd (&quot;TYPE I&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    # ftp.storlines(&quot;STOR %s&quot; % ftpfile, f)&#xD;&#xA;    ftp.storbinary(&quot;STOR %s&quot; % ftpfile, f)&#xD;&#xA;    f.close()&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ftp.dir (ftpfile)&#xD;&#xA;    ftp.quit()&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ###&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any suggestions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;TIA,&#xD;&#xA;Pablo" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2636" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="2300" RevisionGUID="35b3900b-3394-46fd-a9b2-91fc23f751cc" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:30:46.290" UserId="193" Text="How do I build a collection in classic ASP?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2648" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2317" RevisionGUID="56398fa1-13bc-4acc-98c0-3fac60a00981" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:45:47.867" UserId="17" Text="Well if you go under the properties of your file in Windows or a *nix environment, you will notice two sizes.  One is the sector size, and one is the actual size.  The sector size is the number of sectors in bytes that are used up on your hard disk.  That is because two files cannot be in the same sector with most modern file systems, so if your file fills up half of the sector the whole sector is marked as filled.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So you might be comparing the sector file size to the actual file size on the FTP server or vice versa." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2653" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2320" RevisionGUID="2c66d4e6-4484-46ef-a196-130aa277580b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:47:00.077" UserId="91" Text="Make sure that the file has svn:keywords &quot;Rev Id&quot; and then put $Rev$ somewhere in there.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See [this question and the answers to it][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/163/how-do-i-sync-the-svn-revision-number-with-my-aspnet-web-site" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2655" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2322" RevisionGUID="8111b061-498a-4819-9455-9f439ea9f4f5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:47:23.790" UserId="390" Text="If you need to populate each member variable by hand you can generalize it a bit as far as the primitives are concerned by using FormatterServices to retrieve in order the list of variable types associated with an object. I've had to do this in a project where I had a lot of different message types coming off the stream and I definitely didn't want to write the serializer/deserializer for each message. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's the code I used to generalize the deserialization from a byte[].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public virtual bool SetMessageBytes(byte[] message)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            MemberInfo[] members = FormatterServices.GetSerializableMembers(this.GetType());&#xD;&#xA;            object[] values = FormatterServices.GetObjectData(this, members);&#xD;&#xA;            int j = 0;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            for (int i = 0; i &lt; members.Length; i++)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                string[] var = members[i].ToString().Split(new char[] { ' ' });&#xD;&#xA;                switch (var[0])&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                    case &quot;UInt32&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;                        values[i] = (UInt32)((message[j] &lt;&lt; 24) + (message[j + 1] &lt;&lt; 16) + (message[j + 2] &lt;&lt; 8) + message[j + 3]);&#xD;&#xA;                        j += 4;&#xD;&#xA;                        break;&#xD;&#xA;                    case &quot;UInt16&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;                        values[i] = (UInt16)((message[j] &lt;&lt; 8) + message[j + 1]);&#xD;&#xA;                        j += 2;&#xD;&#xA;                        break;&#xD;&#xA;                    case &quot;Byte&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;                        values[i] = (byte)message[j++];&#xD;&#xA;                        break;&#xD;&#xA;                    case &quot;UInt32[]&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;                        if (values[i] != null)&#xD;&#xA;                        {&#xD;&#xA;                            int len = ((UInt32[])values[i]).Length;&#xD;&#xA;                            byte[] b = new byte[len * 4];&#xD;&#xA;                            Array.Copy(message, j, b, 0, len * 4);&#xD;&#xA;                            Array.Copy(Utilities.ByteArrayToUInt32Array(b), (UInt32[])values[i], len);&#xD;&#xA;                            j += len * 4;&#xD;&#xA;                        }&#xD;&#xA;                        break;&#xD;&#xA;                    case &quot;Byte[]&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;                        if (values[i] != null)&#xD;&#xA;                        {&#xD;&#xA;                            int len = ((byte[])values[i]).Length;&#xD;&#xA;                            Array.Copy(message, j, (byte[])(values[i]), 0, len);&#xD;&#xA;                            j += len;&#xD;&#xA;                        }&#xD;&#xA;                        break;&#xD;&#xA;                    default:&#xD;&#xA;                        throw new Exception(&quot;ByteExtractable::SetMessageBytes Unsupported Type: &quot; + var[1] + &quot; is of type &quot; +  var[0]);&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;            FormatterServices.PopulateObjectMembers(this, members, values);&#xD;&#xA;            return true;&#xD;&#xA;        }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2656" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2324" RevisionGUID="36a7fdce-2ea9-4982-a63c-0ac1891e08f8" CreationDate="2008-08-05T13:48:19.950" UserId="51" Text="As long as the two databases are on the same physical server (assuming MSSQL) and the username/password being used in the connection string has rights to both DBs, then you should be able to perform a join across the two databases. Example: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    select p.Date,&#xD;&#xA;           p.Amount,&#xD;&#xA;           d.SoftwareName,&#xD;&#xA;           d.DownloadLink&#xD;&#xA;    from   PurchaseDB.dbo.Purchases as p&#xD;&#xA;    join   ProductDB.dbo.Products as d on d.sku = p.sku&#xD;&#xA;    where  p.UserID = 12345" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2735" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2379" RevisionGUID="942a03ad-b3e8-48d7-833c-e07ae3c15b0f" CreationDate="2008-08-05T14:25:19.750" UserId="51" Text="Check out this blog post: [Tweaking the ICallbackEventHandler and Viewstate][1].   <row Id="2737" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="1644" RevisionGUID="f3595eb1-27af-4472-b10a-852ecf784443" CreationDate="2008-08-04T22:17:08.503" UserId="91" Text="|podcast|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2738" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1644" RevisionGUID="f3595eb1-27af-4472-b10a-852ecf784443" CreationDate="2008-08-04T22:17:08.503" UserId="91" Text="Yes, Podcasts, those nice little Audiobooks I can listen to on the way to work. I'm able to read the data &quot;chunk by chunk&quot;, i.e. getting the first 40 bytes of data converting it to a string, get the next 40 bytes, ...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since there are at least three slighlty different version of the data, I would like to read the data directly into a struct. I get an AccessViolationException when using Marshal.PtrToStructure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The stream contains more information than I'm trying to read since I'm not interested in data at the end of the file.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The struct is defined like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Explicit)]&#xD;&#xA;    struct StructType&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        [FieldOffset(0)]&#xD;&#xA;        public string FileDate;&#xD;&#xA;        [FieldOffset(8)]&#xD;&#xA;        public string FileTime;&#xD;&#xA;        [FieldOffset(16)]&#xD;&#xA;        public int Id1;&#xD;&#xA;        [FieldOffset(20)]&#xD;&#xA;        public string Id2;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The examples code is changed from original to make this question shorter.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How would I read binary data from a file into a struct?"   <row Id="2831" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2452" RevisionGUID="be850ece-cb50-41ce-a5f7-34b7e5cc30c7" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:08:42.037" UserId="383" Text="Using the example you gave:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;form&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;text&quot; name=&quot;field1&quot; /&gt;&lt;!-- put your cursor in this field and press Enter --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;prev&quot; value=&quot;Previous Page&quot; /&gt; &lt;!-- This is the button that will submit --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;next&quot; value=&quot;Next Page&quot; /&gt; &lt;!-- But this is the button that I WANT to submit --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/form&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you click on &quot;Previous Page&quot; only the value of &quot;prev&quot; will be submitted. If you click on &quot;Next Page&quot; only the value of &quot;next&quot; will be submitted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If however, you press enter somewhere on the form, neither &quot;prev&quot; nor &quot;next&quot; will be submitted.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So using pseudo code you could do the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    If &quot;prev&quot; submitted then&#xD;&#xA;        Previous Page was click&#xD;&#xA;    Else If &quot;next&quot; submitted then&#xD;&#xA;        Next Page was click&#xD;&#xA;    Else&#xD;&#xA;        No button was click" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2838" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2460" RevisionGUID="0472b836-7749-44af-9e72-31b2ba6e64b2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:19:18.363" UserId="72" Text="@chopeen You could change the way you're calculating these statistics, and instead keep a separate table of all per-product stats.. when an order is placed, loop through the products and update the appropriate records in the stats table.  This would shift a lot of the calculation load to the checkout page rather than running everything in one huge query when running a report.  Of course there are some stats that aren't going to work as well this way, e.g. tracking customers' next purchases after purchasing a particular product." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2840" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2462" RevisionGUID="66c8bce2-ea0e-4c3c-97b0-8686d8967749" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:19:41.187" UserId="71" Text="For SQL Server 2005, I'd recommend using table variables and partially building the data as you go. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To do this, create a table variable that represents your final result set you want to send to the user.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then find your primary table (say the orders table in your example above) and pull that data, plus a bit of supplementary data that is only say one join away (customer name, product name). You can do a SELECT INTO to put this straight into your table variable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From there, iterate through the table and for each row, do a bunch of small SELECT queries that retrieves all the supplemental data you need for your result set. Insert these into each column as you go.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once complete, you can then do a simple SELECT * from your table variable and return this result set to the user.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't have any hard numbers for this, but there have been three distinct instances that I have worked on to date where doing these smaller queries has actually worked faster than doing one massive select query with a bunch of joins." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

This is assuming the advert is on the same server.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If your adverts are on a separate server, then I would suggest it's impossible to do so.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The best way to stop users from blocking adverts, is to have inline text adverts which are generated by the server and dished up inside your html."   <row Id="2864" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2479" RevisionGUID="aee18f54-9b36-4ac5-bc37-07d364a031c1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:37:36.063" UserId="170" Text="You need to think about the different ways that ads are blocked. The first thing to look at is whether they are running noscript, so you could add a script that would check for that. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The next thing is to see if they are blocking flash, a small movie should do that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you look at the adblock site, there is some indication of how it does blocking: &#xD;&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://adblockplus.org/en/faq_internal#elemhide&quot;&gt;http://adblockplus.org/en/faq_internal#elemhide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you look further down that page, you will see that conventional chrome probing will not work, so you need to try and parse the altered DOM."   <row Id="2865" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="2483" RevisionGUID="75fd5c98-7df2-4764-933c-cb2b729a42c6" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:42:30.110" UserId="91" Text="Casting: (NewType) vs. Object as NewType" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2866" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="2483" RevisionGUID="75fd5c98-7df2-4764-933c-cb2b729a42c6" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:42:30.110" UserId="91" Text="|c#|.net|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2867" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2483" RevisionGUID="75fd5c98-7df2-4764-933c-cb2b729a42c6" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:42:30.110" UserId="91" Text="What is actually the difference between these two casts?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SomeClass sc = (SomeClass)SomeObject;&#xD;&#xA;    SomeClass sc2 = SomeObject as SomeClass;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Normally, they should both be explicit casts to the specified type?"   <row Id="2870" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2487" RevisionGUID="2c38421d-e774-4322-9c68-fbb01f48ee6e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:44:46.330" UserId="266" Text="The former will throw an exception if the source type can't be cast to the target type. The latter will result in sc2 being a null reference, but no exception." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2871" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2489" RevisionGUID="f20a3cf6-f059-4602-9e45-b8c35f7f4022" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:45:06.610" UserDisplayName="user316" Text="The parenthetical cast throws an exception if the cast attempt fails. The &quot;as&quot; cast returns null if the cast attempt fails." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2872" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2491" RevisionGUID="a7a6a800-fd85-4ca0-b233-da2ab16af853" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:47:15.997" UserDisplayName="user316" Text="I've honestly never read it myself, but [Concurrent Programming in Java](http://www.amazon.com/Concurrent-Programming-Java-TM-Principles/dp/0201310090/ref=pd_bbs_sr_2?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1217951195&amp;sr=8-2) is a book I've heard recommended by several people."   <row Id="2873" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2492" RevisionGUID="8891de57-97ed-4884-8877-fae688a583d2" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:47:51.830" UserId="2089740" Text="Alright. From a theoretical point of view, given that the distortion is &quot;arbitrary&quot;, and any solution requires you to model this arbitrary distortion, you obviously can't get an &quot;answer&quot;. However, any solution is going to involve imposing (usually implicitly) some model of the distortion that may or may not reflect the reality of the situation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since you seem to be most interested in models that presume some sort of local continuity of the distortion mapping, the most obvious choice is the one you've already tried: linear interpolaton between the nearest points. Going beyond that is going to require more sophisticated mathematical and numerical analysis knowledge.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You are incorrect, however, in presuming you cannot expand this to more points. You can by using a least-squared error approach. Find the linear answer that minimizes the error of the other points. This is probably the most straight-forward extension. In other words, take the 5 nearest points and try to come up with a linear approximation that minimizes the error of those points. And use that. I would try this next.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If that doesn't work, then the assumption of linearity over the area of N points is broken. At that point you'll need to upgrade to either a quadratic or cubic model. The math is going to get hectic at that point." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2874" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2494" RevisionGUID="b08eb97e-e34b-4d49-b2d0-42ce1f6ba906" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:48:10.163" UserId="305" Text="I believe [DB Designer](http://www.fabforce.net/dbdesigner4/) does something like that.  And I think they even have a free version.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*edit*&#xD;&#xA;Never mind.  Michael's link is much better." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2876" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2496" RevisionGUID="d8ab2ade-3c24-407c-a178-ae5ce827e25a" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:48:57.413" UserId="398" Text="[http://www.cilk.com/multicore-e-book/][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That's a nice general overview of the sitution, if you're looking for tuorials and books it might be best to specify a language as a starting point so you can mess around with some code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.cilk.com/multicore-e-book/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2877" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2497" RevisionGUID="a8e7fed4-c862-4191-883f-cb624c944c95" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:49:34.310" UserId="402" Text="They'll throw different exceptions. &lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;() : NullReferenceException &lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;as : InvalidCastException &lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Which could help for debugging.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The &quot;as&quot; keyword attempts to cast the object and if the cast fails, null is returned silently. The () cast operator will throw an exception immediately if the cast fails.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;Only use the C# &quot;as&quot; keyword where you are expecting the cast to fail in a non-exceptional case. If you are counting on a cast to succeed and are unprepared to receive any object that would fail, you should use the () cast operator so that an appropriate and helpful exception is thrown.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For code examples and a further explanation: [http://blog.nerdbank.net/2008/06/when-not-to-use-c-keyword.html][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blog.nerdbank.net/2008/06/when-not-to-use-c-keyword.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2878" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2498" RevisionGUID="14c2d0df-8a6a-4867-834f-b3bc1c4f3c41" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:50:05.120" UserDisplayName="user316" Text="The two self-balancing BSTs I'm most familiar with are red-black and AVL, so I can't say for certain if any other solutions are better, but as I recall, red-black has faster insertion and slower retrieval compared to AVL. So if insertion is a higher priority than retrieval, red-black may be a better solution." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2880" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2490" RevisionGUID="ea6db8e2-892b-45a6-a46a-f3aca5c450b5" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:46:35.157" UserId="275" Text="Most of the people use .NET serialization (there is faster binary and slower XML formatter, they both depend on reflection)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you want the fastest (unsafe) way - go ahead:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Writing:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    YourStruct o = new YourStruct();&#xD;&#xA;    byte[] buffer = new byte[Marshal.SizeOf(typeof(YourStruct))];&#xD;&#xA;    GCHandle handle = GCHandle.Alloc(buffer, GCHandleType.Pinned);&#xD;&#xA;    Marshal.StructureToPtr(o, handle.AddrOfPinnedObject(), false);&#xD;&#xA;    handle.Free();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reading:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    handle = GCHandle.Alloc(buffer, GCHandleType.Pinned);&#xD;&#xA;    o = (YourStruct)Marshal.PtrToStructure(handle.AddrOfPinnedObject(), typeof(YourStruct));&#xD;&#xA;    handle.Free();" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2881" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2490" RevisionGUID="b0aeafe5-2191-4436-bdc9-f408cd8cef96" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:50:23.713" UserId="275" Text="Most of the people use .NET serialization (there is faster binary and slower XML formatter, they both depend on reflection and are version tolerant to certain degree)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you want the fastest (unsafe) way - why not:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Writing:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    YourStruct o = new YourStruct();&#xD;&#xA;    byte[] buffer = new byte[Marshal.SizeOf(typeof(YourStruct))];&#xD;&#xA;    GCHandle handle = GCHandle.Alloc(buffer, GCHandleType.Pinned);&#xD;&#xA;    Marshal.StructureToPtr(o, handle.AddrOfPinnedObject(), false);&#xD;&#xA;    handle.Free();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reading:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    handle = GCHandle.Alloc(buffer, GCHandleType.Pinned);&#xD;&#xA;    o = (YourStruct)Marshal.PtrToStructure(handle.AddrOfPinnedObject(), typeof(YourStruct));&#xD;&#xA;    handle.Free();" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2882" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2500" RevisionGUID="0f3c2a8d-3182-4d98-88b3-3e61877af897" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:51:11.873" UserId="383" Text="As you've said&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; To me, that seems a bit overkill, since viewing the site without Javascript will probably break most of it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This isn't progressive enhancement. Progressive enhancement is when the site works perfectly with JavaScript or CSS and then adding these extra technologies/code, you increase the usability and functionality of the website.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The best example I can give is the tag input box on this website. With JavaScript turned off, it would still work allowing you to enter tags separated with a space. With JavaScript turned on, you get a drop down with suggestions of previous entries.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is progressive enhancement." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2896" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2506" RevisionGUID="71d49a6f-52c7-43a1-8f5b-eb923669c949" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:57:00.113" UserId="312" Text="Going at it from the other direction is sometimes referred to as graceful degradation.  This is usually needed when the site is built first with the enhanced functionality afforded by the various technologies then modified to degrade gracefully for browsers with those technologies are not available.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is also graceful degradation when designing to work with older browsers (ancient in the Internets terminology) such as IE 5.5, Netscape, etc...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In my opinion it is much more work to gracefully degrade the application.  Progressively enhancing it tends to be much more efficient; however, sometimes the need to take an existing app and make it accessible in these lacking environments arise." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2899" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2511" RevisionGUID="ad7695b9-c55d-4434-9ea7-0dd5ed6f33fe" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:59:27.563" UserId="2089740" Text="[Red-black](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-black_tree) is better than AVL for insertion-heavy applications. If you foresee relatively uniform look-up, then Red-black is the way to go. If you foresee a relatively unbalanced look-up where more recently viewed elements are more likely to be viewed again, you want to use [splay trees](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Splay_tree)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2913" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2523" RevisionGUID="de917b35-754b-4825-96a2-af018d2bec98" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:16:01.150" UserId="422" Text="[The Dragon Book][1] is definitely the &quot;building compilers&quot; book, but if your language isn't quite as complicated as the current generation of languages, you may want to look at the Interpreter pattern from [Design Patterns][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The example in the book designs a regular expression-like language and is well thought through, but as they say in the book, it's good for thinking through the process but is effective really only on small languages. However, it is much faster to write an Interpreter for a small language with this pattern than having to learn about all the different types of parsers, yacc and lex, et cetera...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/Compilers-Principles-Techniques-Tools-2nd/dp/0321486811/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.amazon.com/Design-Patterns-Object-Oriented-Addison-Wesley-Professional/dp/0201633612/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2929" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2547" RevisionGUID="881429c6-a9c2-4beb-98ae-8baede716e1b" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:36:43.933" UserId="91" Text="XML/SWF Charts does Chart off XML:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[http://www.maani.us/xml_charts/][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.maani.us/xml_charts/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2930" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2548" RevisionGUID="1ce06349-6e3a-4e10-a3fb-a950f3bb9a9e" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:36:53.840" UserId="341" Text="I understand BDD to be more about **specification** than **testing**. It is linked to Domain Driven Design (don't you love these *DD acronyms?). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It is linked with a certain way to write user stories, including high-level tests. An example by [Tom Teh Thij][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Story: User logging in&#xD;&#xA;      As a user&#xD;&#xA;      I want to login with my details&#xD;&#xA;      So that I can get access to the site&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Scenario: User uses wrong password&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;      Given a username 'jdoe'&#xD;&#xA;      And a password 'letmein'&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;      When the user logs in with username and password&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;      Then the login form should be shown again&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(In his article, Tom goes on to directly execute this test specification in Ruby.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The pope of BDD is [Dan North][2]. You'll find a great introduction in his [Introducing BDD][3] article.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You will find a comparison of BDD and TDD in this [video][4]. Also an opinion about DBB as &quot;TDD done right&quot; by [Jeremy D. Miller][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://tomtenthij.co.uk/2008/1/25/rspec-plain-text-story-runner-on-a-fresh-rails-app&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://dannorth.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://dannorth.net/introducing-bdd&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=8135690990081075324&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://codebetter.com/blogs/jeremy.miller/archive/2007/09/06/bdd-tdd-and-the-other-double-d-s.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2932" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2554" RevisionGUID="af44f183-82cf-453d-9ab2-2df7157446e6" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:40:35.063" UserId="46" Text="Here is another article for the [c# programming language][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;c# passes its arguments **by value** (by default)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    private void swap(string a, string b) {&#xD;&#xA;      string tmp = a;&#xD;&#xA;      a = b;&#xD;&#xA;      b = tmp;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;calling this version of swap will thus have no result:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    string x = &quot;foo&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    string y = &quot;bar&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    swap(x, y);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &quot;output: &#xD;&#xA;    x: foo&#xD;&#xA;    y: bar&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;however, [unlike java][2] c# *does* give the developer the opportunity to pass parameters **by reference**, this is done by using the 'ref' keyword before the type of the parameter:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    private void swap(ref string a, ref string b) {&#xD;&#xA;      string tmp = a;&#xD;&#xA;      a = b;&#xD;&#xA;      b = tmp;&#xD;&#xA;    } &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;this swap *will* change the value of the referenced parameter:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    string x = &quot;foo&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    string y = &quot;bar&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    swap(x, y);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &quot;output: &#xD;&#xA;    x: bar&#xD;&#xA;    y: foo&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;c# also has a **out keyword**, and the difference between ref and out is a subtle one.&#xD;&#xA;[from msdn:][3]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; The caller of a method which takes an&#xD;&#xA;&gt; **out parameter** is not required to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; assign to the variable passed as the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; out parameter prior to the call;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; however, the callee is *required to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; assign to the out parameter before&#xD;&#xA;&gt; returning.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; In contrast **ref parameters** are&#xD;&#xA;&gt; *considered initially assigned* by the&#xD;&#xA;&gt; callee. As such, the callee is *not&#xD;&#xA;&gt; required to assign to the ref*&#xD;&#xA;&gt; parameter before use. Ref parameters&#xD;&#xA;&gt; are passed both into and out of a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; method.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;a small pitfall is, like in java, that **objects passed by value can still be changed using their inner methods**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**conclusion:** &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - c# passes its parameters, by default, **by value** &#xD;&#xA;  - but when needed parameters can also be passed **by reference** using the ref keyword&#xD;&#xA;  - inner methods from a parameter passed by value **will alter** the object (if that method itself alters some values)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;useful links:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/vcsharp/aa336814.aspx][4]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/saragana/Willswapwork11162005012542AM/Willswapwork.aspx][5]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://en.csharp-online.net/Value_vs_Reference][6]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/vcsharp/default.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2027/#2028&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/vcsharp/aa336814.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/vcsharp/aa336814.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/saragana/Willswapwork11162005012542AM/Willswapwork.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://en.csharp-online.net/Value_vs_Reference" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="2933" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2555" RevisionGUID="0171dbe0-d2e7-40d1-98ca-0346757a55ed" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:40:37.840" UserId="77" Text="I know you said flash, but this is a good silverlight chart api. &lt;http://www.visifire.com/&gt;. Always good to keep your options open right?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Had to plug silverlight, but you can also take a look at [Yahoo!'s YUI charting](http://developer.yahoo.com/yui/charts/) component."   <row Id="2934" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2546" RevisionGUID="691d453e-3a75-47bf-bf82-c424a787f115" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:36:43.463" UserId="152" Text="You can add a mouse click event to the TreeView, then select the correct node using GetNodeAt given the mouse coordinates provided by the MouseEventArgs.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void treeView1MouseUp(object sender, MouseEventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        if(e.Button == MouseButtons.Right)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Select the clicked node&#xD;&#xA;            treeView1.SelectedNode = treeView1.GetNodeAt(e.X, e.Y);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            if(treeView1.SelectedNode != null)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                myContextMenuStrip.Show(treeView1, e.Location)&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="16" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="18" RevisionGUID="0cfdfa19-039f-4645-8a48-1c316543b98f" CreationDate="2008-08-01T05:12:44.193" UserDisplayName="phpguy" Text="For a table like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    CREATE TABLE binary_data (&#xD;&#xA;    id INT(4) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,&#xD;&#xA;    description CHAR(50),&#xD;&#xA;    bin_data LONGBLOB,&#xD;&#xA;    filename CHAR(50),&#xD;&#xA;    filesize CHAR(50),&#xD;&#xA;    filetype CHAR(50)&#xD;&#xA;    );&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a PHP example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?php&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    // store.php3 - by Florian Dittmer &lt;dittmer@gmx.net&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    // Example php script to demonstrate the storing of binary files into&#xD;&#xA;    // an sql database. More information can be found at http://www.phpbuilder.com/&#xD;&#xA;    ?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &lt;html&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;head&gt;&lt;title&gt;Store binary data into SQL Database&lt;/title&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;body&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?php&#xD;&#xA;    // code that will be executed if the form has been submitted:&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    if ($submit) {&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        // connect to the database&#xD;&#xA;        // (you may have to adjust the hostname,username or password)&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        MYSQL_CONNECT(&quot;localhost&quot;,&quot;root&quot;,&quot;password&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        mysql_select_db(&quot;binary_data&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        $data = addslashes(fread(fopen($form_data, &quot;r&quot;), filesize($form_data)));&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        $result=MYSQL_QUERY(&quot;INSERT INTO binary_data (description,bin_data,filename,filesize,filetype) &quot;.&#xD;&#xA;            &quot;VALUES ('$form_description','$data','$form_data_name','$form_data_size','$form_data_type')&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        $id= mysql_insert_id();&#xD;&#xA;        print &quot;&lt;p&gt;This file has the following Database ID: &lt;b&gt;$id&lt;/b&gt;&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        MYSQL_CLOSE();&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    } else {&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        // else show the form to submit new data:&#xD;&#xA;    ?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        &lt;form method=&quot;post&quot; action=&quot;&lt;?php echo $PHP_SELF; ?&gt;&quot; enctype=&quot;multipart/form-data&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        File Description:&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;input type=&quot;text&quot; name=&quot;form_description&quot;  size=&quot;40&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;input type=&quot;hidden&quot; name=&quot;MAX_FILE_SIZE&quot; value=&quot;1000000&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;br&gt;File to upload/store in database:&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;input type=&quot;file&quot; name=&quot;form_data&quot;  size=&quot;40&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;p&gt;&lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;submit&quot; value=&quot;submit&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/form&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?php&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    ?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/body&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/html&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4299" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3699" RevisionGUID="74e055b7-8019-4ec9-9dba-4ba580a1f592" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:16:00.077" UserId="265" Text="HTML 4.01. There is absolutely **no reason** to use XHTML for anything but experimental or academic problems that you only want to run on the 'obscure' web browsers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;XHTML Transitional is completely pointless even to _those_ browsers, so I'm not sure why anyone would aim for that. It's actually pretty alarming that a number of people would recommend that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd say aiming for HTML 4.01 is the most predictable, but Teifion is right really, &quot;anything that renders your page will do&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in response to [Michael Stum][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; XHTML is XML based, so it allows easier parsing and you can also use the XML Components of most IDEs to programatically query and insert stuff.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is certainly not true. A lot of XHTML on the web (if not most) does not conform to XML validity (and it needn't - it's not being sent as XML). Trying to treat this like XML when dealing with it is just going to earn you a lot of headaches. This page on Stack Overflow, for instance, will generate errors with many unforgiving XML tools for having invalid mark-up.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3654/html-version-choice#3659" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4305" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3718" RevisionGUID="d0a0ffae-5ebb-4275-bb82-d309f76a4371" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:18:58.357" UserId="514" Text="When i worked in a small dev team (small meaning me, another programmer and the boss), it was quite the chaotic mess.  However we found that Assigning a &quot;gatekeeper&quot; type of process worked for us.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The gatekeeper was the person who had done the most work on the app (in this case, i had 2 projects i developed from the ground up, he had like 4). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, whenever he had to work on my projects, he'd notify me that he was doing work, i'd make sure the repository was up-to-date and buildable, then he would pull down, make his changes, then commit.  He would inform me that it was done, i would pull down, build and deploy.  If there were DB changes we had a DB Change folder with all the scripts that would correct the DB.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It's obviously got a lot of holes in it, but the process worked for us, and kept us from building over each other." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4312" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="3725" RevisionGUID="5e228b77-0b61-4ff1-8bd1-9fea9c942df4" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:22:27.350" UserId="551" Text="Best method for creating a &quot;tree-view preferences dialog&quot; type of interface in C#?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

The function of the application is simply a pass-through for data from a serial device to a file. This seems really, really clunky while designing it. It basically means I have tons of container controls beyond the edge of the main window during design time that I have to keep scrolling the main window over to in order to work with them.   <row Id="19642" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15542" RevisionGUID="731f2724-78e0-4c13-bad8-50869bda5591" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:10:14.573" UserId="1693" Text="perl -e 'print &quot;\xFF&quot;', where FF is the hex code of the ACSII code you want to print. So for ACSII code 2, it would be \x02." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19648" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15547" RevisionGUID="fc56828b-b965-4ca5-b407-59325167ebf8" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:14:14.067" UserId="872" Text="@James&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I'm not even really clear why it needs the additional data, as you wouldn't call delete[] on the array anyway, so I don't entirely see why it needs to know how many items are in it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;After giving this some thought, I agree with you.  There is no reason why placement new should need to store the number of elements, because there is no placement delete.  Since there's no placement delete, there's no reason for placement new to store the number of elements.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I also tested this with gcc on my Mac, using a class with a destructor.  On my system, placement new was *not* changing the pointer.  This makes me wonder if this is a VC++ issue, and whether this might violate the standard (the standard doesn't specifically address this, so far as I can find)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48909" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35891" RevisionGUID="72e43a82-07a2-4c75-a9b3-7997e6b3ed23" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:20:50.513" UserId="2025" Text="As far as I remember there is an xml element for the image data. You can use this [website][1] to encode a file (use the upload field). Then just copy and paste the data to the XML element.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You could also use PHP to do this like so:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?php&#xD;&#xA;        // Use appropriate function for your filetype&#xD;&#xA;        // - file_get_contents + imagecreatefromstring if needed&#xD;&#xA;        $im = imagecreatefromgif('filename.gif');&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        $imdata = base64_encode($im);&#xD;&#xA;        echo($imdata);&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        imagedestroy($im);&#xD;&#xA;    ?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Use [Mozilla's guide][2] for help on creating OpenSearch plugins. For example, the icon element is used like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;Image width=&quot;16&quot; height=&quot;16&quot;&gt;data:image/x-icon;base64,imageData&lt;/Image&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Where `imageData` is your base64 data.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: http://www.motobit.com/util/base64-decoder-encoder.asp&#xD;&#xA;[2]: http://developer.mozilla.org/en/Creating_OpenSearch_plugins_for_Firefox" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54738" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39510" RevisionGUID="944093e3-503a-461f-9873-fefec54e9b73" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:28:17.263" UserId="3230" Text="I'm using a slightly modified version of that plugin so I'm not 100% sure that this will be the same for you, but for me the default is to redirect to the root path, or the page you were trying to get to if there is one.   <row Id="60811" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43514" RevisionGUID="34a6d9a0-3910-4817-b2ec-b1d95307e5d3" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:29:15.100" UserId="1219" Text="A few cons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - 2 points of failure&#xD;&#xA;  - Application logic will have to take into account the delay between writing something and then reading it, since it won't be available immediately from the secondary database&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A strategy I have used is to send key reporting data to a secondary database nightly, de-normalizing it on the way, so that beefy queries can run on that database instead of locking up tables and stealing resources from the OLTP server.  I'm not using any formal data warehousing or replication tools, rather I identify problem queries that are Ok without up-to-the-minute data and create data structures on the secondary server specifically for those queries.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;There are definitely pros to the &quot;replicate everything&quot; approach:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - You can run any ad-hoc query on the secondary, since it has all of your data&#xD;&#xA;  - If your primary server dies, you can re-purpose the secondary quickly to take over" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60812" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43515" RevisionGUID="04505009-2d01-4777-bf1a-8bdd4bc903e3" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:29:29.437" UserId="3355" Text="I would honestly recommend using one of the many libraries available for Ajax. I use [prototype][1] myself, while others prefer [jQuery][2]. I like prototype because it's pretty minimal. The [Prototype Ajax tutorial][3] explains it well. It also allows you to handle errors easily.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    new Ajax.Request('/some_url',&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;        method:'get',&#xD;&#xA;        onSuccess: function(transport){&#xD;&#xA;          var response = transport.responseText || &quot;no response text&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;          alert(&quot;Success! \n\n&quot; + response);&#xD;&#xA;        },&#xD;&#xA;        onFailure: function(){ alert('Something went wrong...') }&#xD;&#xA;      });&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.prototypejs.org/api&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://jquery.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.prototypejs.org/learn/introduction-to-ajax&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="47049" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="21294" RevisionGUID="ee5d125c-fce7-4ce7-8c0e-30deebc9218c" CreationDate="2008-08-28T19:31:28.023" UserId="1341" Comment="added 292 characters in body" Text="How can you reliably and dynamically load a javascript file?  This will can be used to implement a module or component that when 'initialized' the component will dynamically load all needed javascript library scripts on demand.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The client that uses the component isn't required to load all the library script files (and manually insert &lt;script&gt; tags into their web page) that implement this component - just the 'main' component script file.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How do mainstream javascript libraries accomplish this (Prototype, jquery, etc)?  Do these tools merge multiple javascript files into a single redistributable 'build' version of a script file?  Or do they do any dynamic loading of ancillary 'library' scripts?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;An addition to this question --- is there a way to handle the event after a dynamically included javascript file is loaded?  Prototype has document.observe for document-wide events.  Example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    document.observe(&quot;dom:loaded&quot;, function() {&#xD;&#xA;      // initially hide all containers for tab content&#xD;&#xA;      $$('div.tabcontent').invoke('hide');&#xD;&#xA;    });&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What are the available events for a script element?&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="12105" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="9895" RevisionGUID="0ac40b38-aa3d-4827-a60e-d32c5124aa37" CreationDate="2008-08-13T14:34:54.057" UserId="543" Text="Putting your resume up online somewhere helps, I get a lot of recruitment emails from people who happened on my resume via googling.   <row Id="12106" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="9896" RevisionGUID="58b3abf6-02c4-43c5-b1be-f5bd394f3faf" CreationDate="2008-08-13T14:35:16.693" UserDisplayName="user1228" Text="If you're running it on a 2k3 box, you need to install all updates for Sql Server and the 2003 server.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Check the event logs after you start the Sql Server.  It logs everything well, telling you if its being blocked, and where it is listening for connections.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From a remote machine, you can use telnet to see if a sql server is listening for remote connections.  You just need the IP and the port of the server (default is 1433).  From the command line:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    telnet 192.168.10.10 1433&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you get a blank screen, its listening.  If you get thrown back to the command prompt, something is blocking you." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="12112" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="9904" RevisionGUID="aa81398c-04bc-43e8-b3d9-5eb3f1f36b9c" CreationDate="2008-08-13T14:42:52.357" UserId="914" Text="This was the fastest I could come up with after some fiddling:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    private function castMethod4(dateString:String):Date {			&#xD;&#xA;        if ( dateString == null ) &#xD;&#xA;            return null;    &#xD;&#xA;        if ( dateString.length != 10 &amp;&amp; dateString.length != 19) &#xD;&#xA;            return null;&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;        dateString = dateString.replace(&quot;-&quot;, &quot;/&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;        dateString = dateString.replace(&quot;-&quot;, &quot;/&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;	&#xD;&#xA;        return new Date(Date.parse( dateString ));&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I get 50k iterations in about 470ms for castMethod2() on my computer and 300 ms for my version (that's the same amount of work done in 63% of the time). I'd definitely say both are &quot;Good enough&quot; unless you're parsing silly amounts of dates.  " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="12114" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="9907" RevisionGUID="34df4944-36f1-4724-9765-a34c1378d64b" CreationDate="2008-08-13T14:44:10.780" UserId="737" Text="&gt; What specifically does that question mean?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Good question.  If reversing the &quot;ON&quot; bits means reversing only the bits that are &quot;ON&quot;, then you will always get 0, no matter what the input is.  If it means reversing *all* the bits, i.e. changing all 1s to 0s and all 0s to 1s, which is how I initially read it, then that's just a bitwise NOT, or complement.  C-based languages have a complement operator, &lt;code&gt;~&lt;/code&gt;, that does this.  For example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    unsigned char b = 102;      /* 0x66, 01100110 */&#xD;&#xA;    unsigned char reverse = ~b; /* 0x99, 10011001 */&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="29458" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="23207" RevisionGUID="010c8d70-526a-4dd9-83fa-729f91c42d16" CreationDate="2008-08-22T19:03:43.320" UserId="1585" Text="Javascript doesn't really have namespace or packages like other languages. Instead it has closures. If you have an application that consists of multiple functions, variables and objects, then you should put them inside a single global object. This will have the same effect as a namespace. &#xD;&#xA;For example:&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;&#xD;&#xA;var namespace = {&#xD;&#xA;  this.foo; function(){&#xD;&#xA;    ...&#xD;&#xA;  },&#xD;&#xA;  this.foo.prototype.getLength; function(){&#xD;&#xA;    ...&#xD;&#xA;  }&#xD;&#xA;}&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You could also create a set of nested objects and simulate packages:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    loadPackage = function(){&#xD;&#xA;      var path = arguments[0];&#xD;&#xA;      for(var i=1; i&lt;arguments.length; i++){&#xD;&#xA;        if(!path[arguments[i]]){&#xD;&#xA;          path[arguments[i]] = {};&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        path = path[arguments[i]];&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;      return path;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    loadPackage(this, &quot;com&quot;, &quot;google&quot;, &quot;mail&quot;) = {&#xD;&#xA;      username: &quot;gundersen&quot;,&#xD;&#xA;      login: function(password){&#xD;&#xA;        ...&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    this.com.google.mail.login(&quot;mySecretPassword&quot;);" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="29459" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="23208" RevisionGUID="bd16513d-cc86-4bea-af27-9f4027d0efd0" CreationDate="2008-08-22T19:03:51.183" UserId="811" Text="Downside? It's fairly limited - you trigger a &quot;GET&quot; request and get back some script that's executed. You don't get error handling if your server throws an error, so you need to wrap all errors in JSON as well. You can't really cancel or retry the request. You're at the mercy of the various browser author opinions of &quot;correct&quot; behavior for dynamically-generated `&lt;script&gt;` tags. Debugging is somewhat more difficult. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, i've used it on occasion, and haven't suffered. YMMV." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="56790" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="40678" RevisionGUID="d90ce111-827d-42cc-af66-e51ff7de202e" CreationDate="2008-09-02T21:09:16.440" UserId="4223" Text="Instead of using a DOMParser, use a SAXParser.  This reads from an input stream or reader so you can keep the XML on disk instead of loading it all into memory." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="56791" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="40678" RevisionGUID="3810e0ae-bd0e-402c-ba7e-f2cb8bbe76d5" CreationDate="2008-09-02T23:41:04.280" UserId="4223" Comment="Added a code example" Text="Instead of using a DOMParser, use a SAXParser.  This reads from an input stream or reader so you can keep the XML on disk instead of loading it all into memory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SAXParserFactory factory = SAXParserFactory.newInstance();&#xD;&#xA;    factory.setValidating(true);&#xD;&#xA;    factory.setNamespaceAware(true);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SAXParser parser = factory.newSAXParser();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    XMLReader reader = parser.getXMLReader();&#xD;&#xA;    reader.setErrorHandler(new SimpleErrorHandler());&#xD;&#xA;    reader.parse(new InputSource(new FileReader (&quot;document.xml&quot;)));&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="56796" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="40929" RevisionGUID="36c6f04a-419f-46f4-94b0-67e0fe60acfb" CreationDate="2008-09-02T23:46:21.087" UserId="4301" Text="I'm not entirely sure I understand your question, especially the bit about displaying two SPField collections. Sorry if this turns out to be the answer to a completely different question!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Anyway here's a quick demo walkthrough of using the MultipleLookupField in a web part.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Create a team site. Add a few tasks to the task list. Also put a document in the Shared Documents library. Create a new column in the Shared Documents library; call it &quot;Related&quot;, have it be a Lookup into the Title field of the Tasks list, and allow multiple values.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now create a web part, do all the usual boilerplate and then add this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Label l;&#xD;&#xA;    MultipleLookupField mlf;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    protected override void CreateChildControls()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        base.CreateChildControls();&#xD;&#xA;        SPList list = SPContext.Current.Web.Lists[&quot;Shared Documents&quot;];&#xD;&#xA;        if (list != null &amp;&amp; list.Items.Count &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            LiteralControl lit = new LiteralControl(&quot;Associate tasks to &quot; + &#xD;&#xA;                                 list.Items[0].Name);&#xD;&#xA;            this.Controls.Add(lit);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            mlf = new MultipleLookupField();&#xD;&#xA;            mlf.ControlMode = SPControlMode.Edit;&#xD;&#xA;            mlf.FieldName = &quot;Related&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;            mlf.ItemId = list.Items[0].ID;&#xD;&#xA;            mlf.ListId = list.ID;&#xD;&#xA;            mlf.ID = &quot;Related&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;            this.Controls.Add(mlf);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            Button b = new Button();&#xD;&#xA;            b.Text = &quot;Change&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;            b.Click += new EventHandler(bClick);&#xD;&#xA;            this.Controls.Add(b);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            l = new Label();&#xD;&#xA;            this.Controls.Add(l);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    void bClick(object sender, EventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        l.Text = &quot;&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;        foreach (SPFieldLookupValue val in (SPFieldLookupValueCollection)mlf.Value)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            l.Text += val.LookupValue.ToString() + &quot; &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        SPListItem listitem = mlf.List.Items[0];&#xD;&#xA;        listitem[&quot;Related&quot;] = mlf.Value;&#xD;&#xA;        listitem.Update();&#xD;&#xA;        mlf.Value = listitem[&quot;Related&quot;];&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    protected override void OnInit(EventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        base.OnInit(e);&#xD;&#xA;        EnsureChildControls();&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Granted, this is borderline ridiculous -- everything is hard-coded, there is no error-handling at all, and it serves no useful purpose -- but it's only meant as a quick demo. Now build and deploy this web part and add an instance of it to your team site's homepage; it should allow you to get and set the tasks which are associated with the first document in the library.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The strange bit towards the end of the button Click handler, where we read a value from mlf.Value and then write it back again, appears to be required if you want the UI to stay in sync with the actual list values. Try omitting the last line of bClick to see what I mean. This has been driving me nuts for the last hour or so, and I'm hoping another commenter can come up with a better approach..." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="23502" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="18610" RevisionGUID="eb75a87b-a15b-44d5-a0e7-1438abc8ad59" CreationDate="2008-08-20T19:12:59.630" UserId="1862" Text="Actually, because of leap years, your code would be off.  Since the timespan object has no TotalYears property the best way to get it would be this&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Pardon the VB.Net&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Dim myAge AS Integer = DateTime.Now.year - BirthDate.year&#xD;&#xA;    If Birthdate.month &lt; DateTime.Now.Month _&#xD;&#xA;    OrElse BirthDate.Month = DateTime.Now.Month AndAlso Birthdate.Day &lt; DateTime.Now.Day Then&#xD;&#xA;    MyAge -= 1&#xD;&#xA;    END IF&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="23503" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="18611" RevisionGUID="5d7127d1-10f2-4bb0-ba9d-57c24b9e8513" CreationDate="2008-08-20T19:13:25.323" UserId="51" Text="I think you have your answer right here: [Reflector sold to Red Gate][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blog.lutzroeder.com/2008/08/future-of-net-reflector.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="23504" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="18612" RevisionGUID="9eb32433-ec70-47db-8dd8-4a84edd3aac2" CreationDate="2008-08-20T19:14:19.237" UserId="1438" Text="A more complete discussion of the pitfalls of using a regex to find matching tags can be found at: &lt;http://faq.perl.org/perlfaq4.html#How_do_I_find_matchi&gt;.  In particular, be aware that nesting tags really need a full-fledged parser in order to be interpreted correctly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that case sensitivity will need to be turned off in order to answer the question as stated.  In perl, that's the **i** modifier:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $ echo &quot;Data Data Data [Start] Data i want [End] Data&quot; \&#xD;&#xA;      | perl -ne '/\[start\](.*?)\[end\]/i; print &quot;$1\n&quot;'&#xD;&#xA;     Data i want &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The other trick is to use the ***?** quantifier which turns off the greediness of the captured match.  For instance, if you have a non-matching **[end]** tag:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Data Data [Start] Data i want [End] Data [end]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;you probably don't want to capture:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;     Data i want [End] Data&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
