  <row Id="23514" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="18607" RevisionGUID="90f1f4a9-8a3b-466b-acd9-ebd292cd81c7" CreationDate="2008-08-20T19:11:36.513" UserId="1926" Text="As of PHP 5.1.0 you can use [date__default__timezone_set()][1] function to set the default timezone used by all date/time functions in a script. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For MySql (quoted from [MySQL Server Time Zone Support][2] page)&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Before MySQL 4.1.3, the server operates only in the system time zone set at startup. Beginning with MySQL 4.1.3, the server maintains several time zone settings, some of which can be modified at runtime. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Of interest to you is per-connection setting of the time zones, which you would use at the beginning of your scripts&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SET timezone = 'Europe/London';&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for detecting the client timezone setting, you could use a bit of JavaScript to get and save that information to a cookie, and use it on subsequent page reads, to calculate the proper timezone.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    //Returns the offset (time difference) between Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) &#xD;&#xA;    //and local time of Date object, in minutes.&#xD;&#xA;    var offset = new Date().getTimezoneOffset(); &#xD;&#xA;    document.cookie = 'timezoneOffset=' + escape(offset);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Or you could offer users the chioce to set their time zones themselves.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.date-default-timezone-set.php&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/4.1/en/time-zone-support.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="13959" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="11363" RevisionGUID="b9715d2e-cec5-4b02-864c-b4a12e07fb23" CreationDate="2008-08-14T17:19:28.183" UserDisplayName="user316" Text="Ah, if only C supported closures...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Antonio is right; if you need to pass extra parameters, you'll need to redefine your function pointer to accept the additional arguments. If you don't know exactly what parameters you'll need, then you have at least three choices:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. Have the last argument in your prototype be a void*. This gives you flexibility of passing in anything else that you need, but it definitely isn't type-safe.&#xD;&#xA; 2. Use variadic parameters (...). Given my lack of experience with variadic parameters in C, I'm not sure if you can use this with a function pointer, but this gives even more flexibility than the first solution, albeit still with the lack of type safety.&#xD;&#xA; 3. Upgrade to C++ and use [function objects](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_object)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="13964" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="11370" RevisionGUID="beb0b5d3-62d9-42d8-a02b-58fcdadcf8c0" CreationDate="2008-08-14T17:22:27.943" UserId="312" Text="If you are trying to use xslt you can add the namespace in to the stylesheet delcaration.  If you do that, you must make sure that there is a prefix or it will not work.  If the source XML does not have a prefix, that is still fine, you add your own prefix in the stylesheet.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;_Stylesheet_&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;xsl:stylesheet&#xD;&#xA;        xmlns:fb=&quot;uri&quot;&#xD;&#xA;        xmlns:xsl=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform&quot; version=&quot;1.0&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;xsl:template match=&quot;fb:foo/bar&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;            &lt;!--  do stuff here --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/xsl:template&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/xsl:stylsheet&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Or something like that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="13971" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="11379" RevisionGUID="3f55e203-5444-464b-a375-a0dd051fbf79" CreationDate="2008-08-14T17:24:57.423" UserId="1179" Text="If I'm reading this right, what I'd suggest is to make your function take a pointer to a struct as an argument. Then, your struct can have can have &quot;game&quot; and &quot;depth&quot; when it needs them, and just leave them set to 0 or Null when you don't need them. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What is going on in that function? Do you have a conditional that says, &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    if (depth &gt; -1) //some default&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;      //do something&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Does the function always REQUIRE &quot;game&quot; and &quot;depth&quot;. Then, they should always be arguments, and that can go into your prototypes. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are you indicating the function only sometimes requires &quot;game&quot; and &quot;depth&quot;? Well, maybe make two functions and use each one when you need to. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But, having a structure as the argument is probably the easiest thing." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Let's see your implementations (in your language of choice, of course) of a function which returns a human readable String representation of a specified Integer. For example:&#xD;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;humanReadable(1) returns &quot;one&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;humanReadable(53) returns &quot;fifty-three&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;humanReadable(723603) returns &quot;seven hundred and twenty-three thousand, six hundred and three&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;humanReadable(1456376562) returns &quot;one billion, four hundred and fifty-six million, three hundred and seventy-six thousand, five hundred and sixty-two&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Bonus points for particularly clever/elegant solutions!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It might seem like a pointless exercise, but there are number of real world applications for this kind of algorithm (although supporting numbers as high as a billion may be overkill :-)&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="43228" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="16749" RevisionGUID="ac167a73-32d9-46d1-892f-6adbf6e7e1ca" CreationDate="2008-08-19T19:03:26.540" UserId="999" Text="Note that Zend Optimizer and MMCache (or similar applications) are totally different things. While Zend Optimizer tries to optimize the program opcode MMCache will cache the scripts in memory and reuse the precompiled code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I did some benchmarks some time ago and you can find the [results][1] in my blog (in German though). The basic results:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Zend Optimizer alone didn't help at all. Actually my scripts were slower than without optimizer.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When it comes to caches:&#xD;&#xA;* fastest: [eAccelerator][2]&#xD;&#xA;* [XCache][3]&#xD;&#xA;* [APC][4]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And: You DO want to install a opcode cache!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example:&#xD;&#xA;![alt text][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is the duration it took to call the wordpress homepage 10.000 times.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.interdose.com/dominik/2008/04/11/benchmarking-php-eaccelerator-und-andere-opcode-caches/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://eaccelerator.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://xcache.lighttpd.net/&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://www.php.net/manual/en/book.apc.php&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://blogs.interdose.com/dominik/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/opcode_wordpress.png" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="10210" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8338" RevisionGUID="70154086-7c34-46d7-b492-b96b422194f8" CreationDate="2008-08-11T23:34:10.243" UserId="527" Text="The right thing to is to access the database via an abstraction layer in a way such if you change your RDBMS or how you implemented that access, you only have to modify this layer while all the rest of your application remains untouched. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To do this, to free your application from knowing how to deal with the database, your abstraction layer for DB access must be implemented by a framework such as &lt;a href=&quot;http://adodb.sourceforge.net/&quot;&gt;ADODB&lt;/a&gt;. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All the files related to this layer must be located in a sub directory:&#xD;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;/ado&lt;/li&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xD;&#xA;In this directories you'll put all of your .php.inc files which contains general methods to access the database." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="10218" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8344" RevisionGUID="e0a7d313-1ad6-41e8-8b1e-69a4d95a1c74" CreationDate="2008-08-11T23:44:20.423" UserId="1060" Text="There probably isn't a definitive &quot;right&quot; answer - it's going to depend on how you like to develop.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, it's interesting to note that most of the &quot;name&quot; Rails folk seem to use Textmate on their Macs. So a fairly powerful editor rather than an IDE. I suspect this is at least in part because of the fairly strong TDD bias within the Rails community - not so much debugging being necessary because they're working in small test-driven steps. That's the theory anyway.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The closest analog to Textmate in Windows seems to be **e**. It costs, but a fairly trivial amount (pocket-money, if we're honest). There's a 30-day free evaluation available too.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've used Scite for much of my Ruby/Rails work, don't discard it just because it's the &quot;default&quot; - there's a reason why it was chosen for inclusion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for IDEs, I couldn't get anything to work in Eclipse, NetBeans seems quite good and I tried the beta of Sapphire in Steel, also pretty slick. I just don't seem to want to work in an IDE; the opposite of how I feel about working in C#, strangely enough." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="10221" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8349" RevisionGUID="1dfd449e-8b1e-4ca9-a1a2-52682ee2c3bb" CreationDate="2008-08-11T23:52:03.793" UserId="791" Text="I've been arounda while, so most books that I have found influential don't necessarily apply today.  I do believe it is universally important to understand the platform that you are developing for (both hardware and OS).  I also think it's important to learn from other peoples mistakes.  So two books I would recommend are:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Computing Calamities][1] and [In Search of Stupidity: Over Twenty Years of High Tech Marketing Disasters][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/Computing-Calamities-Products-Projects-Companies/dp/0130828629/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1218498682&amp;sr=8-1&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.amazon.com/Search-Stupidity-Twenty-Marketing-Disasters/dp/1590597214/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1218498576&amp;sr=1-1" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="27434" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="21642" RevisionGUID="88f0a97d-b616-4869-9800-1330836f6f5d" CreationDate="2008-08-22T02:19:44.120" UserId="2406" Text="To do arithmetic with dates on UNIX you get the date as the number seconds since the UNIX epoch, do some calculation, then convert back to your printable date format. The date command should be able to both give you the seconds since the epoch and convert from that number back to a printable date. My local date command does this,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    % date -n&#xD;&#xA;    1219371462&#xD;&#xA;    % date 1219371462&#xD;&#xA;    Thu Aug 21 22:17:42 EDT 2008&#xD;&#xA;    % &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See your local date(1) man page.&#xD;&#xA;To increment a day add 86400 seconds.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="27436" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="21644" RevisionGUID="7a263e56-39a3-44cf-839e-d51623e9dccf" CreationDate="2008-08-22T02:19:51.827" UserId="956" Text="I think you should benchmark and take a look at what you are doing to determine if stat() is the slowest part of your code. Stating 1 file on each request on a server that gets about 100 hits/day is not a problem. Stating every file could be a problem when you have to eek out a few more requests a second.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can avoid stating the same file repeatedly by caching the results via memcached, apc or some other in-memory caching system.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Premature optimization is the root of all evil. - Donald Knuth" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="17589" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="13678" RevisionGUID="85f2960a-17ee-4a99-9c3d-506f3510dafa" CreationDate="2008-08-17T15:39:57.560" UserId="1615" Text="|graphicallanguage|labview|robotics|highschool|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="17590" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="13678" RevisionGUID="85f2960a-17ee-4a99-9c3d-506f3510dafa" CreationDate="2008-08-17T15:39:57.560" UserId="1615" Text="I am part of a high school robotics team, and there is some debate about which language to use to program our robot.  We are choosing between C (or maybe C++) and LabVIEW.  There are pros for each language.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;C(++):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Widely used&#xD;&#xA;  - Good preparation for the future (most programming positions require text-based programmers.)&#xD;&#xA;  - We can expand upon our C codebase from last year&#xD;&#xA;  - Allows us to better understand what our robot is doing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;LabVIEW&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Easier to visualize program flow (blocks and wires, instead of lines of code)&#xD;&#xA;  - Easier to teach (Supposedly...)&#xD;&#xA;  - &quot;The future of programming is graphical.&quot;  (Think so?)&#xD;&#xA;  - Closer to the Robolab background that some new members may have.&#xD;&#xA;  - Don't need to intimately know what's going on.  Simply tell the module to find the red ball, don't need to know how.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is a very difficult decision for us, and we've been debating for a while.  Based on those pros for each language, and on the experience you've got, **what do you think the better option is?** Keep in mind that we aren't necessarily going for pure efficiency.  We also hope to prepare our programmers for a future in programming.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - **Do you think that graphical languages such as LabVEIW are the future of programming?**&#xD;&#xA;  - **Is a graphical language easier to learn than a textual language?**  I think that they should be about equally challenging to learn.&#xD;&#xA;  -  Seeing as we are partailly rooted in helping people learn, **how much should we rely on prewritten modules, and how much should we try to write on our own?**  (&quot;Good programmers write good code, great programmers copy great code.&quot;  But isn't it worth being a good programmer, first?)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thanks for the advice!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="25520" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="20238" RevisionGUID="f00ed3c7-8b88-4bab-a482-f657ce73cb1d" CreationDate="2008-08-21T15:28:27.090" UserId="1297" Text="Rebuild the setup file, check the exact file size.&#xD;&#xA;Check the exact file size of the &quot;suspected&quot; setup file.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the source code hasn't changed and the two file sizes are different, there's a pretty good chance it got contaminated in transit.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd do that as a bit of a sanity check first." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25529" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="20249" RevisionGUID="8f3ecdb7-c4f2-4223-a4d4-6ad3327b199e" CreationDate="2008-08-21T15:31:45.007" UserId="1907" Text="ILMerge and Web Resources" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25530" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="20249" RevisionGUID="8f3ecdb7-c4f2-4223-a4d4-6ad3327b199e" CreationDate="2008-08-21T15:31:45.007" UserId="1907" Text="|c#|asp.net|ilmerge|webresource|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25531" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="20249" RevisionGUID="8f3ecdb7-c4f2-4223-a4d4-6ad3327b199e" CreationDate="2008-08-21T15:31:45.007" UserId="1907" Text="We're attemtping to merge our DLL's into one for deployment, thus ILMerge.  Almost everything seems to work great.  We have a couple web controls that use `ClientScript.RegisterClientScriptResource` and these are 404-ing after the merge (These worked before the merge).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example one of our controls would look like&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    namespace Company.WebControls&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;      public class ControlA: CompositeControl, INamingContainer&#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnPreRender(EventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnPreRender(e);&#xD;&#xA;            this.Page.ClientScript.RegisterClientScriptResource(typeof(ControlA), &quot;Company.WebControls.ControlA.js&quot;);                &#xD;&#xA;        }      &#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It would be located in Project WebControls, assembly Company.WebControls.  Underneath would be ControlA.cs and ControlA.js.  ControlA.js is marked as an embedded resource.  In the AssemblyInfo.cs I include the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [assembly: System.Web.UI.WebResource(&quot;Company.WebControls.ControlA.js&quot;, &quot;application/x-javascript&quot;)]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;After this is merged into CompanyA.dll, what is the proper way to reference this web resource?  The ILMerge command line is as follows (from the bin directory after the build): `&quot;C:\Program Files\Microsoft\ILMerge\ILMerge.exe&quot; /keyfile:../../CompanySK.snk /wildcards:True /copyattrs:True /out:Company.dll Company.*.dll` &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thanks in advance!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25533" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="19326" RevisionGUID="4c2b9228-5307-427c-ba22-9d1e8773e0f1" CreationDate="2008-08-21T04:17:57.887" UserId="1117" Text="You could use the Mutex class, but you will soon find out that you will need to implement the code to pass the arguments and such yourself.  Well, I learned a trick when programming in WinForms when I read Chris Sell's book.  This trick uses logic that is already available to us in the framework.  I don't know about you, but when I learn about stuff I can reuse in the framework, that is usually the route I take instead of reinventing the wheel.  Unless of course it doesn't do everything I want.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I got into WPF, I came up with a way to use that same code, but in a WPF application.  This solution should meet your needs based off your question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, we need to create our application class.  In this class we are going override the OnStartup event and create a method called Activate, which will be used later.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceApplication : System.Windows.Application&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartup(System.Windows.StartupEventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Call the OnStartup event on our base class&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartup(e);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            // Create our MainWindow and show it&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow window = new MainWindow();&#xD;&#xA;            window.Show();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        public void Activate()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Reactivate the main window&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, we will need to create a class that can manage our instances.  Before we go through that, we are actually going to reuse some code that is in the Microsoft.VisualBasic assembly.  Since, I am using C# in this example, I had to make a reference to the assembly.  If you are using VB.NET, you don't have to do anything.  The class we are going to use is WindowsFormsApplicationBase and inherit our instance manager off of it and then leverage properties and events to handle the single instancing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceManager : Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.WindowsFormsApplicationBase&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        private SingleInstanceApplication _application;&#xD;&#xA;        private System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection&lt;string&gt; _commandLine;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public SingleInstanceManager()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            IsSingleInstance = true;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override bool OnStartup(Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.StartupEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // First time _application is launched&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application = new SingleInstanceApplication();&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Run();&#xD;&#xA;            return false;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartupNextInstance(StartupNextInstanceEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Subsequent launches&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartupNextInstance(eventArgs);&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, we are using the VB bits to detect single instance's and process accordingly.  OnStartup will be fired when the first instance loads.  OnStartupNextInstance is fired when the application is re-run again.  As you can see, I can get to what was passed on the command line through the event arguments.  I set the value to an instance field.  You could parse the command line here, or you could pass it to your application through the constructor and the call to the Activate method.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Third, it's time to create our EntryPoint.  Instead of newing up the application like you would normally do, we are going to take advantage of our SingleInstanceManager.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class EntryPoint&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        [STAThread]&#xD;&#xA;        public static void Main(string[] args)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            SingleInstanceManager manager = new SingleInstanceManager();&#xD;&#xA;            manager.Run(args);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Well, I hope you are able to follow everything and be able take this implementation and make it your own.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25534" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="19326" RevisionGUID="cacd42dc-193e-47e1-9df7-ab568eb71cb2" CreationDate="2008-08-21T12:19:22.643" UserId="1117" Comment="Fixed a typo." Text="You could use the Mutex class, but you will soon find out that you will need to implement the code to pass the arguments and such yourself.  Well, I learned a trick when programming in WinForms when I read Chris Sell's book.  This trick uses logic that is already available to us in the framework.  I don't know about you, but when I learn about stuff I can reuse in the framework, that is usually the route I take instead of reinventing the wheel.  Unless of course it doesn't do everything I want.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I got into WPF, I came up with a way to use that same code, but in a WPF application.  This solution should meet your needs based off your question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, we need to create our application class.  In this class we are going override the OnStartup event and create a method called Activate, which will be used later.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceApplication : System.Windows.Application&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartup(System.Windows.StartupEventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Call the OnStartup event on our base class&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartup(e);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            // Create our MainWindow and show it&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow window = new MainWindow();&#xD;&#xA;            window.Show();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        public void Activate()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Reactivate the main window&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, we will need to create a class that can manage our instances.  Before we go through that, we are actually going to reuse some code that is in the Microsoft.VisualBasic assembly.  Since, I am using C# in this example, I had to make a reference to the assembly.  If you are using VB.NET, you don't have to do anything.  The class we are going to use is WindowsFormsApplicationBase and inherit our instance manager off of it and then leverage properties and events to handle the single instancing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceManager : Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.WindowsFormsApplicationBase&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        private SingleInstanceApplication _application;&#xD;&#xA;        private System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection&lt;string&gt; _commandLine;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public SingleInstanceManager()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            IsSingleInstance = true;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override bool OnStartup(Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.StartupEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // First time _application is launched&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application = new SingleInstanceApplication();&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Run();&#xD;&#xA;            return false;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartupNextInstance(StartupNextInstanceEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Subsequent launches&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartupNextInstance(eventArgs);&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, we are using the VB bits to detect single instance's and process accordingly.  OnStartup will be fired when the first instance loads.  OnStartupNextInstance is fired when the application is re-run again.  As you can see, I can get to what was passed on the command line through the event arguments.  I set the value to an instance field.  You could parse the command line here, or you could pass it to your application through the constructor and the call to the Activate method.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Third, it's time to create our EntryPoint.  Instead of newing up the application like you would normally do, we are going to take advantage of our SingleInstanceManager.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class EntryPoint&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        [STAThread]&#xD;&#xA;        public static void Main(string[] args)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            SingleInstanceManager manager = new SingleInstanceManager();&#xD;&#xA;            manager.Run(args);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Well, I hope you are able to follow everything and be able use this implementation and make it your own.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="25535" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="19326" RevisionGUID="ecbf50e6-d4f2-4980-8684-ce18248e1f90" CreationDate="2008-08-21T15:32:05.410" UserId="1117" Comment="Added reference to Chris's book." Text="You could use the Mutex class, but you will soon find out that you will need to implement the code to pass the arguments and such yourself.  Well, I learned a trick when programming in WinForms when I read [Chris Sell's book][1].  This trick uses logic that is already available to us in the framework.  I don't know about you, but when I learn about stuff I can reuse in the framework, that is usually the route I take instead of reinventing the wheel.  Unless of course it doesn't do everything I want.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I got into WPF, I came up with a way to use that same code, but in a WPF application.  This solution should meet your needs based off your question.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, we need to create our application class.  In this class we are going override the OnStartup event and create a method called Activate, which will be used later.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceApplication : System.Windows.Application&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartup(System.Windows.StartupEventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Call the OnStartup event on our base class&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartup(e);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            // Create our MainWindow and show it&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow window = new MainWindow();&#xD;&#xA;            window.Show();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        public void Activate()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Reactivate the main window&#xD;&#xA;            MainWindow.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Second, we will need to create a class that can manage our instances.  Before we go through that, we are actually going to reuse some code that is in the Microsoft.VisualBasic assembly.  Since, I am using C# in this example, I had to make a reference to the assembly.  If you are using VB.NET, you don't have to do anything.  The class we are going to use is WindowsFormsApplicationBase and inherit our instance manager off of it and then leverage properties and events to handle the single instancing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class SingleInstanceManager : Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.WindowsFormsApplicationBase&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        private SingleInstanceApplication _application;&#xD;&#xA;        private System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection&lt;string&gt; _commandLine;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        public SingleInstanceManager()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            IsSingleInstance = true;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override bool OnStartup(Microsoft.VisualBasic.ApplicationServices.StartupEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // First time _application is launched&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application = new SingleInstanceApplication();&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Run();&#xD;&#xA;            return false;&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected override void OnStartupNextInstance(StartupNextInstanceEventArgs eventArgs)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Subsequent launches&#xD;&#xA;            base.OnStartupNextInstance(eventArgs);&#xD;&#xA;            _commandLine = eventArgs.CommandLine;&#xD;&#xA;            _application.Activate();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, we are using the VB bits to detect single instance's and process accordingly.  OnStartup will be fired when the first instance loads.  OnStartupNextInstance is fired when the application is re-run again.  As you can see, I can get to what was passed on the command line through the event arguments.  I set the value to an instance field.  You could parse the command line here, or you could pass it to your application through the constructor and the call to the Activate method.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Third, it's time to create our EntryPoint.  Instead of newing up the application like you would normally do, we are going to take advantage of our SingleInstanceManager.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class EntryPoint&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        [STAThread]&#xD;&#xA;        public static void Main(string[] args)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            SingleInstanceManager manager = new SingleInstanceManager();&#xD;&#xA;            manager.Run(args);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Well, I hope you are able to follow everything and be able use this implementation and make it your own.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.sellsbrothers.com/writing/wfbook/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

AKA ^J or ctrl-j&#xD;&#xA;                '13 -&gt; Enter.      AKA ^M or ctrl-m&#xD;&#xA;            KeyAscii = 0  'clear the the KeyPress&#xD;&#xA;        End If&#xD;&#xA;    End Sub" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="35457" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="769" RevisionGUID="922d4774-e4d6-4280-8dce-708cc49702cd" CreationDate="2008-08-25T18:06:09.627" UserId="123" Comment="edited tags" Text="|math|system|linear-equation|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35458" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="26468" RevisionGUID="f6a33901-106f-40c4-8435-3cebf675f08e" CreationDate="2008-08-25T17:32:23.343" UserId="1143" Text="Have you tried calling .SaveOrUpdateCopy()? &#xD;&#xA;Failing that, you may have to identify and .Evict() the existing object before Attaching (.Update()) your &quot;new&quot; object." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35459" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="26468" RevisionGUID="a6fb5d29-92b4-44dc-aa0d-d93480bbc38e" CreationDate="2008-08-25T18:06:19.640" UserId="1143" Comment="added 626 characters in body" Text="Have you tried calling .SaveOrUpdateCopy()? &#xD;&#xA;It should work in all instances, if there is an entity by the same id in the session or if there is no entity at all. This is basically the catch-all method, as it converts a transient object into a persistent one (Save), updates the object if it is existing (Update) or even handles if the entity is a copy of an already existing object (Copy).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Failing that, you may have to identify and .Evict() the existing object before Attaching (.Update()) your &quot;new&quot; object.&#xD;&#xA;This should be easy enough to do:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    IPersistable entity = Whatever(); // This is the object we're trying to update&#xD;&#xA;    // (IPersistable has an id field)&#xD;&#xA;    session.Evict(session.Get(entity.GetType(), entity.Id));&#xD;&#xA;    session.SaveOrUpdate(entity);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although the above code could probably do with some null checking for the .Get() call." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35460" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="26512" RevisionGUID="7ca21499-bac5-49b3-a5a0-1634461e828b" CreationDate="2008-08-25T17:56:40.537" UserId="1638" Text="Can I add an event listener to a databinding action in Flex?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35461" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="26512" RevisionGUID="7ca21499-bac5-49b3-a5a0-1634461e828b" CreationDate="2008-08-25T17:56:40.537" UserId="1638" Text="|apache-flex|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35462" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="26512" RevisionGUID="7ca21499-bac5-49b3-a5a0-1634461e828b" CreationDate="2008-08-25T17:56:40.537" UserId="1638" Text="I have a ComboBox that I bind to a standard HTTPService, I would like to add an event listener so that I can run some code after the ComboBox is populated from the data provider.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How can I do this?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35463" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="26512" RevisionGUID="15b0f00b-18ad-4645-904f-eed033c068b4" CreationDate="2008-08-25T18:06:58.017" UserId="35" Comment="edited tags" Text="|apache-flex|data-binding|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35464" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="26383" RevisionGUID="8305addf-f726-4fd2-a6a3-ac64aa18cf6c" CreationDate="2008-08-25T16:52:23.110" UserDisplayName="user1144" Text="Exception handling: Contract vs Exceptional approach" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35465" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="26383" RevisionGUID="8305addf-f726-4fd2-a6a3-ac64aa18cf6c" CreationDate="2008-08-25T16:52:23.110" UserDisplayName="user1144" Text="|exception|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="35466" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="26383" RevisionGUID="8305addf-f726-4fd2-a6a3-ac64aa18cf6c" CreationDate="2008-08-25T16:52:23.110" UserDisplayName="user1144" Text="I know two approaches to Exception handling, lets have a look at them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. Contract approach.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When a method does not do what it says it will do in the method header, it will throw an exception. Thus the method &quot;promises&quot; that it will do the operation, and if it fails for some reason, it will throw an exception.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Exceptional approach.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Only throw exceptions when something truly weird happens. You should not use exceptions when you can resolve the situation with normal control flow (If statements). You don't use Exceptions for control flow, as you might in the contract approach.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Lets use both approaches in different cases:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have a Customer class that has a method called OrderProduct.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;contract approach:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    class Customer&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;         public void OrderProduct(Product product)&#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;               if((m_credit - product.Price) &lt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;                      throw new NoCreditException(&quot;Not enough credit!&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;               // do stuff &#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;exceptional approach:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    class Customer&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;         public bool OrderProduct(Product product)&#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;              if((m&amp;#95;credit - product.Price) &lt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;                       return false;&#xD;&#xA;              // do stuff&#xD;&#xA;              return true;&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    if !(customer.OrderProduct(product))&#xD;&#xA;                Console.WriteLine(&quot;Not enough credit!&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    else&#xD;&#xA;       // go on with your life&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here I prefer the exceptional approach, as it is not truly Exceptional that a customer has no money assuming he did not win the lottery.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;But here is a situation I err on the contract style.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Exceptional:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    class CarController&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;         // returns null if car creation failed.&#xD;&#xA;         public Car CreateCar(string model)&#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;             // something went wrong, wrong model&#xD;&#xA;             return null;&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;     }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I call a method called CreateCar, I damn wel expect a Car instance and some lousy null pointer, which can ravage my running code a dozen lines later. Thus I prefer contract to this one:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    class CarController&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;         &#xD;&#xA;         public Car CreateCar(string model)&#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;             // something went wrong, wrong model&#xD;&#xA;             throw new CarModelNotKnownException(&quot;Model unkown&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;             return new Car();&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;     }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Which do style do you use? What do you think is best general approach to Exceptions?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="50975" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="36885" RevisionGUID="21d564fb-1ff9-44a4-bd57-92b4e8543c2c" CreationDate="2008-08-31T14:49:29.067" UserId="1820" Comment="added 5 characters in body" Text="When setting cookies manually, use the following parameter syntax to the [header()][1] function:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    header( &quot;Set-Cookie: name=value; httpOnly&quot; );&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you have PHP **5.2.0** or greater, then you can use the [setcookie()][2] and [setrawcookie()][3] functions. Simply set the 7th parameter to true, as per the syntax&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    bool setcookie( $name, $value, $expire, $path, $domain, $secure, $httponly )&#xD;&#xA;    bool setrawcookie( $name, $value, $expire, $path, $domain, $secure, $httponly )&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(function syntax simplified for brevity). Enter NULL for parameters you wish to remain as default.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please note that versions of PHP before 5.2.0 do have the setcookie functions, but the httpOnly parameter was not yet introduced.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://uk.php.net/manual/en/function.header.php&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://uk.php.net/setcookie&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://uk.php.net/manual/en/function.setrawcookie.php" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="50976" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="36885" RevisionGUID="9732b9b8-8daf-4480-a3fb-db1e05dc74d4" CreationDate="2008-08-31T15:24:43.070" UserId="1820" Comment="added 3 characters in body" Text="When setting cookies manually, use the following parameter syntax to the [header()][1] function:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    header( &quot;Set-Cookie: name=value; httpOnly&quot; );&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you have PHP **5.2.0** or greater, then you can use the [setcookie()][2] and [setrawcookie()][3] functions. Simply set the 7th parameter to true, as per the syntax&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    setcookie(    $name, $value, $expire, $path, $domain, $secure, $httponly )&#xD;&#xA;    setrawcookie( $name, $value, $expire, $path, $domain, $secure, $httponly )&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(function syntax simplified for brevity). Enter NULL for parameters you wish to remain as default.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please note that versions of PHP before 5.2.0 do have the setcookie functions, but the httpOnly parameter was not yet introduced.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://uk.php.net/manual/en/function.header.php&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://uk.php.net/setcookie&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://uk.php.net/manual/en/function.setrawcookie.php" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="50978" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="36914" RevisionGUID="8def8897-03d5-470c-882c-b5ab63ec5d60" CreationDate="2008-08-31T15:28:15.027" UserId="1124" Text="I agree with Pat. At this point in the game, writing your own code to deal with cross-browser compatibility given the available Javascript frameworks doesn't make a lot of sense. There's a framework for nearly any taste (some really quite tiny) and they've focused on really abstracting out all of the differences between the browsers. They're doing WAY more testing of it than you're likely to.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Something like jQuery or Yahoo's YUI (think how many people hit the Yahoo Javascript in a day and the variety of browsers) is just way more road-tested than any snippet you or I come up with."   <row Id="8471" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="6978" RevisionGUID="73e887fb-e56d-414d-9ac9-0c14659f4118" CreationDate="2008-08-10T01:03:49.720" UserId="483" Text="As others have stated, the best performance comes from the bottom one since you are just rethrowing an existing object. The middle one is least correct because it looses the stack.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I personally use custom exceptions if I want to decouple certain dependencies in code. For example, I have a method that loads data from an XML file. This can go wrong in many different ways.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It could fail to read from the disk (FileIOException), the user could try to access it from somewhere where they are not allowed (SecurityException), the file could be corrupt (XmlParseException), data could be in the wrong format (DeserialisationException).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this case, so its easier for the calling class to make sense of all this, all these exceptions rethrow a single custom exception (FileOperationException) so that means the caller does not need references to System.IO or System.Xml, but can still access what error occurred through an enum and any important information.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As stated, don't try to micro-optimize something like this, the act of throwing an exception at all is the slowest thing that occurs here. The best improvement to make is to try avoiding an exception at all.&#xD;&#xA;&lt;code&gt;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    public bool Load(filepath)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        if (File.Exists(filepath)) //Avoid throwing by checking state&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            //Wrap anyways in case something changes between check and operation&#xD;&#xA;            try { .... }&#xD;&#xA;            catch (IOException ioFault) { .... }&#xD;&#xA;            catch (OtherException otherFault) { .... }&#xD;&#xA;            return true; //Inform caller of success&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        else { return false; } //Inform caller of failure due to state&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/code&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="8472" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="6978" RevisionGUID="13fd245d-cdcf-4f51-b8ca-7514837923d6" CreationDate="2008-08-10T01:07:12.257" UserId="483" Comment="" Text="As others have stated, the best performance comes from the bottom one since you are just rethrowing an existing object. The middle one is least correct because it looses the stack.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I personally use custom exceptions if I want to decouple certain dependencies in code. For example, I have a method that loads data from an XML file. This can go wrong in many different ways.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It could fail to read from the disk (FileIOException), the user could try to access it from somewhere where they are not allowed (SecurityException), the file could be corrupt (XmlParseException), data could be in the wrong format (DeserialisationException).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this case, so its easier for the calling class to make sense of all this, all these exceptions rethrow a single custom exception (FileOperationException) so that means the caller does not need references to System.IO or System.Xml, but can still access what error occurred through an enum and any important information.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As stated, don't try to micro-optimize something like this, the act of throwing an exception at all is the slowest thing that occurs here. The best improvement to make is to try avoiding an exception at all.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;public bool Load(string filepath)&#xD;&#xA;{&#xD;&#xA;  if (File.Exists(filepath)) //Avoid throwing by checking state&#xD;&#xA;  {&#xD;&#xA;    //Wrap anyways in case something changes between check and operation&#xD;&#xA;    try { .... }&#xD;&#xA;    catch (IOException ioFault) { .... }&#xD;&#xA;    catch (OtherException otherFault) { .... }&#xD;&#xA;    return true; //Inform caller of success&#xD;&#xA;  }&#xD;&#xA;  else { return false; } //Inform caller of failure due to state&#xD;&#xA;}&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="52839" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="38137" RevisionGUID="bd57ffe7-1754-4924-982d-f61b9620da9b" CreationDate="2008-09-01T16:43:01.843" UserId="3191" Comment="Adding actual solution" Text="You could use the excellent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.codeplex.com/umbrella&quot;&gt;Umbrella library&lt;/a&gt;:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    using nVentive.Umbrella.Extensions.Calendar;&#xD;&#xA;    DateTime beginning = DateTime.Now.BeginningOfWeek();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, they *do* seem to have stored Monday as the first day of the week (see the property `nVentive.Umbrella.Extensions.Calendar.DefaultDateTimeCalendarExtensions.WeekBeginsOn`), so that previous localized solution is a bit better. Unfortunate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit**: looking closer at the question, it looks like Umbrella might actually work for that too:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    // Or DateTime.Now.PreviousDay(DayOfWeek.Monday)&#xD;&#xA;    DateTime monday = DateTime.Now.PreviousMonday(); &#xD;&#xA;    DateTime sunday = DateTime.Now.PreviousSunday();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Although it's worth noting that if you ask for the previous Monday on a Monday, it'll give you seven days back.   <row Id="52849" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="38160" RevisionGUID="d9b03527-6fda-408c-a12e-29414bcbbaa6" CreationDate="2008-09-01T16:47:53.377" UserId="163" Text="Lets say I have a loop in bash:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    for foo in `some-command`&#xD;&#xA;    do&#xD;&#xA;       do-something $foo&#xD;&#xA;    done&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`do-something` is cpu bound and I have a nice shiny 4 core processor. I'd like to be able to run up to 4 `do-something`'s at once.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The naive approach seems to be:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    for foo in `some-command`&#xD;&#xA;    do&#xD;&#xA;       do-something $foo &amp;&#xD;&#xA;    done&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This will run *all* `do-something`s at once, but there are a couple downsides, mainly that do-something may also have some significant I/O which performing *all* at once might slow down a bit. The other problem is that this code block returns immediately, so no way to do other work when all the `do-something`s are finished.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How would you write this loop so there are always X `do-something`s running at once?"   <row Id="52853" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="38164" RevisionGUID="d8b2554b-941c-4b93-864d-0a6a9c1e0f18" CreationDate="2008-09-01T16:49:39.053" UserId="1147" Text="Why not just do all the work in C# instead of using batch files?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I was bored so i wrote this real quick, it's just an outline of how I would do it since I don't know what the command line switches do or the file paths.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    using System;&#xD;&#xA;    using System.IO;&#xD;&#xA;    using System.Text;&#xD;&#xA;    using System.Security;&#xD;&#xA;    using System.Diagnostics;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    namespace asdf&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        class StackoverflowQuestion&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            private const string MSBUILD = @&quot;path\to\msbuild.exe&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;            private const string BMAIL = @&quot;path\to\bmail.exe&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;            private const string WORKING_DIR = @&quot;path\to\working_directory&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            private string stdout;&#xD;&#xA;            private Process p;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            public void DoWork()&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                // build project&#xD;&#xA;                StartProcess(MSBUILD, &quot;myproject.csproj /t:Build&quot;, true);&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            public void StartProcess(string file, string args, bool redirectStdout)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                SecureString password = new SecureString();&#xD;&#xA;                foreach (char c in &quot;mypassword&quot;.ToCharArray())&#xD;&#xA;                    password.AppendChar(c);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;                ProcessStartInfo psi = new ProcessStartInfo();&#xD;&#xA;                p = new Process();&#xD;&#xA;                psi.WindowStyle = ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.WorkingDirectory = WORKING_DIR;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.FileName = file;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.UseShellExecute = false;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.RedirectStandardOutput = redirectStdout;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.UserName = &quot;builder&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;                psi.Password = password;&#xD;&#xA;                p.StartInfo = psi;&#xD;&#xA;                p.EnableRaisingEvents = true;&#xD;&#xA;                p.Exited += new EventHandler(p_Exited);&#xD;&#xA;                p.Start();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;                if (redirectStdout)&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                    stdout = p.StandardOutput.ReadToEnd();&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            void p_Exited(object sender, EventArgs e)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;                if (p.ExitCode != 0)&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                    // failed&#xD;&#xA;                    StringBuilder args = new StringBuilder();&#xD;&#xA;                    args.Append(&quot;-s k2smtpout.secureserver.net &quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                    args.Append(&quot;-f build@example.com &quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                    args.Append(&quot;-t josh@example.com &quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                    args.Append(&quot;-a \&quot;Build failed.\&quot; &quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                    args.AppendFormat(&quot;-m {0} -h&quot;, stdout);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;                    // send email&#xD;&#xA;                    StartProcess(BMAIL, args.ToString(), false);&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="33471" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="25317" RevisionGUID="4f5308b9-261b-4c24-aa83-aea576b0b5e0" CreationDate="2008-08-24T20:23:17.590" UserId="1117" Comment="Added link to MvcContrib." Text="I have made the switch, since you pointed out it will be the preferred way for microsoft shops.  The switch was pretty trivial and as Mike pointed out it ships with the webform view engine as the default, but like Mike also said you can still take advantage of the views you wrote in brail and nvelocity with the [MvcContrib][1] project.  ASP.NET MVC, doesn't tie you to a direct ViewEngine, you can use any ViewEngine you want.  I don't necessarily think this is a difference.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The biggest difference I found was grouping my controllers and views.  In MonoRail you could do this easily with the ControllerDetails attribute,  I was able to easily get around this limitation by coding my own, but wish the functionality was built in.  I did it by creating my own ViewLocator and creating a ActionFilterAttribute.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.mvccontrib.org" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="33474" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="25322" RevisionGUID="31d52fd5-996f-4106-b39e-0578ef49e0f4" CreationDate="2008-08-24T20:32:26.723" UserId="2687" Text="Read the code of other (good) javascript apps and see how they handle things.  But I start out with a file per class.  But once its ready for production, I would combine the files into one large file and minify.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only reason, I would not combine the files, is if I didn't need all the files on all the pages."   <row Id="33475" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="25324" RevisionGUID="e7749d54-b675-4efb-bcbe-9a9eea20de92" CreationDate="2008-08-24T20:35:12.520" UserId="101" Text="Boxed values are [data structures](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_structure) that are minimal wrappers around [primitive types](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primitive_type)*.  Boxed values are typically stored as pointers to objects on [the heap](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_memory_allocation).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thus, boxed values use more memory and take at minimum two memory lookups to access: once to get the pointer, and another to follow that pointer to the primitive.  Obviously this isn't the kind of thing you want in your inner loops.  On the other hand, boxed values typically play better with other types in the system.  Since they are first-class data structures in the language, they have the expected metadata and structure that other data structures have.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In Java and Haskell generic collections can't contain unboxed values.  Generic collections in .NET can hold unboxed values with no penalties.  Where Java's generics are only used for compile-time type checking, .NET will [generate specific classes for each generic type instantiated at run time](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/f4a6ta2h.aspx).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Java and Haskell have unboxed arrays, but they're distinctly less convenient than the other collections.  However, when peak performance is needed it's worth a little inconvenience to avoid the overhead of boxing and unboxing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;\* For this discussion, a primitive value is any that can be stored on [the call stack](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_stack), rather than stored as a pointer to a value on the heap.  Frequently that's just the machine types (ints, floats, etc), structs, and sometimes static sized arrays.  .NET-land calls them value types (as opposed to reference types).  Java folks call them primitive types.  Haskellions just call them unboxed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;\** I'm also focusing on Java, Haskell, and C# in this answer, because that's what I know.  For what it's worth, Python, Ruby, and Javascript all have exclusively boxed values.  This is also known as the &quot;Everything is an object&quot; approach." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="33476" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="25325" RevisionGUID="d77f3563-8645-40b7-baca-0bb4544e1b2e" CreationDate="2008-08-24T20:36:19.697" UserId="2741" Text="Quick followup question - can you use the &quot;runas&quot; command from an MSBuild script? If so, wouldn't you be able to simply impersonate another user with runas /user:dsfsdf /password:dfdf sc.exe ... (or similiar - I haven't researched the command-line options)?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="15803" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="12863" RevisionGUID="46ec38ee-9777-4a50-be39-faa6ea95fc74" CreationDate="2008-08-15T23:00:44.410" UserId="646" Text="The best answer I have ever heard about using the provided type aliases in C# comes from Jeffrey Richter in his book [CLR Via C#][1]. Here are his 3 reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - I've seen a number of developers confused, not knowing whether to use **string** or **String** in their code. Because in C# the string (a keyword) maps exactly to System.String (an FCL type), there is no difference and either can be used.&#xD;&#xA;- In C#, **long** maps to **System.Int64**, but in a different programming language, **long** could map to an **Int16** or **Int32**. In fact, C==/CLI does in fact treat long as an **Int32**. Someone reading source code in one language could easily misinterpret the code's intention if he or she were used to programming in a different programming language. In fact, most languages won't even treat **long** as a keyword and won't compile code that uses it.&#xD;&#xA;- The FCL has many methods that have type names as part of their method names. For example, the BinaryReader type offers methods such as ReadBoolean, ReadInt32, ReadSingle, and so on, and the System.Convert type offers methods such as ToBoolean, ToInt32, ToSingle, and so on. Although it's legal to write the following code, the line with float feels very unnatural to me, and it's not obvious that the line is correct:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    BinaryReader br = new BinaryReader(...);&#xD;&#xA;    float val  = br.ReadSingle(); // Ok, but feels unnatural&#xD;&#xA;    Single val = br.ReadSingle(); // OK and feels good&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So there you have it. I think these are all really good points. I however, don't find myself using Jeffrey's advice in my own code. Maybe I am too stuck in my C# world but I end up trying to make my code look like the framework code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/CLR-via-Second-Pro-Developer/dp/0735621632/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1218840666&amp;sr=8-1" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="15804" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="12863" RevisionGUID="73e0a2f9-6f8f-4bcd-836b-dbbe67f0b4b0" CreationDate="2008-08-15T23:12:42.470" UserId="646" Comment="improved formatting" Text="The best answer I have ever heard about using the provided type aliases in C# comes from Jeffrey Richter in his book [CLR Via C#][1]. Here are his 3 reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; - I've seen a number of developers confused, not knowing whether to use **string** or **String** in their code. Because in C# the string (a keyword) maps exactly to System.String (an FCL type), there is no difference and either can be used.&#xD;&#xA;- In C#, **long** maps to **System.Int64**, but in a different programming language, **long** could map to an **Int16** or **Int32**. In fact, C==/CLI does in fact treat long as an **Int32**. Someone reading source code in one language could easily misinterpret the code's intention if he or she were used to programming in a different programming language. In fact, most languages won't even treat **long** as a keyword and won't compile code that uses it.&#xD;&#xA;- The FCL has many methods that have type names as part of their method names. For example, the **BinaryReader** type offers methods such as **ReadBoolean**, **ReadInt32**, **ReadSingle**, and so on, and the **System.Convert** type offers methods such as **ToBoolean**, **ToInt32**, **ToSingle**, and so on. Although it's legal to write the following code, the line with float feels very unnatural to me, and it's not obvious that the line is correct:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    BinaryReader br = new BinaryReader(...);&#xD;&#xA;    float val  = br.ReadSingle(); // Ok, but feels unnatural&#xD;&#xA;    Single val = br.ReadSingle(); // OK and feels good&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So there you have it. I think these are all really good points. I however, don't find myself using Jeffrey's advice in my own code. Maybe I am too stuck in my C# world but I end up trying to make my code look like the framework code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/CLR-via-Second-Pro-Developer/dp/0735621632/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1218840666&amp;sr=8-1" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="21574" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="17068" RevisionGUID="8680c12b-2b78-497e-b9f7-634940976bbf" CreationDate="2008-08-19T22:11:31.707" UserId="77" Text="Best solution is to let IIS do it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[IIS6 Compression](http://www.microsoft.com/technet/prodtechnol/WindowsServer2003/Library/IIS/502ef631-3695-4616-b268-cbe7cf1351ce.mspx?mfr=true) - most likely you need to [specify file types to be compressed](http://www.microsoft.com/technet/prodtechnol/WindowsServer2003/Library/IIS/502ef631-3695-4616-b268-cbe7cf1351ce.mspx?mfr=true) like .jpg, .png, .gif types, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Caching will come from making sure that the correct headers are being sent to the client from code, and i believe there is a setting you can set in IIS that enables it for static content, but i'm not sure on that one." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="31518" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="24436" RevisionGUID="6cc83ea1-e515-4bea-9090-897400eee944" CreationDate="2008-08-23T17:50:40.180" UserId="2620" Text="Similar to the above, but I think the best version is (slightly modified) from &quot;perldoc -f readdir&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    opendir(DIR, $somedir) || die &quot;can't opendir $somedir: $!&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    @dots = grep { (!/^\./) &amp;&amp; -f &quot;$somedir/$_&quot; } readdir(DIR);&#xD;&#xA;    closedir DIR;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="31519" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="24429" RevisionGUID="501b4e16-5c2c-460c-9daf-04dfa5394b78" CreationDate="2008-08-23T17:38:59.397" UserId="1862" Text="You can use a file system watcher to check when the file has been changed.  It only becomes &quot;changed&quot; after whichever program had the file previously closes the file.  I know you asked for C#, but my VB.Net is much better. Hope you or someone else can translate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It tries to open the file, if it isn't available, it adds a watcher, and waits for the file to be changed.  After the file is changed, it tries to open again.  It throws an exception if it waits more than 120 seconds, because you may get caught in a situation where the file is never released.  Also, I decided to add a timeout of waiting for the file change of 5 seconds, in case of the small possibility that the file was closed prior to the actual file watcher being created.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;     Public Sub WriteToFile(ByVal Path As String, ByVal FileName As String, ByVal Data() As Byte)&#xD;&#xA;            Dim FileOpen As Boolean&#xD;&#xA;            Dim File As System.IO.FileStream = Nothing&#xD;&#xA;            Dim StartTime As DateTime&#xD;&#xA;            Dim MaxWaitSeconds As Integer = 120&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            StartTime = DateTime.Now&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            FileOpen = False&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            Do&#xD;&#xA;                Try&#xD;&#xA;                    File = New System.IO.FileStream(FilePath &amp; FileName, IO.FileMode.Append)&#xD;&#xA;                    FileOpen = True&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                Catch ex As Exception&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                    If DateTime.Now.Subtract(StartTime).TotalSeconds &gt; MaxWaitSeconds Then&#xD;&#xA;                        Throw New Exception(&quot;Waited more than &quot; &amp; MaxWaitSeconds &amp; &quot; To Open File.&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;                    Else&#xD;&#xA;                        Dim FileWatch As System.IO.FileSystemWatcher&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                        FileWatch = New System.IO.FileSystemWatcher(FilePath, FileName)&#xD;&#xA;                        FileWatch.WaitForChanged(IO.WatcherChangeTypes.Changed,5000)&#xD;&#xA;                    End If&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                    FileOpen = False&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                End Try&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            Loop While Not FileOpen&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            If FileOpen Then&#xD;&#xA;                File.Write(Data, 0, Data.Length)&#xD;&#xA;                File.Close()&#xD;&#xA;            End If&#xD;&#xA;        End Sub" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="58789" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="42125" RevisionGUID="bdd7f082-626d-4e39-a1b0-444da757eab1" CreationDate="2008-09-03T17:08:18.163" UserId="3807" Text="function declaration isn't a prototype" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="58800" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="42133" RevisionGUID="f2f500a7-7c53-472f-a33d-b3d8c77882d1" CreationDate="2008-09-03T17:11:31.527" UserId="267" Text="Try:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    extern int testlib(void);" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="58804" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="41177" RevisionGUID="dc8bf7cb-6aaa-4ce9-9ec9-82b324ad5cc5" CreationDate="2008-09-03T04:37:02.040" UserId="3434" Text="Math is your friend:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Long.toString;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.round;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.random;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.pow;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.abs;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.min;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public class RandomAlphaNum() {&#xD;&#xA;      public static String gen(int length) {&#xD;&#xA;        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();&#xD;&#xA;        for (int i = length; i &gt; 0; i -= 12)&#xD;&#xA;          sb.append(toString(round(random() * pow(36, min(12, abs(i)))), 36));&#xD;&#xA;        return sb.toString();&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="58805" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="41177" RevisionGUID="b1aecb4e-ef04-4d91-af4e-ca73255ee68e" CreationDate="2008-09-03T04:55:30.250" UserId="3434" Comment="added 118 characters in body" Text="Math is your friend:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.round;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.random;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.pow;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.abs;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.min;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    public class RandomAlphaNum {&#xD;&#xA;      public static String gen(int length) {&#xD;&#xA;        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();&#xD;&#xA;        for (int i = length; i &gt; 0; i -= 12)&#xD;&#xA;          sb.append(Long.toString(round(random() * pow(36, min(12, abs(i)))), 36));&#xD;&#xA;        return sb.toString();&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's a sample run:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    scala&gt; RandomAlphaNum.gen(42)&#xD;&#xA;    res3: java.lang.String = uja6snx21bswt89s3ubxssu8g6qlu16ffzqaxxoy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="58806" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="41177" RevisionGUID="ca9a2a70-6c86-4a7e-830e-7b8e00aa01e3" CreationDate="2008-09-03T05:39:29.303" UserId="3434" Comment="added 49 characters in body" Text="    import static java.lang.Math.round;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.random;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.pow;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.abs;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.min;&#xD;&#xA;    import static org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.leftPad&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    public class RandomAlphaNum {&#xD;&#xA;      public static String gen(int length) {&#xD;&#xA;        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();&#xD;&#xA;        for (int i = length; i &gt; 0; i -= 12) {&#xD;&#xA;          int n = min(12, abs(i));&#xD;&#xA;          sb.append(leftPad(Long.toString(round(random() * pow(36, n)), 36), n, '0'));&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        return sb.toString();&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's a sample run:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    scala&gt; RandomAlphaNum.gen(42)&#xD;&#xA;    res3: java.lang.String = uja6snx21bswf9t89s00bxssu8g6qlu16ffzqaxxoy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2950" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2566" RevisionGUID="74e06810-71fb-460e-af9a-77d61eb83df1" CreationDate="2008-08-05T16:49:31.723" UserId="46" Text="I have worked for a company that developed a system for distributing media content to dedicated &quot;players&quot;. It was web based and used ASP.NET technology and have tried almost every possible media format you can think of and your choice really comes down to asking yourself:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;does it needs to play directly out of the box, or can I make sure that the components required to play the videos can be installed beforehand?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If your answer is that it needs to play out of the box then really your only option is flash (I know that it is not installed by default, but most will already have it installed)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If it is not a big issue that extra components are needed then you can go with formats that are supported by windows media player&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The reason why windows media player falls into the second option is because for some browsers and some formats extra components must be installed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We had the luxury that the &quot;players&quot; were provided by us, so we could go for the second option, however even we tried to [convert as much as possible][1] back to flash because it handles way better than windows media player&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://ffmpeg.mplayerhq.hu/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="2981" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2596" RevisionGUID="ab6c81a6-bb1f-4c73-8057-53e0936e823f" CreationDate="2008-08-05T17:19:03.893" UserId="72" Text="I'm no expert on Agile development, but I would imagine that integrating some basic automated pen-test software into your build cycle would be a good start.   <row Id="31520" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="24429" RevisionGUID="03eab5c2-209b-4d59-9519-107fb6b6c079" CreationDate="2008-08-23T17:51:41.660" UserId="1862" Comment="added 4 characters in body" Text="You can use a file system watcher to check when the file has been changed.  It only becomes &quot;changed&quot; after whichever program had the file previously closes the file.  I know you asked for C#, but my VB.Net is much better. Hope you or someone else can translate.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It tries to open the file, if it isn't available, it adds a watcher, and waits for the file to be changed.  After the file is changed, it tries to open again.  It throws an exception if it waits more than 120 seconds, because you may get caught in a situation where the file is never released.  Also, I decided to add a timeout of waiting for the file change of 5 seconds, in case of the small possibility that the file was closed prior to the actual file watcher being created.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;     Public Sub WriteToFile(ByVal FilePath As String, ByVal FileName As String, ByVal Data() As Byte)&#xD;&#xA;            Dim FileOpen As Boolean&#xD;&#xA;            Dim File As System.IO.FileStream = Nothing&#xD;&#xA;            Dim StartTime As DateTime&#xD;&#xA;            Dim MaxWaitSeconds As Integer = 120&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            StartTime = DateTime.Now&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            FileOpen = False&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            Do&#xD;&#xA;                Try&#xD;&#xA;                    File = New System.IO.FileStream(FilePath &amp; FileName, IO.FileMode.Append)&#xD;&#xA;                    FileOpen = True&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                Catch ex As Exception&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                    If DateTime.Now.Subtract(StartTime).TotalSeconds &gt; MaxWaitSeconds Then&#xD;&#xA;                        Throw New Exception(&quot;Waited more than &quot; &amp; MaxWaitSeconds &amp; &quot; To Open File.&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;                    Else&#xD;&#xA;                        Dim FileWatch As System.IO.FileSystemWatcher&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                        FileWatch = New System.IO.FileSystemWatcher(FilePath, FileName)&#xD;&#xA;                        FileWatch.WaitForChanged(IO.WatcherChangeTypes.Changed,5000)&#xD;&#xA;                    End If&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                    FileOpen = False&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;                End Try&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            Loop While Not FileOpen&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;            If FileOpen Then&#xD;&#xA;                File.Write(Data, 0, Data.Length)&#xD;&#xA;                File.Close()&#xD;&#xA;            End If&#xD;&#xA;        End Sub" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="31522" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="24370" RevisionGUID="d545d51d-4f8d-4b2a-83ea-f486b9118394" CreationDate="2008-08-23T16:50:59.403" UserId="726" Text="**Python** uses pass-by-value, but since all such values are object references, the net effect is something akin to pass-by-reference. However, Python programmers think more about whether an object type is *mutable* or *immutable*. Mutable objects can be changed in-place (e.g., dictionaries, lists, user-defined objects), whereas immutable objects can't (e.g., integers, strings, tuples).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The following example shows a function that is passed two arguments, an immutable string, and a mutable list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; def do_something(a, b):&#xD;&#xA;    ...     a = &quot;Red&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    ...     b.append(&quot;Blue&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    ... &#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = &quot;Yellow&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; b = [&quot;Black&quot;, &quot;Burgundy&quot;]&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; print a, b&#xD;&#xA;    Yellow ['Black', 'Burgundy', 'Blue']&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Because the `a` parameter in `do_something()` is a reference to an immutable string object, the line `a = &quot;Red&quot;` merely creates a local name, `a`, for the string value `&quot;Red&quot;` and has no effect on the passed-in argument.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The `b` parameter is a reference to a mutable list object, and the `.append()` method performs an in-place extension of the list, tacking on the new `&quot;Blue&quot;` string value.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Because string objects are immutable, they don't have any methods that support in-place modifications.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once the function returns, the re-assignment of `a` has had no effect, while the extension of `b` clearly shows pass-by-reference style call semantics.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that even if the argument for `a` is a mutable type, the re-assignment within the function is not an in-place operation, and so there would be no change to the passed argument's value:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = [&quot;Purple&quot;, &quot;Violet&quot;]&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; print a, b&#xD;&#xA;    ['Purple', 'Violet'] ['Black', 'Burgundy', 'Blue', 'Blue']&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you did't want your list modified by the called function, you would instead use the immutable tuple type (identified by the parentheses in the literal form, rather than square brackets), which does not support the in-place `.append()` method:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = &quot;Yellow&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; b = (&quot;Black&quot;, &quot;Burgundy&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    Traceback (most recent call last):&#xD;&#xA;      File &quot;&lt;stdin&gt;&quot;, line 1, in &lt;module&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      File &quot;&lt;stdin&gt;&quot;, line 3, in do_something&#xD;&#xA;    AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'append'&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="58807" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="41177" RevisionGUID="723970ca-72b6-41d9-813e-a406cd31f9ae" CreationDate="2008-09-03T17:16:38.253" UserId="3434" Comment="added 28 characters in body" Text="Here it is in Java:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.round;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.random;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.pow;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.abs;&#xD;&#xA;    import static java.lang.Math.min;&#xD;&#xA;    import static org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.leftPad&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    public class RandomAlphaNum {&#xD;&#xA;      public static String gen(int length) {&#xD;&#xA;        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();&#xD;&#xA;        for (int i = length; i &gt; 0; i -= 12) {&#xD;&#xA;          int n = min(12, abs(i));&#xD;&#xA;          sb.append(leftPad(Long.toString(round(random() * pow(36, n)), 36), n, '0'));&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        return sb.toString();&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's a sample run:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    scala&gt; RandomAlphaNum.gen(42)&#xD;&#xA;    res3: java.lang.String = uja6snx21bswf9t89s00bxssu8g6qlu16ffzqaxxoy&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Have you looked to see if odbcss.h has declared a variable you already have?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
