  <row Id="58821" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="42148" RevisionGUID="0c6abf5f-201a-4405-9ee0-3c2c8494b5ec" CreationDate="2008-09-03T17:27:18.430" UserId="1219" Text="If you use an XmlTextReader class it will technically be faster than using an XmlDocument, which parses the entire file and builds a DOM for you.  But you must also consider that fact that with an XmlTextReader, you are just reading one node at a time, so there is the additional overhead of making sense of the data as you read it.  If you are going to end up storing everything yourself anyway, using XmlDocument might end up being more efficient." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="31523" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="24370" RevisionGUID="5a23a56c-f1ad-4d68-91d4-4dd8f03d1675" CreationDate="2008-08-23T17:53:47.177" UserId="726" Comment="Corrected a misleading statement about immutable arguments." Text="**Python** uses pass-by-value, but since all such values are object references, the net effect is something akin to pass-by-reference. However, Python programmers think more about whether an object type is *mutable* or *immutable*. Mutable objects can be changed in-place (e.g., dictionaries, lists, user-defined objects), whereas immutable objects can't (e.g., integers, strings, tuples).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The following example shows a function that is passed two arguments, an immutable string, and a mutable list.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; def do_something(a, b):&#xD;&#xA;    ...     a = &quot;Red&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    ...     b.append(&quot;Blue&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    ... &#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = &quot;Yellow&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; b = [&quot;Black&quot;, &quot;Burgundy&quot;]&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; print a, b&#xD;&#xA;    Yellow ['Black', 'Burgundy', 'Blue']&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The line `a = &quot;Red&quot;` merely creates a local name, `a`, for the string value `&quot;Red&quot;` and has no effect on the passed-in argument (which is now hidden, as `a` must refer to the local name from then on). Assignment is not an in-place operation, regardless of whether the argument is mutable or immutable.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The `b` parameter is a reference to a mutable list object, and the `.append()` method performs an in-place extension of the list, tacking on the new `&quot;Blue&quot;` string value.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(Because string objects are immutable, they don't have any methods that support in-place modifications.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once the function returns, the re-assignment of `a` has had no effect, while the extension of `b` clearly shows pass-by-reference style call semantics.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As mentioned before, even if the argument for `a` is a mutable type, the re-assignment within the function is not an in-place operation, and so there would be no change to the passed argument's value:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = [&quot;Purple&quot;, &quot;Violet&quot;]&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; print a, b&#xD;&#xA;    ['Purple', 'Violet'] ['Black', 'Burgundy', 'Blue', 'Blue']&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you didn't want your list modified by the called function, you would instead use the immutable tuple type (identified by the parentheses in the literal form, rather than square brackets), which does not support the in-place `.append()` method:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; a = &quot;Yellow&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; b = (&quot;Black&quot;, &quot;Burgundy&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    &gt;&gt;&gt; do_something(a, b)&#xD;&#xA;    Traceback (most recent call last):&#xD;&#xA;      File &quot;&lt;stdin&gt;&quot;, line 1, in &lt;module&gt;&#xD;&#xA;      File &quot;&lt;stdin&gt;&quot;, line 3, in do_something&#xD;&#xA;    AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'append'&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="31524" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="7252" RevisionGUID="b5ddd4d5-944c-4c24-8961-b08947a09c5b" CreationDate="2008-08-10T17:34:46.630" UserId="573" Text="How to make junior programmers write tests?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="31526" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="7252" RevisionGUID="b5ddd4d5-944c-4c24-8961-b08947a09c5b" CreationDate="2008-08-10T17:34:46.630" UserId="573" Text="We have a junior programmer that simply doesn't write enough tests.  &#xD;&#xA;I have to nag him every two hours, &quot;have you written tests?&quot;.  &#xD;&#xA;We've tried:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Showing that the design becomes simpler&#xD;&#xA;  - Showing it prevents defects&#xD;&#xA;  - Making it an ego thing saying only bad programmers don't&#xD;&#xA;  - This weekend 2 team members had to come to work because his code had a NULL reference and he didn't test it&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My work requires top quality stable code, and usually everyone 'get it' and there's no need to push tests through. We know we can make him write tests, but we all know the useful tests are those written when you're into it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Do you know of more motivations?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="25" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="33" RevisionGUID="b05fc0ef-9eee-4efc-8e15-cc7c3c734ea6" CreationDate="2008-08-01T12:26:39.773" UserId="13" Text="`Math.Floor` rounds down, `Math.Ceiling` rounds up, and `Math.Truncate` rounds towards zero. Thus, `Math.Truncate` is like `Math.Floor` for positive numbers, and like `Math.Ceiling` for negative numbers. Here's the [reference](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.math.truncate.aspx).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For completeness, `Math.Round` rounds to the nearest integer. If the number is exactly midway between two integers, then it rounds towards the even one. [Reference.](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.math.round.aspx)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="43" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="52" RevisionGUID="25e071df-8581-4cf5-a270-b05d129160db" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:08:59.127" UserId="23" Text="Have a look at this article&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://www.gskinner.com/blog/archives/2006/06/as3_resource_ma.html&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IANA actionscript programmer, however the feeling I'm getting is that, because the garbage collector might not run when you want it to.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hence&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://www.craftymind.com/2008/04/09/kick-starting-the-garbage-collector-in-actionscript-3-with-air/&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So I'd recommend trying out their collection code and see if it helps&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    private var gcCount:int;&#xD;&#xA;    private function startGCCycle():void{&#xD;&#xA;    	gcCount = 0;&#xD;&#xA;    	addEventListener(Event.ENTER_FRAME, doGC);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    private function doGC(evt:Event):void{&#xD;&#xA;    	flash.system.System.gc();&#xD;&#xA;    	if(++gcCount &gt; 1){&#xD;&#xA;    		removeEventListener(Event.ENTER_FRAME, doGC);&#xD;&#xA;    		setTimeout(lastGC, 40);&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    private function lastGC():void{&#xD;&#xA;    	flash.system.System.gc();&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="44" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="53" RevisionGUID="e7a9a615-b7e7-4445-a522-514b9322f061" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:08:59.487" UserId="34" Text="(I'm not positive about this, but...)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;AS3 uses a non-deterministic garbage collection. Which means that unreferenced memory will be freed up whenever the runtime feels like it (typically not unless there's a reason to run, since it's an expensive operation to execute). This is the same approach used by most modern garbage collected languages (like C# and Java as well).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Assuming there are no other references to the memory pointed to by byteArray or the items within the array itself, the memory will be freed at some point after you exit the scope where byteArray is declared.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can force a garbage collection, though you really shouldn't. If you do, do it only for testing...if you do it in production, you'll hurt performance much more than help me.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To force a GC, try (yes, twice):&#xD;&#xA;flash.system.System.gc();&#xD;&#xA;flash.system.System.gc();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can read more at:&#xD;&#xA;http://www.craftymind.com/2008/04/09/kick-starting-the-garbage-collector-in-actionscript-3-with-air/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4349" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3752" RevisionGUID="fbb43152-43bf-4efb-a404-a410070eceff" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:40:32.087" UserId="106" Text="The [Microsoft AJAX library][1] will accomplish this. You could also create your own solution that involves using AJAX to call your own aspx (as basically) script files to run .NET functions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suggest the Microsoft AJAX library. Once installed and referenced, you just add a line in your page load or init:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Ajax.Utility.RegisterTypeForAjax(GetType(YOURPAGECLASSNAME))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then you can do things like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;Ajax.AjaxMethod()&gt; _&#xD;&#xA;    Public Function Get5() AS Integer&#xD;&#xA;        Return 5&#xD;&#xA;    End Function&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then, you can call it on your page as:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var myVar = PageClassName.Get5(javascriptCallbackFunction);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The last parameter of your function call must be the javascript callback function that will be executed when the AJAX request is returned.&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.asp.net/ajax/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19712" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15591" RevisionGUID="e655aeaf-a415-443b-9feb-abeacf9be0f8" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:43:58.220" UserId="1855" Text="I think that like many events in VB, it can't be switched off.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Just set a boolean flag as you've suggested.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19713" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15592" RevisionGUID="d02fade5-6cd7-4a2d-9b10-09e17242f991" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:44:26.393" UserId="178" Text="1. You should translate your requirements into a Product Backlog. This backlog is what you use to decide what Sprint Backlog items are chosen for each Sprint iteration. Management decides what is on the Product Backlog, but the team needs to agree to what they can produce in the Sprint (this is a negotiation that occurs at every sprint).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Your Product Owner (usually a product manager) drives the creation of the stories. The Stories are simple (as a system admin, I need to be able to add a user). If your product management does not understand your product, you are in trouble.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. Agile is about designing as required. The design is never in the story. The spec can be per story, or per feature. You could design all your CRUD inside of one spec, which covers multiple stories.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. The Product Owner gets a product demo at the end of every Sprint. So value is demonstrated at every cycle. So your VP would get reports on a monthly basis (ususally 3 weeks of dev + 1 week to prepare for the Sprint demo).  " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39236" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29253" RevisionGUID="e15843de-8905-484d-b1bd-cb59d8736927" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:34:39.700" UserId="2131" Text="6/2002/2003/2005/2008, I believe, can all coexist.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Though just this weekend I purged 'em all except 2008 as it went totally mad and stopped showing the build output.  Plus my splash screen wasn't right. Now it is.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39237" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29255" RevisionGUID="cf6c13da-4b19-48d4-b4de-c6c8d7245b5e" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:35:29.807" UserId="3002" Text="Setting an attribute on an object won't give a compile-time or a run-time error, it will just do nothing useful if the object doesn't access it (i.e. &quot;`node.noSuchAttr = 'bar'`&quot; would also not give an error).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Unless you need a specific feature of `minidom`, I would look at `ElementTree`:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    import sys&#xD;&#xA;    from xml.etree.cElementTree import Element, ElementTree&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    def make_xml():&#xD;&#xA;        node = Element('foo')&#xD;&#xA;        node.text = 'bar'&#xD;&#xA;        doc = ElementTree(node)&#xD;&#xA;        return doc&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    if __name__ == '__main__':&#xD;&#xA;        make_xml().write(sys.stdout)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39239" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29217" RevisionGUID="2d9fc5e9-e9dd-439d-bb20-69dce911c001" CreationDate="2008-08-26T23:47:35.413" UserId="1143" Text="The ability to express real-world scenarios in code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    foreach(House house in location.Houses)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;     foreach(Deliverable mail in new Mailbag(new Deliverable[]&#xD;&#xA;                  {&#xD;&#xA;                  GetLetters(), &#xD;&#xA;                  GetPackages(), &#xD;&#xA;                  GetAdvertisingJunk()&#xD;&#xA;                  })&#xD;&#xA;     {&#xD;&#xA;        if(mail.AddressedTo(house))&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            house.Deliver(mail);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;     }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;-&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    foreach(Deliverable myMail in GetMail())&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        IReadable readable = myMail as IReadable;&#xD;&#xA;        if ( readable != null )&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            Console.WriteLine(readable.Text);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To achieve this you need:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Pointers/References** to ensure that this == this and this != that.&#xD;&#xA;* **Classes** to point to (e.g. Arm) that store data (int hairyness) and operations (Throw(IThrowable))&#xD;&#xA;* **Polymorphism (Inheritance and/or Interfaces)** to treat specific objects in a generic fashion so you can read books as well as graffiti on the wall (both implement IReadable)&#xD;&#xA;* **Encapsulation** because an apple doesn't expose an Atoms[] property" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39240" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="29217" RevisionGUID="6a5d1373-4a2a-42e3-84d9-1b2d751a8a85" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:37:29.787" UserId="1143" Comment="added 217 characters in body" Text="**Archetype**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The ability to express real-world scenarios in code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    foreach(House house in location.Houses)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;     foreach(Deliverable mail in new Mailbag(new Deliverable[]&#xD;&#xA;                  {&#xD;&#xA;                  GetLetters(), &#xD;&#xA;                  GetPackages(), &#xD;&#xA;                  GetAdvertisingJunk()&#xD;&#xA;                  })&#xD;&#xA;     {&#xD;&#xA;        if(mail.AddressedTo(house))&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            house.Deliver(mail);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;     }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;-&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    foreach(Deliverable myMail in GetMail())&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        IReadable readable = myMail as IReadable;&#xD;&#xA;        if ( readable != null )&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            Console.WriteLine(readable.Text);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Why?**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To help us understand this shit more easily. It makes better sense in our heads and if implemented correctly makes the code more efficient, re-usable and reduces repetition.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To achieve this you need:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* **Pointers/References** to ensure that this == this and this != that.&#xD;&#xA;* **Classes** to point to (e.g. Arm) that store data (int hairyness) and operations (Throw(IThrowable))&#xD;&#xA;* **Polymorphism (Inheritance and/or Interfaces)** to treat specific objects in a generic fashion so you can read books as well as graffiti on the wall (both implement IReadable)&#xD;&#xA;* **Encapsulation** because an apple doesn't expose an Atoms[] property" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39241" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29257" RevisionGUID="b856d2c9-8049-42d8-80f3-2e9743f069c6" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:38:15.370" UserId="2219" Text="I ultimately ended up finding the &lt;a href=&quot;http://groups.google.com/group/borland.public.delphi.winapi/browse_frm/thread/36b3d5a199be91f4/7de8dab437f6aa1e?lnk=st&amp;q=delphi+main+form+modal+dialog+z-order#7de8dab437f6aa1e&quot;&gt;answer&lt;/a&gt; using Google Groups. In a nutshell, all the modal dialogs need to have the following added to them:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;&#xD;&#xA;procedure TDialogForm.CreateParams(var Params: TCreateParams);&#xD;&#xA;begin&#xD;&#xA;  inherited;&#xD;&#xA;  Params.Style := Params.Style or WS_POPUP;&#xD;&#xA;  Params.WndParent := (Owner as TWinControl).Handle;&#xD;&#xA;end;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm guessing this does the equivalent of Lars' and Marius' answers in Delphi 7.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48918" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35894" RevisionGUID="2c0f4086-e3e4-4e0a-9ea5-b22beec37a66" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:26:57.207" UserId="1462" Text="I did it this way (ZF 1.5):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $name = new Zend_Form_Element_Text('name');&#xD;&#xA;    $name-&gt;setLabel('Full Name: ')&#xD;&#xA;         -&gt;setRequired(true)&#xD;&#xA;         -&gt;addFilter('StripTags')&#xD;&#xA;         -&gt;addFilter('StringTrim')&#xD;&#xA;         -&gt;addValidator($MyNotEmpty);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;so, the addValidator() is the interesting part. The Message is set in an &quot;Errormessage File&quot; (to bundle all custom messages in one file):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $MyNotEmpty = new Zend_Validate_NotEmpty();&#xD;&#xA;    $MyNotEmpty-&gt;setMessage($trans-&gt;translate('err.IS_EMPTY'),Zend_Validate_NotEmpty::IS_EMPTY);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hope this helps..." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48919" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35895" RevisionGUID="9122eeda-86d2-4a8c-b0b8-f61bba2ded3d" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:31:42.000" UserId="745" Text="&gt; Is it better to go all the way and log everything across multiple attempts/days, or log only what you need to (given hdd is cheap).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The fact harddrives are cheap really isn't a good reason to verbosely log everything possible, for a few reasons.. For one, with a very busy application, you really don't want to slow it down and tie up disc-writes writing logs (harddrives are pretty slow). The second point, and the more important one - there's really very little to gain from terabytes worth of logs.. For development, they can are useful, but you don't need to keep more than a few minutes of them..&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Some logging is of course useful, having different levels is about the only way to go about it - for example debug() info() only get logged if requested (in a config, or command line flag), then maybe warning() and error() get sent to a log file&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For most of the things I've written (smallish scripts) I generally just have a debug() function, that checks if --verbose is set, and prints the message.. That way I can shove debug(&quot;some value: %s&quot; % (avar)) when needed, and not have to worry about going back and removing debugging print() statements everwhere.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For web applications, I generally just use the web-server logs for statistics, and the error log. I use things like mod_rewrite's log when needed, but it would be idiotic to leave this enabled beyond development (as it creates many many lines on each page request)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I suppose it depends on the application itself, but generally, for big applications use multiple levels of logs that can be activated when needed. For smaller things, a --verbose flag or equivalent, for web applications, log errors and (to a point) log hits.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, in &quot;production&quot; log only the information you can use, in development log everything you could possible need to fix problems." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48920" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35897" RevisionGUID="6b017091-d9ec-4ba0-ad59-51d2bce69fe2" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:34:12.120" UserId="3197" Text="Even if you create a voronoi diagram, that still means you need to compare your x, y coordinates to all 15 thousand created areas. To make that easier, the first thing that popped into my mind though was to create some sort of grid over the possible values, so that you can easily place and x/y coordinate into one of the boxes in a grid, if the same is done for the list of areas you should quickly shrink the possible candidates for comparison (because the grid would be more rectangular, it's possible for an area to be in multiple grid positions). " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="46" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="56" RevisionGUID="f1d77e97-2e4a-4602-bd53-65d2434cdf34" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:10:16.473" UserId="39" Text="Give your submit buttons same name like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;submitButton&quot; value=&quot;Previous Page&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;submitButton&quot; value=&quot;Next Page&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When the user presses enter and the *Request* goes to server, you can check the value for **submitButton** on your server-side code which contains a collection of form name/value pairs. For example in classic ASP:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    If Request.Form(&quot;submitButton&quot;) = &quot;Previous Page&quot; Then&#xD;&#xA;        ' Code for Previous Page&#xD;&#xA;    ElseIf Request.Form(&quot;submitButton&quot;) = &quot;Next Page&quot; Then&#xD;&#xA;        ' Code for Next Page&#xD;&#xA;    End If&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Reference: [Using multiple submit buttons on a single form][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.chami.com/tips/internet/042599I.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="51" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="58" RevisionGUID="d6428baa-2fec-47bd-ad1e-6b9323d9ce0f" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:14:30.303" UserId="37" Text="Would it be possible for you to change the previous button type int a button like this:  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;button&quot; name=&quot;prev&quot; value=&quot;Previous Page&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now the Next button would be the default, plus you could also add the default attribute to it so that your browser will highlight it like so:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;next&quot; value=&quot;Next Page&quot; default /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hope that helps,  &#xD;&#xA;Wally" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="52" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="60" RevisionGUID="0fca11ea-9e56-4e3a-92d8-e1015fa8f853" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:14:40.007" UserId="41" Text="Unfortunately when it comes to memory management in Flash/actionscript there isn't a whole lot you can do. ActionScript was designed to be easy to use (so they didn't want people to have to worry about memory management)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The following is a workaround, instead of creating a ByteArray variable try this.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var byteObject:Object = new Object();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    byteObject.byteArray = new ByteArray();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    //Then when you are finished delete the variable from byteObject&#xD;&#xA;    delete byteObject.byteArray;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Where byteArray is a dynamic property of byteObject, you can free the memory that was allocated for it." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="53" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="27" RevisionGUID="3fe3b79d-15fe-4ffd-9ed2-0b75acd66584" CreationDate="2008-08-01T12:17:19.357" UserId="17" Text="This is the method I am currently using on one of my websites.  This only returns a relative day, hour, time.  And then the user has to slap on &quot;ago&quot; in the output.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	public static string ToLongString(this TimeSpan time)&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		string output = String.Empty;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (time.Days &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Days + &quot; days &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if ((time.Days == 0 || time.Days == 1) &amp;&amp; time.Hours &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Hours + &quot; hr &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (time.Days == 0 &amp;&amp; time.Minutes &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Minutes + &quot; min &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (output.Length == 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Seconds + &quot; sec&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		return output.Trim();&#xD;&#xA;	}" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="27" RevisionGUID="222dcb1a-c413-46db-b047-681ce771c47c" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:16:49.127" UserId="17" Text="@jeff&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IMHO yours seems a little long.  However it does seem a little more robust with support for &quot;yesterday&quot; and &quot;years&quot;.  But in my experience when this is used the person is most likely to view the content in the first 30 days.  It is only the really hardcore people that come after that.  So that is why I usually elect to keep this short and simple.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is the method I am currently using on one of my websites.  This only returns a relative day, hour, time.  And then the user has to slap on &quot;ago&quot; in the output.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	public static string ToLongString(this TimeSpan time)&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		string output = String.Empty;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (time.Days &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Days + &quot; days &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if ((time.Days == 0 || time.Days == 1) &amp;&amp; time.Hours &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Hours + &quot; hr &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (time.Days == 0 &amp;&amp; time.Minutes &gt; 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Minutes + &quot; min &quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		if (output.Length == 0)&#xD;&#xA;			output += time.Seconds + &quot; sec&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;		return output.Trim();&#xD;&#xA;	}" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="62" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="62" RevisionGUID="b1929537-4fdc-4034-af13-42b4b9b08345" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:18:37.640" UserId="45" Text="According to Mark Russo (http://introducinglinq.com/blogs/marcorusso/archive/2008/07/20/use-of-distinct-and-orderby-in-linq.aspx) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &quot;The problem is that the Distinct&#xD;&#xA;&gt; operator does not grant that it will&#xD;&#xA;&gt; maintain the original order of&#xD;&#xA;&gt; values.&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So your query will need to work like this&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var names = (from DataRow dr in dataTable.Rows&#xD;&#xA;                 select (string)dr[&quot;Name&quot;]).Distinct().OrderBy( name =&gt; name );" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="31541" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="18803" RevisionGUID="e8c35fee-5a10-41f1-8e58-4986385e1216" CreationDate="2008-08-21T19:20:47.793" UserId="2134" Comment="edited title" Text="|bestpractices|diagram|uml|classdesign|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="31542" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="18803" RevisionGUID="e8c35fee-5a10-41f1-8e58-4986385e1216" CreationDate="2008-08-21T19:20:47.793" UserId="2134" Comment="edited title" Text="In college I've had numerous design and [UML][1] oriented courses, and I recognize that UML can be used to benefit a software project, especially [use-case][2] mapping, but is it really practical?  I've done a few co-op work terms, and it appears that UML is not used heavily in the industry.  Is it worth the time during a project to create UML diagrams?  Also, I find that class diagrams are generally not useful, because it's just faster to look at the header file for a class.  Specifically which diagrams are the most useful?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:** My experience is limited to small, under 10 developer projects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_Modeling_Language&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_case" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39242" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29258" RevisionGUID="598a5686-d265-4df5-a64b-ed65ac7fbe08" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:38:23.060" UserId="2894" Text="You could consider inverting the problem.  That is add the control to the repeaters definition and the remove it if it is not needed.  Not knowing the details of your app this might be a tremendous waste of time but it might just work out in the end." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39243" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29260" RevisionGUID="23c4095e-44cc-4006-b7fb-830d406a49ce" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:38:59.487" UserId="493" Text="Just make sure you only have RTM versions and not Beta or RC versions installed. You'll have no end of pain if you don't cleanly remove the beta or RC versions before installing the RTM versions." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39255" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29265" RevisionGUID="5c45dccf-b2ba-4369-ae07-713fd36d6ad7" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:45:14.727" UserId="1042" Text="1. High-level discussions about purpose, scope, limitations of operating environment, size, etc&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2. Audition a single paragraph description of the system, hammer it out&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3. Mock up UI&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;4. Formalize known requirements&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;5. Now iterate between 3 and 4 with more and more functional prototypes and more specs with more details.  Write tests as you go. Do this until you have functional software and a complete, objective, testable requirements spec.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That's the dream.  The reality is usually after a couple iterations everybody goes head-down and codes until there's a month left to test." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39261" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29267" RevisionGUID="8520bdf2-2fa6-453f-a4c7-725a9310abb2" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:46:26.473" UserId="327" Text="If I understand correctly, Perforce makes all files that are not checked out read-only.  This is similar to the behavior under Microsoft TFS and VSS.  Subversion on the other hand does not set read-only attributes.  IMO, the Subversion method is easier because you don't have to bother with a source control client in order to modify files -- you go ahead and modify with reckless abandon and then compare what has changed on disk with the server when you are ready to check in.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When all files are read-only, I find myself constantly changing a file, attempting to save, discovering it is read-only, then having to hop over to the source control client to check it out.  Its not so bad if the source control client is integrated into your editor, but if you are storing things that are not source code under version control this often isn't an option." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39262" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29268" RevisionGUID="8cff9bed-ad44-414e-ab76-176f96d520ab" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:46:53.367" UserId="242853" Text="In addition to other people's suggestions, I'd recommend either acquiring a copy of SICP, or [reading it online](http://mitpress.mit.edu/sicp/full-text/book/book.html). It's one of the few books that I've read that I feel _greatly_ increased my skill in designing software, particularly in creating good abstraction layers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A book that is not _directly_ related to programming, but is also a good read for programmers (IMO) is [Concrete Mathematics](http://www.amazon.com/Concrete-Mathematics-Foundation-Computer-Science/dp/0201558025). Most, if not all of the topics in it are useful for programmers to know about, and it does a better job of explaining things than any other math book I've read to date." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39267" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29273" RevisionGUID="d81f716c-557f-43a8-b0f1-a368e15889b4" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:50:03.843" UserId="470" Text="I'm a big fan of most titles by Robert C.   <row Id="48926" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35872" RevisionGUID="bed3516f-6ad7-4423-b08a-2a7d71bf0253" CreationDate="2008-08-30T10:41:35.147" UserId="893" Text="You will want to use a geometric construction called a [Voronoi diagram](http://mathworld.wolfram.com/VoronoiDiagram.html). This divides up the plane into a number of areas, one for each point, that encompass all the points that are closest to each of your given points.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The code for the exact algorithms to create the Voronoi diagram and arrange the data structure lookups are too large to fit in this little edit box. :)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48927" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="35872" RevisionGUID="b7c0aaf3-077f-4d31-9340-c409a6cae3ad" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:39:59.623" UserId="893" Comment="additional info about preprocessing" Text="You will want to use a geometric construction called a [Voronoi diagram](http://mathworld.wolfram.com/VoronoiDiagram.html). This divides up the plane into a number of areas, one for each point, that encompass all the points that are closest to each of your given points.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The code for the exact algorithms to create the Voronoi diagram and arrange the data structure lookups are too large to fit in this little edit box. :)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;@Linor: That's essentially what you would do after creating a Voronoi diagram. But instead of making a rectangular grid, you can choose dividing lines that closely match the lines of the Voronoi diagram (this way you will get fewer areas that cross dividing lines). If you recursively divide your Voronoi diagram in half along the best dividing line for each subdiagram, you can then do a tree search for each point you want to look up. This requires a bit of work up front but saves time later. Each lookup would be on the order of log N where N is the number of points. 16 comparisons is a lot better than 15,000!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48928" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35892" RevisionGUID="bcf450fe-dcdc-4434-83ef-6cca40837a6d" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:20:54.727" UserId="2422" Text="The key thing for logging is good planning. I would suggest that you look into the enterprise library exception and logging application block (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc467894.aspx). There is a wee bit of a learning curve but it does work quite well. The approach I favour at the moment is to define 4 priority levels. 4=Unhandled exception (error in event log), 3=Handled exception (warning in event log), 2=Access an external resource such as a webservice, db or mainframe system (information in event log), 1=Verbose/anything else of interest (information in event log).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Using the application block it's then quite easy to tweak what level of priority you want to log. So in development you'd log everything but as you get a stable system in production, you'd probably only be interested in unhandled exceptions and possibly handled exceptions." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48929" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="35892" RevisionGUID="210efa02-654c-41f1-9a7c-50de5687eaf8" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:30:49.380" UserId="2422" Comment="added 916 characters in body" Text="The key thing for logging is good planning. I would suggest that you look into the enterprise library exception and logging application block (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc467894.aspx). There is a wee bit of a learning curve but it does work quite well. The approach I favour at the moment is to define 4 priority levels. 4=Unhandled exception (error in event log), 3=Handled exception (warning in event log), 2=Access an external resource such as a webservice, db or mainframe system (information in event log), 1=Verbose/anything else of interest (information in event log).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Using the application block it's then quite easy to tweak what level of priority you want to log. So in development you'd log everything but as you get a stable system in production, you'd probably only be interested in unhandled exceptions and possibly handled exceptions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Update: For clarity, I would suggest you have logging in both your winform/wpf app and your webservices. In a web scenario, I've had problems in the past where it can be difficult to tie an error on the client back through to the app servers. Mainly because any error through webservices gets wrapped up as a SOAP exception. I can't remember off the top of my head, but I think if you use a custom exception handler (that is part of the enterprise library) you can add data onto exceptions such as the handlinginstance id of the exception from the app server. This makes it easier to tie up exceptions on a client back to your app box by using LogParser (http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=890cd06b-abf8-4c25-91b2-f8d975cf8c07&amp;displaylang=en). " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="64" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="65" RevisionGUID="336f3bd3-df20-4992-81d7-1d4a60ebc74a" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:20:44.283" UserId="35" Text="[Office 2007 MIME Types for IIS][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.bram.us/2007/05/25/office-2007-mime-types-for-iis/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="66" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="68" RevisionGUID="5b2a40f7-4408-45d5-96e0-a0fc3efe91ff" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:22:04.483" UserId="17" Text="It is very simple with the Skip and Take extension methods.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var query = from i in ideas&#xD;&#xA;                select i;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var paggedCollection = query.Skip(startIndex).Take(count);" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="68" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="71" RevisionGUID="2b4d8371-60fd-4162-8b2e-84cfce33930b" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:37:59.723" UserId="49" Text="Here's a general description of a technique for calculating pi that i learnt in high-school.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I only share this because I think it is simple enough that anyone can remember it, indefinitely, plus it teaches you the concept of &quot;Monte-Carlo&quot; methods -- which are statistical methods of arriving at answers that don't immediately appear to be deducible through random processes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Draw a square, and inscribe a quadrant (one quarter of a semi-circle) inside that square (a quadrant with radius equal to the side of the square, so it fills as much of the square as possible)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now throw a dart at the square, and record where it lands -- that is, choose a random point anywhere inside the square. Of course it landed inside the square, but is it inside the semi-circle? record this fact.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Repeat this process many times -- and you will find there is a ratio of the number of points inside the semi-circle versus the total number thrown, call this ratio x.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since the area of the square is r times r, you can deduce that the area of the semi circle is x times r times r (that is, x times r squared). Hence x times 4 will give you pi. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is not a quick method to use. But it's a nice example of a monte carlo method. And if you look around, you may find that many problems otherwise outside your computational skills can be solved by such methods." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="71" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="76" RevisionGUID="6dd9427e-6b56-4226-8831-2a570fbb2efd" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:44:35.843" UserId="50" Text="I believe the easiest way would be to follow Jeff's own advice and have a look around existing code. Try looking at Wordpress, Drupal, Joomla and other well known PHP-based CMS's to see how their API hooks look and feel. This way you can even get ideas you may have not thought of previously to make things a little more rubust.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A more direct answer would be to write general files that they would &quot;include_once&quot; into their file that would provide the usability they would need. This would be broken up into categories and NOT provided in one MASSIVE &quot;hooks.php&quot; file. Be careful though, because what ends up happening is that files that they include end up having more and more dependencies and functionality improves. Try to keep API dependencies low. I.E fewer files for them to include." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="72" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="77" RevisionGUID="8177b4f8-b9d2-4af5-b078-319b71613f3e" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:46:00.097" UserId="40" Text="You could use an Observer pattern.  A simple functional way to accomplish this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?php&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /** Plugin system **/&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    $listeners = array();&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /* Create an entry point for plugins */&#xD;&#xA;    function hook(){&#xD;&#xA;      global $listeners;&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      $num_args = func_num_args();&#xD;&#xA;      $args = func_get_args();&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      if($num_args &lt; 2)&#xD;&#xA;        trigger_error(&quot;Insufficient arguments&quot;, E_USER_ERROR);&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;      // Hook name should always be first argument&#xD;&#xA;      $hook_name = array_shift($args);&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      if(!isset($listeners[$hook_name]))&#xD;&#xA;        return; // No plugins have registered this hook&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      foreach($listeners[$hook_name] as $func){&#xD;&#xA;        $args = $func($args); &#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      return $args;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /* Attach a function to a hook */&#xD;&#xA;    function add_listener($hook, $function_name){&#xD;&#xA;      global $listeners;&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      $listeners[$hook][] = $function_name;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /////////////////////////&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /** Sample Plugin **/&#xD;&#xA;    add_listener('a_b', 'my_plugin_func1');&#xD;&#xA;    add_listener('str', 'my_plugin_func2');&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    function my_plugin_func1($args){&#xD;&#xA;      return array(4, 5);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    function my_plugin_func2($args){&#xD;&#xA;      return str_replace('sample', 'CRAZY', $args[0]);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /////////////////////////&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    /** Sample Application **/&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    $a = 1;&#xD;&#xA;    $b = 2;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    list($a, $b) = hook('a_b', $a, $b);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    $str  = &quot;This is my sample application\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    $str .= &quot;$a + $b = &quot;.($a+$b).&quot;\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    $str .= &quot;$a * $b = &quot;.($a*$b).&quot;\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    $str = hook('str', $str);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    echo $str;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    ?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Output:**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    This is my CRAZY application&#xD;&#xA;    4 + 5 = 9&#xD;&#xA;    4 * 5 = 20&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Notes:**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For this example source code, you must declare all your plugins before the actual source code that you want to be extendable.  I've included an example of how to handle single or multiple values being passed to the plugin.  The hardest part of this is writing the actual documentation which lists what arguments get passed to each hook.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is just one method of accomplishing a plugin system in PHP.  There are better alternatives, I suggest you check out the WordPress Documentation for more information.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Sorry, it appears underscore characters are replaced by HTML entities by Markdown?  I can re-post this code when this bug gets fixed.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Edit: Nevermind, it only appears that way when you are editing*" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19722" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15600" RevisionGUID="8c5bdb54-5f36-4cee-a052-f977eaab1888" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:48:05.043" UserId="1854" Text="It would be pretty easy to build this by setting up a sample database with a extremely small amount of dummy data, which would receive the query first. A couple of things will happen:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1. You might get a SQL syntax error, which would not load the database much since it's a small database.&#xD;&#xA;2. You might get back a response which could clearly be shown to contain every row in one or more tables, which is probably not what they want.&#xD;&#xA;3. Things which pass the above conditions are likely to be okay, so you can run them against the copy of the production database.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Assuming your schema doesn't change much and is not particularly weird, writing the above is likely the quickest solution to your problem.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19723" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15601" RevisionGUID="162f729c-20b9-4842-a1db-16f0782f0008" CreationDate="2008-08-19T02:48:52.063" UserId="1877" Text="Jeff built an [Ultimate Developer Rig][1] for Scott Hanselman a while back.   <row Id="19748" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15622" RevisionGUID="d2e59aa7-3e7c-44f8-a9b2-40912c295c2b" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:03:58.617" UserId="751" Text="It may not help if the problem is inside one of your controls - as you expect - but if the page is poorly designed and that's causing render to be slow, [YSlow][1] should help clean that up.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]:http://developer.yahoo.com/yslow/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19755" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15627" RevisionGUID="cdef137b-9969-4f80-98c5-f99e83c472c4" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:07:38.343" UserId="536" Text="One useful example is the guys who run DB4O object oriented database. There, WeakReferences are used as a kind of light cache: it will keep your objects in memory only as long as your application does, allowing you to put a real cache on top.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another use would be in the implementation of weak event handlers. Currently, one big source of memory leaks in .NET applications is forgetting to remove event handlers. E.g.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public MyForm()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        MyApplication.Foo += someHandler;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See the problem? In the above snippet, MyForm will be kept alive in memory forever as long as MyApplication is alive in memory. Create 10 MyForms, close them all, your 10 MyForms will still be in memory, kept alive by the event handler.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Enter WeakReference. You can build a weak event handler using WeakReferences so that someHandler is a weak event handler to MyApplication.Foo, thus fixing your memory leaks!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This isn't just theory. Dustin Campbell from the DidItWith.NET blog posted [an implementation of weak event handlers][1] using System.WeakReference.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://diditwith.net/PermaLink,guid,aacdb8ae-7baa-4423-a953-c18c1c7940ab.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19760" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15630" RevisionGUID="9fead55e-c19e-4997-be0f-2f37102d3ddc" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:10:41.253" UserId="1879" Text="If your people are using the mysql(1) program to run queries, you can use the [safe-updates][1] option (aka i-am-a-dummy) to get you part of what you need.  Its name is somewhat misleading; it not only prevents UPDATE and DELETE without a WHERE (which you're not worried about), but also adds an implicit LIMIT 1000 to SELECT statements, and aborts SELECTs that have joins and are estimated to consider over 1,000,000 tuples --- perfect for discouraging Cartesian joins.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/mysql-tips.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4361" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3764" RevisionGUID="0666367a-197e-4e5f-9ded-90ba7b7421f4" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:51:00.053" UserDisplayName="Jeff" Text="Second the recommendation on file paths. I've worked on a couple of projects that needed to manage large-ish asset collections, and any attempts to store things directly in the DB resulted in pain and frustration long-term.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The only real &quot;pro&quot; I can think of regarding storing them in the DB is the potential for easy of individual image assets. If there are no file paths to use, and all images are streamed straight out of the DB, there's no danger of a user finding files they shouldn't have access to.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That seems like it would be better solved with an intermediary script pulling data from a web-inaccessible file store, though. So the DB storage isn't REALLY necessary." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4366" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3691" RevisionGUID="d480442f-5ff1-42e7-8a80-643a05ac8c8a" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:06:44.247" UserId="501" Text="Something like this came to my mind&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    select @rownum:=@rownum+1 rownum, entries.* &#xD;&#xA;    from (select @rownum:=0) r, entries &#xD;&#xA;    where uid = ? and ronum % 150 = 0&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't have MySQL at my hand but maybe this will help ..."   <row Id="4367" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3691" RevisionGUID="300c05a3-e12f-4721-bcf1-2c57249eee85" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:58:30.757" UserId="501" Text="Something like this came to my mind&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    select @rownum:=@rownum+1 rownum, entries.* &#xD;&#xA;    from (select @rownum:=0) r, entries &#xD;&#xA;    where uid = ? and rownum % 150 = 0&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't have MySQL at my hand but maybe this will help ..."   <row Id="4369" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3772" RevisionGUID="32389c0b-c532-409c-b9a8-3b297b015981" CreationDate="2008-08-06T17:59:59.380" UserId="437" Text="In my experience, sometimes the simplest solution is to **name the images according to the primary key**. So it's easy to find the image that belongs to a particular record, and vice versa. But at the same time you're not storing *anything* about the image in the database."   <row Id="4372" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3777" RevisionGUID="e393de07-3e01-4cb7-8163-01fb33b97dec" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:04:25.270" UserId="384" Text="Well, if you don't want to do it using AJAX or any other way and just want a normal ASP.NET postback to happen, here is how you do it (without using any other libraries):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*It is a little tricky though... :)*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;i. In your code file (assuming you are using C# and .NET 2.0 or later) add the following Interface to your Page Class to make it look like&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public partial class Default : System.Web.UI.Page, IPostBackEventHandler{}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;ii. This should add (using Tab-Tab) this function to your code file:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public void RaisePostBackEvent(string eventArgument) { }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;iii. In your onclick event in Javascript write the following code:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var pageId = '&lt;%=  Page.ClientID %&gt;';&#xD;&#xA;    __ doPostBack(pageId, argumentString);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This will call the 'RaisePostBackEvent' method in your code file with the 'eventArgument' as the 'argumentString' you passed from the Javascript. Now, you can call any other event you like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;P.S: That is 'underscore-underscore-doPostBack' ... And, there should be no space in that sequence... Somehow the WMD does not allow me to write to underscores followed by a character!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48930" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="35892" RevisionGUID="fc39e56b-fddd-4dbd-9ae5-c7ba4c0ece2a" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:40:40.217" UserId="2422" Comment="added 365 characters in body" Text="The key thing for logging is good planning. I would suggest that you look into the enterprise library exception and logging application block (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc467894.aspx). There is a wee bit of a learning curve but it does work quite well. The approach I favour at the moment is to define 4 priority levels. 4=Unhandled exception (error in event log), 3=Handled exception (warning in event log), 2=Access an external resource such as a webservice, db or mainframe system (information in event log), 1=Verbose/anything else of interest (information in event log).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Using the application block it's then quite easy to tweak what level of priority you want to log. So in development you'd log everything but as you get a stable system in production, you'd probably only be interested in unhandled exceptions and possibly handled exceptions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Update**: For clarity, I would suggest you have logging in both your winform/wpf app and your webservices. In a web scenario, I've had problems in the past where it can be difficult to tie an error on the client back through to the app servers. Mainly because any error through webservices gets wrapped up as a SOAP exception. I can't remember off the top of my head, but I think if you use a custom exception handler (that is part of the enterprise library) you can add data onto exceptions such as the handlinginstance id of the exception from the app server. This makes it easier to tie up exceptions on a client back to your app box by using LogParser (http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=890cd06b-abf8-4c25-91b2-f8d975cf8c07&amp;displaylang=en). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Second Update**: I also like to give each different event a seperate event id and to track that in a text file or spreadsheet under source control. Yes, its a pain but if you're lucky enough to have an IT team looking after your systems in production, I find they tend to expect different events to have different event ids." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48931" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35899" RevisionGUID="9ed0501f-dbdf-4ae7-a8f4-cf4c3b6c79af" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:42:35.860" UserId="2974" Text="G'day,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've worked with both techniques and I would say that developing on the trunk and branching off stable points as releases is the best way to go.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Those people above who object saying that you'll have:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   - Constant build problems for daily builds &#xD;&#xA;&gt;   - Productivity loss when a a developer commits a problem for all&#xD;&#xA;&gt; other people on the project&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;have probably not used continuous integration techniques.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It's true that if you don't perform several test builds during the day, say once every hour or so, will leave themselves open to these problems which will quickly strangle the pace of development.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Doing several test builds during the day quickly folds in updates to the main code base so that other's can use it and also alerts you during the day if someone has broken the build so that they can fix it before going home.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As pointed out, only finding out about a broken build when the nightly build for running the regression tests fails is sheer folly and will quickly slow things down.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Have a read of Martin Fowler's paper on [Continuous Integration][1]. We rolled our own such system for a major project (3,000kSLOC) in about 2,000 lines of Posix sh.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;HTH&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;cheers,&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Rob&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://martinfowler.com/articles/continuousIntegration.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="74" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="73" RevisionGUID="cd52b580-3088-417c-9e00-d8354d40c76f" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:40:16.443" UserId="13" Text="@Jax: The `extern &quot;C&quot;` thing matters, very very much. If a header file doesn't have one, then (unless it's a C++-only header file), you would have to enclose your `#include` with it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #ifdef __cplusplus&#xD;&#xA;    extern &quot;C&quot; {&#xD;&#xA;    #endif&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;sys/socket.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    // include other similarly non-compliant header files&#xD;&#xA;    #ifdef __cplusplus&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    #endif&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Basically, anytime where a C++ program wants to link to C-based facilities, the `extern &quot;C&quot;` is vital. In practical terms, it means that the names used in external references will not be mangled, like normal C++ names would. [Reference.](http://www.parashift.com/c++-faq-lite/mixing-c-and-cpp.html)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

In practical terms, it means that the names used in external references will not be mangled, like normal C++ names would.   <row Id="77" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="82" RevisionGUID="c991da8c-286f-4996-a997-e85647adcd40" CreationDate="2008-08-01T14:06:28.560" UserId="51" Text="Have a DTS job (or a job that is started by a windows service) that runs at a given interval. Each time it is run, it gets information about the given table by using the system [INFORMATION_SCHEMA][1] tables, and records this data in the data repository. Compare the data returned regarding the structure of the table with the data returned the previous time. If it is different, then you know that the structure has changed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Example query to return information regarding all of the columns in table ABC (ideally listing out just the columns from the INFORMATION_SCHEMA table that you want, instead of using *select ** like I do here):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    select * from INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS where TABLE_NAME = 'ABC'&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You would monitor different columns and INFORMATION_SCHEMA views depending on how exactly you define &quot;changes to a table&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms186778.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="79" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="87" RevisionGUID="39798d44-c8af-425c-8481-7593b112bb0e" CreationDate="2008-08-01T14:26:22.793" UserId="59" Text="One framework I'm considering would be for a blogging platform.  Since just about any possible view of data you would want would be sorted by date, I was thinking about this structure:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One directory per content node:&#xD;&#xA;./content/YYYYMMDDHHMMSS/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Subdirectories of each node including  &#xD;&#xA;/tags  &#xD;&#xA;/authors  &#xD;&#xA;/comments  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;as well as simple text files in the node directory for pre- and post-rendered content and the like.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This would allow a simple PHP [glob()][1] call (and probably a reversal of the result array) to query on just about anything within the content structure:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    glob(&quot;content/*/tags/funny&quot;);  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;would return paths including all articles tagged &quot;funny&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://us3.php.net/glob" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39291" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29274" RevisionGUID="4bb0cfa7-2712-479f-84f9-724ee8b10bd5" CreationDate="2008-08-27T00:51:49.703" UserId="2988" Text="[Definitions for Object-Orientation][1] are of course a [huge can of worms][2], but here are my 2 cents:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To me, Object-Orientation is all about objects that collaborate by sending messages. That is, to me, the single most important trait of an object-oriented language.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If I had to put up an ordered list of all the features that an object-oriented language must have, it would look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. [Objects sending messages to other objects][3]&#xD;&#xA; 2. Everything is an Object&#xD;&#xA; 3. [Late Binding][4]&#xD;&#xA; 4. [Subtype Polymorphism][5]&#xD;&#xA; 5. Inheritance or something similarly expressive, like [Delegation][6]&#xD;&#xA; 6. [Encapsulation][7]&#xD;&#xA; 7. [Information Hiding][8]&#xD;&#xA; 8. Abstraction&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Obviously, this list is very controversial, since it excludes a great variety of languages that are widely regarded as object-oriented, such as [Java][9], [C#][10] and [C++][11], all of which violate points 1, 2 and 3. However, there is no doubt that those languages allow for object-oriented programming (but so does [C][12]) and even facilitate it (which C doesn't). So, I have came to call languages that satisfy those requirements &quot;purely object-oriented&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As archetypical object-oriented languages I would name [Self][13] and [Newspeak][14].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Both satisfy the above-mentioned requirements. Both are inspired by and successors to [Smalltalk][15], and both actually manage to be &quot;more OO&quot; in some sense. The things that I like about Self and Newspeak are that both take the message sending paradigm to the extreme (Newspeak even more so than Self).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In Newspeak, *everything* is a message send. There are no instance variables, no fields, no attributes, no constants, no class names. They are all emulated by using getters and setters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In Self, there are *no classes*, only objects. This emphasizes, what OO is *really* about: objects, not classes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?DefinitionsForOo &quot;Definitions for OO on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?OoBestFeatures &quot;OO Best Features on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?MessagePassing &quot;Message Passing on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?LateBinding &quot;Late Binding on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?PolyMorphism &quot;Polymorphism on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?DelegationInheritance &quot;Delegation Inheritance on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?EncapsulationDefinition &quot;Encapsulation Definition on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?InformationHiding &quot;Information Hiding on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://Java.Com/ &quot;Java Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: http://MSDN.Microsoft.Com/vcsharp/ &quot;C# Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://Open-Std.Org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/ &quot;C++ Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [12]: http://Open-Std.Org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/ &quot;C Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [13]: http://Research.Sun.Com/self/ &quot;Self Homepage at Sun Research&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [14]: http://NewspeakLanguage.Org/ &quot;Newspeak Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [15]: http://Smalltalk.Org/ &quot;Smalltalk Programming Language&quot;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48934" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35903" RevisionGUID="6f4acf4b-555f-40a9-a83f-57cd7ca8ebdd" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:48:33.240" UserId="745" Text="Nothing. They both do the same, both perform about equally. The only reason you should choose one over the other is if you help out with a project that already uses one..&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The other possible reason for choosing one is an application or service which only supports one of the system.. For example, I pretty much chose to learn git because of [github](http://github.com).." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48940" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35908" RevisionGUID="ff827cca-7021-44d0-987f-b787b1bd1451" CreationDate="2008-08-30T11:58:22.887" UserDisplayName="JP" Text="Do not mix up the user mode ZwOpenDirectoryObject with the kernel mode ZwOpenDirectoryObject -- the kernel mode API (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms800966.aspx) indeed seems to available as of XP only, but the user mode version should be available at least since NT 4. Anyway, I would not recommend using ZwOpenDirectoryObject.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Why should configuration files and registry keys fail on Vista? Of course, you have to get the security settings right -- but you would have to do that for your named events as well -- so there should not be a big difference here. Maybe you should tell us some more details about the nature of your processes -- do they all run within the same logon session or do they run as different users even? And is there some master process or who creates the events in the first place?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Frankly, I tend to find the Process Explorer idea to be not a very good one. Despite the fact that you probably will not be able to accomplish that without using undocumented APIs and/or a device driver, I do not think that a process should be spelunking around in the handle table of another process just to find out the names of some kernel objects. And, of course, the same security issues apply again." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48943" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35911" RevisionGUID="68679518-5b0b-48b4-a8ce-127dd30bfbe6" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:01:09.527" UserId="745" Text="Thanks to the fact it doesn't need to communicate with a central server constantly, pretty much every command runs in less than a second (obviously git push/pull/fetch are slower simply because they have to initalise SSH connections). Branching is far far easier (one simple command to branch, one simple command to merge)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48944" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35912" RevisionGUID="bf45594e-d155-49de-9e8a-ec73f57c21bf" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:01:48.870" UserId="2246" Text="The general concept you're describing is [nearest-neighbour search][1], and there are a whole raft of techniques which deal with solving these types of queries, either exactly or approximately. The basic idea is to use a spatial partitioning technique to reduce the complexity from O(n) per query to (approximately) O( log n ) per query.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;KD-Trees, and variants of KD-Trees seem to work very well, but quad-trees will also work. The quality of these searches depends on whether your set of 15,000 data points are static (you're not adding a-lot of data points to the reference set). Mount and Arya's work on the [Approximate Nearest Neighbour][2] library is both easy to use and understand, even without a good grounding in the math. It also gives you some flexibility in the types and tolerances of your queries. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-nearest_neighbor_algorithm&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.cs.umd.edu/~mount/ANN/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19766" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15639" RevisionGUID="bd7c7387-d627-4af0-bd8e-a886222f2cae" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:22:18.937" UserId="805" Text="if your sub projects can be released at different versions (like controls, web parts, ect...) then it may make sense to build your structure like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Solution**  &#xD;&#xA;Project 1  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Branch  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Tags  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Trunk  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Project 2&#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Branch  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Tags  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Trunk  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This way you can manage each project release independently.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Otherwise the most common structure is:&#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Branch  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Tags  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Trunk  &#xD;&#xA;&gt;* Docs (Optional)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19777" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15633" RevisionGUID="8e7b8690-9f6a-42ab-a359-828234bd46a4" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:12:54.043" UserId="1491" Text="Subversion repositories are typical sub-divided into:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    branch/&#xD;&#xA;    tags/&#xD;&#xA;    trunk/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You would either place all of your DLL and application projects into the trunk and then use branch and tags for all of them as necessary too. Alternatively, you could create folders for each project in the root and then place the common branch, tags and trunk folders within them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that this practice is simply convention and nothing in SVN requires (or really promotes) doing it exactly this way. However, everyone is used to it. So, you would be doing people a favor to go along.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To elaborate further, the **trunk** is where your main development will take place. When you want to mark a particular revision (e.g. a release version), then simply __svn__ __copy__ the project into the tags directory. Also, just copy code into the **branch** directory when you want to do something dramatic or prolonged and don't want to hinder progress in the **trunk**. Later you can __svn__ __merge__ your **branch** back into the **trunk** when it is ready for action!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19778" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="15633" RevisionGUID="9ef12413-3d6f-4cef-9d58-d2349108770c" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:18:04.670" UserId="1491" Comment="added 356 characters in body" Text="Subversion repositories are typical sub-divided into:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    branch/&#xD;&#xA;    tags/&#xD;&#xA;    trunk/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You would either place all of your DLL and application projects into the **trunk** and then use **branch** and **tags** for all of them as necessary too. Alternatively, you could create folders for each project in the root and then place the common branch, tags and trunk folders within them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that this practice is simply convention and nothing in SVN requires (or really promotes) doing it exactly this way. However, everyone is used to it. So, you would be doing people a favor to go along.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To elaborate further, the **trunk** is where your main development will take place. When you want to mark a particular revision (e.g. a release version), then simply __svn__ __copy__ the project into the tags directory. Also, just copy code into the **branch** directory when you want to do something dramatic or prolonged and don't want to hinder progress in the **trunk**. Later you can __svn__ __merge__ your **branch** back into the **trunk** when it is ready for action!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you want to correct mishaps in your current Subverion repository, then just use __svn__ __move__ to relocate them. Unlike the delete and add process of [CVS](http://www.nongnu.org/cvs/), move will retain version history for the new location." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="86" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="99" RevisionGUID="7b0194e2-e9de-426b-98f5-4528a2f7d8c4" CreationDate="2008-08-01T14:55:08.477" UserId="25" Text="&gt; &#xD;&#xA;The actual resolution of gettimeofday() depends on the hardware architecture. Intel processors as well as SPARC machines offer high resolution timers that measure microseconds. Other hardware architectures fall back to the system’s timer, which is typically set to 100 Hz. In such cases, the time resolution will be less accurate. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I obtained this answer from [High Resolution Time Measurement and Timers, Part I][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.informit.com/guides/content.aspx?g=cplusplus&amp;seqNum=272" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="88" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="93" RevisionGUID="a53a7005-c100-46f2-97d1-a526b708aa41" CreationDate="2008-08-01T14:46:53.097" UserId="25" Text="From my experience, and from what I've read across the internet, the answer is &quot;No,&quot; it is not guaranteed.  It depends on CPU speed, operating system, flavor of Linux, etc." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="89" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="98" RevisionGUID="b7d3d552-f676-4b7b-b23d-20806f132f44" CreationDate="2008-08-01T14:53:47.497" UserId="2089740" Text="Maybe. But you have bigger problems. `gettimeofday()` can result in incorrect timings if there are processes on your system that change the timer (ie, ntpd). On a &quot;normal&quot; linux, though, I believe the resolution of `gettimeofday()` is 10us. It can jump forward and backward and time, consequently, based on the processes running on your system. This effectively makes the answer to your question no.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You should look into `clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC)` for timing intervals. It suffers from several less issues due to things like dual-core systems and external clock settings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, look into the clock_getres() function." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="90" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="98" RevisionGUID="b19939ec-d0b6-400e-b2a1-796fc05389b9" CreationDate="2008-08-01T15:01:48.730" UserId="2089740" Text="Maybe. But you have bigger problems. `gettimeofday()` can result in incorrect timings if there are processes on your system that change the timer (ie, ntpd). On a &quot;normal&quot; linux, though, I believe the resolution of `gettimeofday()` is 10us. It can jump forward and backward and time, consequently, based on the processes running on your system. This effectively makes the answer to your question no.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You should look into `clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC)` for timing intervals. It suffers from several less issues due to things like multi-core systems and external clock settings.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, look into the clock_getres() function."   <row Id="4379" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3776" RevisionGUID="83458df9-36f1-4ec4-80f4-b49a03a842ac" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:02:31.480" UserId="82" Text="A tidier way is to create separate forms for each 'pane' and, in their constructor, set&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Form.TopLevel = false;&#xD;&#xA;    Form.FormBorderStyle = FormBorderStyle.None;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That way, each of these forms can be laid out in its own designer, instantiated one or more times at runtime, and added to the area like a normal control (perhaps you could use a splitcontainer with the TreeView in one panel, and these forms in the other) i.e.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SeparateForm f = new SomePane(); &#xD;&#xA;    MainFormSplitContainer.Controls.Add(f); &#xD;&#xA;    f.DockStyle = DockStyle.Fill; &#xD;&#xA;    f.Show();" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4380" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3776" RevisionGUID="e4af86a2-c88d-46be-ada3-453c72752864" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:07:13.360" UserId="82" Text="A tidier way is to create separate forms for each 'pane' and, in their constructor, set&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Form.TopLevel = false;&#xD;&#xA;    Form.FormBorderStyle = FormBorderStyle.None;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That way, each of these forms can be laid out in its own designer, instantiated one or more times at runtime, and added to the empty area like a normal control.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Perhaps the main form could use a SplitContainer with a static TreeView in one panel, and space to add these forms in the other.   <row Id="19779" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="15633" RevisionGUID="fd393585-5fdd-4ce3-9f98-3131199f3795" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:28:14.540" UserId="1491" Comment="added 195 characters in body" Text="Subversion repositories are typical sub-divided into:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    branch/&#xD;&#xA;    tags/&#xD;&#xA;    trunk/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You would either place all of your DLL and application projects into the **trunk** and then use **branch** and **tags** for all of them as necessary too:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    branch/&#xD;&#xA;    tags/&#xD;&#xA;    trunk/&#xD;&#xA;        project1/&#xD;&#xA;        project2/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Alternatively, you could create folders for each project in the root and then place the common branch, tags and trunk folders within them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    project1/&#xD;&#xA;        branch/&#xD;&#xA;        tags/&#xD;&#xA;        trunk/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    project2/&#xD;&#xA;        branch/&#xD;&#xA;        tags/&#xD;&#xA;        trunk/&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Note that this practice is simply convention and nothing in SVN requires (or really promotes) doing it exactly this way. When you want to mark a particular revision (e.g. a release version), then simply __svn__ __copy__ the project into the tags directory. Also, just copy code into the **branch** directory when you want to do something dramatic or prolonged and don't want to hinder progress in the **trunk**. Later you can __svn__ __merge__ your **branch** back into the **trunk** when it is ready for action!&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you want to correct mishaps in your current Subverion repository, then just use __svn__ __move__ to relocate them.
