  <row Id="19783" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15651" RevisionGUID="41d7b071-8b33-4d87-94eb-646120968ad9" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:33:39.977" UserId="493" Text="using the branch/trunk/tag repository structure is pretty standard, but if I'm understanding you properly, your issue is that you have a set of common dll projects that get used across multiple projects. This can definately become tricky to manage.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So the typical scenario here is that you have some class library called Common.Helpers that has code that is common to all your applications.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Let's say I'm starting a new application called StackOverflow.Web that needs to reference Common.Helpers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Usually what you would do is create a new solution file and add a new project called Stackoverflow.Web and add the existing Common.Helpers project and then reference it from the new Stackoverflow.Web project.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What I usually try and do is create a repository for the Common.Helpers project and then in subversion reference it as an [external][1]. That way you can keep the code under source control in a single location, but still use it seperately in multiple projects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.1/ch07s04.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19785" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15653" RevisionGUID="ce9edb34-ef27-43b5-8320-c0bf18ee1dea" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:36:03.387" UserId="1370" Text="This question actually seems to be about Java vs. C++ performance, and that's not the object orientation so much as running on a virtual machine with garbage collection and such.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[This whitepaper][1] on Java vs. C++ performance might be worth a read.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.idiom.com/~zilla/Computer/javaCbenchmark.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19788" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15657" RevisionGUID="685bfd71-5814-4203-a086-684755eac43b" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:39:43.473" UserId="1353" Text="The best way to do bit manipulation/unsigned bytes is through using **int**s. Even though they are signed they have plenty of spare bits (32 total) to treat as an unsigned byte. Also, all of the mathematical operators will convert smaller fixed precision numbers to **int**. Example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    short a = 1s;&#xD;&#xA;    short b = 2s;&#xD;&#xA;    int c = a + b; // the result is up-converted&#xD;&#xA;    short small = (short)c; // must cast to get it back to short&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Because of this it is best to just stick with integer and mask it to get the bits that you are interested in. Example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    int a = 32;&#xD;&#xA;    int b = 128;&#xD;&#xA;    int foo = (a + b) | 255;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is some more info on Java primitive types http://mindprod.com/jgloss/primitive.html&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One last trivial note, there is one unsigned fixed precision number in Java. That is the **char** primitive.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39292" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="29274" RevisionGUID="2da3c915-8309-4ec8-9a81-e0a896f86ba2" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:09:02.097" UserId="2988" Comment="Corrected spelling" Text="[Definitions for Object-Orientation][1] are of course a [huge can of worms][2], but here are my 2 cents:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To me, Object-Orientation is all about objects that collaborate by sending messages. That is, to me, the single most important trait of an object-oriented language.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If I had to put up an ordered list of all the features that an object-oriented language must have, it would look like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA; 1. [Objects sending messages to other objects][3]&#xD;&#xA; 2. Everything is an Object&#xD;&#xA; 3. [Late Binding][4]&#xD;&#xA; 4. [Subtype Polymorphism][5]&#xD;&#xA; 5. Inheritance or something similarly expressive, like [Delegation][6]&#xD;&#xA; 6. [Encapsulation][7]&#xD;&#xA; 7. [Information Hiding][8]&#xD;&#xA; 8. Abstraction&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Obviously, this list is very controversial, since it excludes a great variety of languages that are widely regarded as object-oriented, such as [Java][9], [C#][10] and [C++][11], all of which violate points 1, 2 and 3. However, there is no doubt that those languages allow for object-oriented programming (but so does [C][12]) and even facilitate it (which C doesn't). So, I have come to call languages that satisfy those requirements &quot;purely object-oriented&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As archetypical object-oriented languages I would name [Self][13] and [Newspeak][14].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Both satisfy the above-mentioned requirements. Both are inspired by and successors to [Smalltalk][15], and both actually manage to be &quot;more OO&quot; in some sense. The things that I like about Self and Newspeak are that both take the message sending paradigm to the extreme (Newspeak even more so than Self).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In Newspeak, *everything* is a message send. There are no instance variables, no fields, no attributes, no constants, no class names. They are all emulated by using getters and setters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In Self, there are *no classes*, only objects. This emphasizes, what OO is *really* about: objects, not classes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?DefinitionsForOo &quot;Definitions for OO on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?OoBestFeatures &quot;OO Best Features on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?MessagePassing &quot;Message Passing on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?LateBinding &quot;Late Binding on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?PolyMorphism &quot;Polymorphism on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [6]: http://C2.Com/cgi/wiki?DelegationInheritance &quot;Delegation Inheritance on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [7]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?EncapsulationDefinition &quot;Encapsulation Definition on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [8]: http://C2.com/cgi/wiki?InformationHiding &quot;Information Hiding on Ward's WikiWikiWeb&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [9]: http://Java.Com/ &quot;Java Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [10]: http://MSDN.Microsoft.Com/vcsharp/ &quot;C# Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [11]: http://Open-Std.Org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/ &quot;C++ Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [12]: http://Open-Std.Org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/ &quot;C Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [13]: http://Research.Sun.Com/self/ &quot;Self Homepage at Sun Research&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [14]: http://NewspeakLanguage.Org/ &quot;Newspeak Programming Language&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [15]: http://Smalltalk.Org/ &quot;Smalltalk Programming Language&quot;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39293" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="1464" RevisionGUID="1509d27f-7bf3-4dd4-896d-e15b93d63c43" CreationDate="2008-08-04T18:00:50.893" UserId="26" Text="Like Rob Allen, I use SQL Compare / Data Compare by Redgate. It's running on a virtual machine which resets each time I start it so the trial never expires. I also use the Database publishing wizard by Microsoft. I also have a console app I wrote in C# that takes a sql script and runs it on a server. This way you can run large scripts with 'GO' commands in it from a command line or in a batch script.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I use Microsoft.SqlServer.BatchParser.dll and Microsoft.SqlServer.ConnectionInfo.dll libraries in the console application."   <row Id="48945" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="35817" RevisionGUID="9718a2f4-7590-4bc5-ba99-8a8dbab6bd9e" CreationDate="2008-08-30T09:27:24.640" UserId="3715" Text="What's the best way to escape os.system() calls in Python?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48947" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35817" RevisionGUID="9718a2f4-7590-4bc5-ba99-8a8dbab6bd9e" CreationDate="2008-08-30T09:27:24.640" UserId="3715" Text="When using `os.system()` it's often necessary to escape filenames passed as parameters to commands.  What's the best way to do this?  Preferably something that would work on multiple operating systems/shells.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm currently doing the following, but am sure there must be a library function for this, or at least a more elegant/robust/efficient option:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    def sh_escape(s):&#xD;&#xA;       return s.replace(&quot;(&quot;,&quot;\\(&quot;).replace(&quot;)&quot;,&quot;\\)&quot;).replace(&quot; &quot;,&quot;\\ &quot;)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    os.system(&quot;cat %s | grep something | sort &gt; %s&quot; &#xD;&#xA;              % (sh_escape(in_filename), &#xD;&#xA;                 sh_escape(out_filename)))" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Text="When using `os.system()` it's often necessary to escape filenames passed as parameters to commands.  What's the best way to do this?  Preferably something that would work on multiple operating systems/shells but in particular for `bash`.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm currently doing the following, but am sure there must be a library function for this, or at least a more elegant/robust/efficient option:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    def sh_escape(s):&#xD;&#xA;       return s.replace(&quot;(&quot;,&quot;\\(&quot;).replace(&quot;)&quot;,&quot;\\)&quot;).replace(&quot; &quot;,&quot;\\ &quot;)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    os.system(&quot;cat %s | grep something | sort &gt; %s&quot; &#xD;&#xA;              % (sh_escape(in_filename), &#xD;&#xA;                 sh_escape(out_filename)))&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**Edit**: I've accepted the simple answer of using quotes, don't know why I didn't think of that, I guess it's because I came from windows where ' and &quot; behave a little differently.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Regarding security, I understand the concern, but in this case, I'm interested in a quick and easy solution which `os.system()` provides and the source of the strings is either not user generated or at least entered by a trusted user (me)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19802" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15665" RevisionGUID="8bfdb695-4517-46e8-9699-97ad21e1af25" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:50:42.593" UserId="943" Text="&gt; I know, I should not use labels.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;But just assume, I have some code, that could gain a lot in readability from labeled breaks, how do I format them.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Mo, your premise is wrong.&#xD;&#xA;The question shouldn't be 'how do I format them?'&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Your question should be 'I have code that has a large amount of logic inside loops - how do I make it more readable?'&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The answer to that question is to move the code into individual, well named functions.   <row Id="39298" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29293" RevisionGUID="a9906f7f-b81a-4dd9-8dc1-957c0b00fc26" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:11:45.710" UserId="2785" Text="I think John is correct. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;My main concern is that instantiating and disposing one huge DataContext class all the time for individual operations that relate to specific areas of the Database would be impose an unnecessary imposition on application resources&quot;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;How do you support that statement? What is your experiment that shows that a large DataContext is a performance bottleneck? Having multiple datacontexts is a lot like having multiple databases and makes sense in similar scenarios, that is, hardly ever. If you are working with multiple datacontexts you need to keep track of which objects belong to which datacontext and you can't relate objects that are not in the same data context. That is a costly design smell for no real benefit. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;@Evan &quot;The DataContext (or Linq to Entities ObjectContext) is more of a &quot;unit of work&quot; than a connection&quot;&#xD;&#xA;That is precisely why you should not have more than one datacontext. Why would you want more that one &quot;unit of work&quot; at a time?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="118" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="128" RevisionGUID="619f4daf-c89e-49db-86e7-f30f98de5179" CreationDate="2008-08-01T16:19:04.283" UserId="26" Text="It depends on how the property is used. For example, say you have a student object that has a name property. You could use your Get method to pull the name from the database, if it hasn't been retrieved already. This way you are reducing unnecessary calls to the database.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now let's say you have a private integer counter in your object that counts the number of times the name has been called. You may want to not use the Get method from inside the object because it would produce an invalid count." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19806" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15669" RevisionGUID="9f85fac8-aeca-4097-92be-54b7f7a8ed29" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:58:22.873" UserId="716" Text="I feel your pain. We have an application which is 'cross-platform'. A typical client/server application where the client needs to be able to run on windows and linux. Since our client base mostly uses windows we work using VS2008 (the debugger makes life a lot easier) - however we still need to perform linux builds. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The major problem with this was we were checking in code that we didn't know would build under gcc, which would more than likely break the CI stuff we had setup. So we installed [MingGW][1] on all our developer's machines which allows us to test that working copy will build under gcc before we commit it back to the repository.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: http://www.mingw.org/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19808" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="15660" RevisionGUID="142a7042-db4a-4e91-bb68-dca5e74b7c76" CreationDate="2008-08-19T03:53:00.920" UserId="257" Comment="wp design doc" Text="Well, [flyweight][1] is a ridiculous pattern to use in a word processor.  IIRC, they had each character being referenced as a object [note: it was for each *glyph*, which is still crazy because your OS will happily draw that for you].  With a pointer being wider than a character and all the processing associated with indirection, you'd be mad to use that particular pattern that way in a word processor.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you're interested in the design of word processors, I found an article that doesn't address patterns but does look at some of the [data structures underlying word processor design and design considerations][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flyweight_pattern&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.bluemug.com/research/text.pdf" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19809" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="15660" RevisionGUID="d94ef03c-961a-4d51-a29c-13698b55136e" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:00:58.360" UserId="257" Comment="make life easy" Text="Well, [flyweight][1] is a ridiculous pattern to use in a word processor.  IIRC, they had each character being referenced as a object [note: it was for each *glyph*, which is still crazy because your OS will happily draw that for you].  With a pointer being wider than a character and all the processing associated with indirection, you'd be mad to use that particular pattern that way in a word processor.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you're interested in the design of word processors, I found an article that doesn't address patterns but does look at some of the [data structures underlying word processor design and design considerations][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Try to remember that design patterns are there to make your life easier, not for you to be pure.  There has to be a reason to use a pattern, it has to offer some benefit.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flyweight_pattern&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.bluemug.com/research/text.pdf" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39307" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29296" RevisionGUID="4eb579e6-a10c-466f-a894-e7ab6477c125" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:13:09.310" UserId="2929" Text="Use something like Host Monitor &lt;http://www.ks-soft.net/hostmon.eng/&gt; to monitor the Event Log for messages related to the failover event, which can send you an alert via email/SMS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm curious though how you wouldn't need to know that the failover happened, because don't you have to then update the datasources in your applications to point to the new server that you failed over to?  Mirroring takes place on different hosts (the primary and the mirror), unlike clustering which has multiple nodes that appear to be a single device from the outside.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, are you using a witness server in order to automatically fail over from the primary to the mirror?  This is the only way I know of to make it happen automatically, and in my experience, you get a lot of false-positives where network hiccups can fool the mirror and witness into thinking the primary is down when in fact it is not."   <row Id="39313" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29300" RevisionGUID="1fe6b773-66fe-4b57-bb23-0699c3eb7d34" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:14:06.767" UserId="1675" Text="I found the answer to my own question by finding a more compatible implementation of &lt;code&gt;stdbool.h&lt;/code&gt; that is compliant with the C99 standard.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;#ifndef _STDBOOL_H&#xD;&#xA;#define _STDBOOL_H&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;#include &lt;stdint.h&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;/* C99 Boolean types for compilers without C99 support */&#xD;&#xA;/* http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/basedefs/stdbool.h.html */&#xD;&#xA;#if !defined(__cplusplus)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;#if !defined(__GNUC__)&#xD;&#xA;/* _Bool builtin type is included in GCC */&#xD;&#xA;/* ISO C Standard: 5.2.5 An object declared as &#xD;&#xA;type _Bool is large enough to store &#xD;&#xA;the values 0 and 1. */&#xD;&#xA;/* We choose 8 bit to match C++ */&#xD;&#xA;/* It must also promote to integer */&#xD;&#xA;typedef int8_t _Bool; &#xD;&#xA;#endif&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;/* ISO C Standard: 7.16 Boolean type */&#xD;&#xA;#define bool _Bool&#xD;&#xA;#define true 1&#xD;&#xA;#define false 0&#xD;&#xA;#define __bool_true_false_are_defined 1&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;#endif&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;#endif&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is taken from the [Ada Class Library](http://sourceforge.net/projects/adacl) project." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39336" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29306" RevisionGUID="1dae2c09-8b6c-4c28-9812-6e7c34b9fd9b" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:19:07.080" UserId="1875" Text="Interesting question.  I don't have a bunch of experience working directly with designers on a project.  When I have, it's been through a contractual sort of agreement where they &quot;delivered&quot; a design.  I have done some of my own design work for both web sites and desktop applications, and though I have not used source control in the past, I am in the process of implementing SVN for my own use as I am starting to do some paid freelance work.  I intend to utilize version/source control precisely the way I would with source code.  It just becomes another folder in the project trunk.  The way I have worked without source control is to create an *assets* folder in which all media files that are equivalents of source code reside.  I like to think of Photoshop PSD's as *graphics source code* while the JPEG output for a web site or otherwise is the *compiled version*.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the case of working with designers, which is a distinct possibility I face in the near future, I'd like to make an attempt to have them &quot;check-in&quot; their different versions of their source files on a regular basis.  I'll be curious to read what others with some experience will say in response to this." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="6617" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="5572" RevisionGUID="9d3d3a56-1eaf-4e53-99a2-261852955ce1" CreationDate="2008-08-08T01:56:00.137" UserId="702" Text="I'm agreeing with Mike Stone also.  My company recently implemented a new user table for outside clients (as opposed to internal users who authenticate through LDAP).  For the external users, we chose to store the GUID as the primary key, and store the username as varchar with unique constraints on the username field.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, if you are going to store the password field, I highly recommend storing the password as a salted, hashed binary in the database.  This way, if someone were to hack your database, they would not have access to your customer's passwords." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

I don't think you need to crank out code with it, but you should know how it works.  The .NET Framework contains a lot of functionality, but it doesn't provide managed code equivalents for the entire Windows API.  Sometimes you have to get a bit closer to the metal, and knowing what's down there and how it behaves will give you  a better understanding of how to use it." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19813" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15673" RevisionGUID="b5283a2f-ca69-4422-b4e1-1b9c493bec81" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:08:02.667" UserId="788" Text="We are using a similar solution to what you described.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We have our code stored on the Windows side of the world and UNIX (QNX 4.25 to be exact) has access though an NFS mount (thanks to UNIX services for Windows). We have an ssh into UNIX to run make and the pipe to output into VS. Accessing the code is fast, builds are a little slower than before, but our longest compile is currently less than two minutes, not a big deal.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Using VS for UNIX development has been worth the effort to set it up, because we now have IntelliSense.   <row Id="19815" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15676" RevisionGUID="8ff9dd6a-15eb-4187-9431-894a166ad28d" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:12:56.247" UserId="200" Text="This is due to how subversion works. Each revision is really a snapshot of the repository identified by that revision number. If all your projects share a repository then it is unavoidable. Typically, in my experience, however you would setup separate repositories for completely unrelated projects. So short answer is no you are doing nothing wrong it is a common question surrounding subversion but it makes sense when you think about how it stores repository information." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="131" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="143" RevisionGUID="dddcf29d-4f27-4433-95d0-64dc9f71980e" CreationDate="2008-08-01T17:01:27.240" UserId="86" Text="As stated in some of the comments: Sometimes you should, sometimes you shouldn't. The great part about private variables is that you are able to see all the places they are used when you change something. If your getter/setter does something you need, use it. If it doesn't matter you decide.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The opposite case could be made that if you use the getter/setter and somebody changes the getter/setter they have to analyze all the places the getter and setter is used internally to see if it messes something up."   <row Id="2997" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2614" RevisionGUID="fd8bc043-1616-4b2c-b878-5ecd72722818" CreationDate="2008-08-05T17:46:00.970" UserId="17" Text="Here is a good way to remember the process that each of them follow that I use when trying to decide which is better for my circumstance.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    DateTime i = (DateTime)value;&#xD;&#xA;    // is like doing&#xD;&#xA;    DateTime i = value is DateTime ? value as DateTime : throw new Exception(...);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;and the next should be easy to guess what it does&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    DateTime i = value as DateTime;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;in the first case if the value cannot be cast than an exception is thrown in the second case if the value cannot be cast, i is set to null.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So in the first case a hard stop is made if the cast fails in the second cast a soft stop is made and you might encounter a NullReferenceException later on." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

For example, you could use {controller}.ashx/{action} and it should work out of the box on IIS 6." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48979" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35933" RevisionGUID="350ac677-7531-4e60-9612-b3aa7f2b89e3" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:31:54.133" UserId="1000" Text="In a client-server setting, if you care about security, you should always program on the assumption that the client may have been compromised. Even if it hasn't, there is always the risk of somebody using an old version of the client, using a competing or modified version of the client, or just of the net connection being a bit screwy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So while you do as much work on the client as possible, processing and marshalling information into the right form, the server then needs to do a thorough sanity check on anything the client gives it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So the answer I guess is &quot;both&quot;." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48980" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35934" RevisionGUID="6705f039-d796-4a7c-bed6-207e6a7526cf" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:33:04.943" UserId="1527" Text="It rather depends how many times you want to do it, and what resources are available - if you're doing the test once, then the O(log N) techniques are good. If you're doing it a thousand times on a server, constructing a bitmap lookup table would be faster, either giving the result directly or as a first stage of. 2GB of bitmap can map the whole world lat-lon to a 32bit value at 0.011 degree pixels (1.2km at equator), and should fit into memory. If you're only doing single country, or can exclude the poles, you can have a smaller map or higher resolution. For 15,000 points you probably have a much smaller map - I first sized it up as a first step to doing lat-lon to postcode searches, which needs higher resolution. Depending on requirements, you use the mapped value to point at the result directly, or to short list of the candidates (which would allow a smaller map, but requires greater subsequent processing - you're not in O(1) lookup territory any more). " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48981" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35936" RevisionGUID="edb68d1c-3ae0-4003-8fc0-61f641f5190d" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:36:24.077" UserId="1233" Text="You could check out the new [UI Automation][1] stuff in .NET 3.5.   <row Id="48982" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35937" RevisionGUID="43942600-21c0-4b18-a5f2-0023a54804b6" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:39:55.253" UserId="3720" Text="Are you using Apache? If so you could have a look at [mod_log_spread][1] Though you may have too big an infrastructure to make it maintainable. The other option is to look at &quot;broadcasting&quot; or &quot;multicasting&quot; your log messages and having dedicated logging servers subscribing to those feeds and collating them&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.schlossnagle.org/~george/mod_log_spread/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48984" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35939" RevisionGUID="032f89fc-c413-4c73-b2ac-ce2204c3dea6" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:49:37.337" UserId="1233" Text="Being an admin, I really appreciate apps that log to the Event Log (preferably their own, otherwise the application log) for all logging but trace logs.  By logging to the event log, you make it much more likely that warnings or errors can be found and addressed by the admin staff before they become a major problem (if it is a issue they can address), or allows them to get in contact with the devs, who can use the trace logs to further troubleshoot the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My biggest pain point in supporting a custom .NET app right now is that there are 8 different applications (some console apps, some winforms, and some web) from the same vendor.  None of them log to the event log, they all have their own custom log files.  But for all the winforms and console apps, they keep the file open while they are running, so I can't monitor it for issues.  Also, the logs are all written slightly differently, so I would have to parse them a bit differently to get useful information.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This forces me to monitor the appearance of an application (is it responding on the ports it is active on, is the process working set getting too high, etc..), rather than what the state of the application really is.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Please, please consider the folks who maintain your application after it is deployed and provide logging they can use. Thanks!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Are they large or small.   <row Id="146" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="158" RevisionGUID="d48c550e-2b1a-49e7-aba6-4b082dff0dc2" CreationDate="2008-08-01T17:51:55.407" UserId="70" Text="Use your httpd log files. Install http://awstats.sourceforge.net/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="147" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="159" RevisionGUID="ecd5cfdc-c31f-46dd-a4c8-fe2d0be331c8" CreationDate="2008-08-01T17:52:46.293" UserId="42" Text="Strictly speaking, a memory leak is consuming memory that is &quot;no longer used&quot; by the program.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;No longer used&quot; has more than one meaning, it could mean &quot;no more reference to it&quot;, that is, totally unrecoverable, or it could mean, referenced, recoverable, unused but the program keeps the references anyway. Only the later applies to .Net for **perfectly managed objects**. However, not all classes are perfect and at some point an underlying unmanaged implementation could leak resources permanently for that process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In all cases, the application consumes more memory than strictly needed. The sides effects, depending on the ammount leaked, could go from none, to slowdown caused by excessive collection, to a series of memory exceptions and finally a fatal error followed by forced process termination.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You know an application has a memory problem when monitoring shows that more and more memory is allocated to your process **after each garbage collection cycle**. In such case, you are either keeping too much in memory, or some underlying unmanaged implementation is leaking.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For most leaks, resources are recovered when the process is terminated, however some resources are not always recovered in some precise cases, GDI cursor handles are notorious for that. Of course, if you have an interprocess communication mechanism, memory allocated in the other process would not be freed until that process frees it or terminates." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19824" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15682" RevisionGUID="372b8695-a811-447f-a725-f7aa89ba451d" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:16:12.247" UserId="307" Text="I store everything in the repository to make it easy for developers (or rebuilt devboxes) to check-out from SVN and then run a build (with all necessary assemblies in relative paths).  If you have multiple projects that should be separate, this would also encourage the team of your shared components to deliver high quality assemblies.  This could follow a normal release to production mentality where the shared assemblied would be updated in your downstream projects.  This is a very natural [Software Value Chain,][1] at the cost of a little bit of disk space.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;JP Boodhoo has [a great series][2] on the topic of automated builds, VS folder structure, and getting developers up and running quickly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.spaconference.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl/ot2004/?KkbagegehhgidslcbhbffcaabcbzencoukKk&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://blog.jpboodhoo.com/AutomatingYourBuildsWithNAntPart1.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19825" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15684" RevisionGUID="f93f3e0c-4ea4-4fa5-9a5c-c1f3bb594a49" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:18:47.623" UserId="1227" Text="I think it is highly recommended that you create separate repositories for each project.  If for nothing else than to avoid the scenario you are talking about.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With version control, especially Subversion, you can easily check out pieces of a repository into another working copy and then commit them back to their respective repositories.  That allows you to keep them clearly separate and distinct while giving you a great deal of flexibility. Once you get into SVN a little more (I'm assuming you are new.) you can start using hooks and I might see where that could get difficult with you setup.  If permission are important to you, a single repository might prove more difficult than necessary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, if you are concerned that it will take a lot of time to setup each repository look into the SVNParentPath variable for the Apache configuration file. (Again, I'm assuming you are using Apache.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39337" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29307" RevisionGUID="10d24ef9-379a-4065-8298-19ce84e8659f" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:20:26.250" UserId="3087" Text="I think there is a great misunderstanding about the use of the Singleton pattern. Most of the comments here refer to it as a place to access global data. We need to be careful here - Singleton as a pattern is **not** for accessing globals. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Singleton should be used to have **only one instance** of the given class. [Pattern Repository][1] has great information on [Singleton][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.netobjectivesrepository.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.netobjectivesrepository.com/TheSingletonPattern" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39342" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="22573" RevisionGUID="855e4d19-7232-40e3-952f-53c95b4a8a3c" CreationDate="2008-08-22T14:54:22.857" UserId="430" Text="    opendir(D, &quot;/path/to/directory&quot;) || die &quot;Can't opedir: $!\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    while (my $f = readdir(D)) {&#xD;&#xA;      print &quot;\$f = $f\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    closedir(D);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT: Oh, sorry, missed the &quot;into an array&quot; part:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    my $d = shift;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    opendir(D, &quot;$d&quot;) || die &quot;Can't opedir $d: $!\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    my @list = readdir(D);&#xD;&#xA;    closedir(D);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    foreach my $f (@list) {&#xD;&#xA;      print &quot;\$f = $f\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39343" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="22573" RevisionGUID="37dc9fdf-3a64-4928-aa03-ea9bb6105151" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:20:55.330" UserId="430" Comment="comment on another post and document a couple of common usage idioms" Text="    opendir(D, &quot;/path/to/directory&quot;) || die &quot;Can't opedir: $!\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    while (my $f = readdir(D)) {&#xD;&#xA;      print &quot;\$f = $f\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    closedir(D);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT: Oh, sorry, missed the &quot;into an array&quot; part:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    my $d = shift;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    opendir(D, &quot;$d&quot;) || die &quot;Can't opedir $d: $!\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    my @list = readdir(D);&#xD;&#xA;    closedir(D);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    foreach my $f (@list) {&#xD;&#xA;      print &quot;\$f = $f\n&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT2: Most of the other answers are valid, but I wanted to comment on [this answer][1] specifically, in which this solution is offered:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    opendir(DIR, $somedir) || die &quot;can't opendir $somedir: $!&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    @dots = grep { (!/^\./) &amp;&amp; -f &quot;$somedir/$_&quot; } readdir(DIR);&#xD;&#xA;    closedir DIR;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, to document what it's doing since the poster didn't, it's passing the returned list from readdir() through a grep() that only returns those values that are files (as opposed to dirs, devices, named pipes, etc) and that do not begin with a dot (which makes the list name @dots misleading, but that's due to the change he made when copying it over from the readdir() documentation).  Since it limits the contents of the directory it returns I don't think it's technically a correct answer to this question, but it illustrates a common idiom used to filter filenames in perl and I thought it would be valuable to document.  Another example seen a lot is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    @list = grep !/^\.\.?$/, readdir(D);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This snippet reads all contents from the dir handle D **except** '.' and '..', since those are very rarely desired to be used in the listing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22566/how-do-i-read-in-the-contents-of-a-directory-in-perl#24436" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="48989" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="35943" RevisionGUID="eae64e5f-df49-4256-95d1-bcb445ae3f0b" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:08:07.697" UserId="1384652" Text="Logging in a PHP webapp" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48996" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="35948" RevisionGUID="6164cc24-42c5-4715-8e80-ef1fac27e254" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:20:02.740" UserId="3117" Text="|python|django|google-app-engine|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="48999" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="34780" RevisionGUID="4da8d7f6-e4dd-499a-b62d-52ae0d1b4b4c" CreationDate="2008-08-29T17:16:45.690" UserId="2509" Text="If the OP is asking about idomatic sorting expressions, then not all languages have a *natural* expression built in. For c I'd go to `&lt;stdlib.h&gt;` and use `qsort`. Something on the lines of :&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdio.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;string.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    int main(int argc, char **argv){&#xD;&#xA;      /* Sort the command line arguments in place */&#xD;&#xA;      qsort(argv[1],argc-1,sizeof(char *),(int(*)(const void*, const void*)strcmp);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;      /* Print the same */&#xD;&#xA;      while(--argc){&#xD;&#xA;        printf(&quot;%s\n&quot;,(++argv)[0]);&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;to sort the arguments into lexical order. Unfortunately this idiom is rather hard to parse for those not used the ways of c.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49000" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="34780" RevisionGUID="560f3481-e446-47c5-85c9-1abac823ad3b" CreationDate="2008-08-30T00:02:18.490" UserId="2509" Comment="Actaully answer the question. Remove broken code." Text="If the OP is asking about idomatic sorting expressions, then not all languages have a *natural* expression built in. For c I'd go to `&lt;stdlib.h&gt;` and use `qsort`. Something on the lines of :&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    /* non-functional mess deleted */&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;to sort the arguments into lexical order. Unfortunately this idiom is rather hard to parse for those not used the ways of c.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Suitably chastened by the downvote, I actually read the linked article. Mea culpa.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In anycase the original code did not work, except in the single case I tested. Damn. Plain vanilla c does not have this function, nor is it in any of the usual libraries. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The code below sorts the command line arguments in the **natural** way as linked. *Caveat emptor* as it is only lightly tested.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdio.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;string.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;ctype.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int naturalstrcmp(const char **s1, const char **s2);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int main(int argc, char **argv){&#xD;&#xA;      /* Sort the command line arguments in place */&#xD;&#xA;      qsort(&amp;argv[1],argc-1,sizeof(char*),&#xD;&#xA;    	(int(*)(const void *, const void *))naturalstrcmp);&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      while(--argc){&#xD;&#xA;        printf(&quot;%s\n&quot;,(++argv)[0]);&#xD;&#xA;      };&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int naturalstrcmp(const char **s1p, const char **s2p){&#xD;&#xA;      if ((NULL == s1p) || (NULL == *s1p)) {&#xD;&#xA;        if ((NULL == s2p) || (NULL == *s2p)) return 0;&#xD;&#xA;        return 1;&#xD;&#xA;      };&#xD;&#xA;      if ((NULL == s2p) || (NULL == *s2p)) return -1;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;      const char *s1=*s1p;&#xD;&#xA;      const char *s2=*s2p;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;      do {&#xD;&#xA;        if (isdigit(s1[0]) &amp;&amp; isdigit(s2[0])){ &#xD;&#xA;          /* Compare numbers as numbers */&#xD;&#xA;          int c1 = strspn(s1,&quot;0123456789&quot;); /* Could be more efficient here... */&#xD;&#xA;          int c2 = strspn(s2,&quot;0123456789&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;          if (c1 &gt; c2) {&#xD;&#xA;    	return 1;&#xD;&#xA;          } else if (c1 &lt; c2) {&#xD;&#xA;    	return -1;&#xD;&#xA;          };&#xD;&#xA;          /* the digit strings have equal length, so compare digit by digit */&#xD;&#xA;          while (c1--) {&#xD;&#xA;    	if (s1[0] &gt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;    	  return 1;&#xD;&#xA;    	} else if (s1[0] &lt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;    	  return -1;&#xD;&#xA;    	}; &#xD;&#xA;    	s1++;&#xD;&#xA;    	s2++;&#xD;&#xA;          };&#xD;&#xA;        } else if (s1[0] &gt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;          return 1;&#xD;&#xA;        } else if (s1[0] &lt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;          return -1;&#xD;&#xA;        }; &#xD;&#xA;        s1++;&#xD;&#xA;        s2++;&#xD;&#xA;      } while ( (s1!='\0') || (s2!='\0') );&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This approach is pretty brute force, but it is simple and can probably be duplicated in any imperative language." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="3022" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2471" RevisionGUID="ecaf3aba-85f9-489b-8f59-253f5407b9f8" CreationDate="2008-08-05T15:30:30.353" UserId="72" Text="A VirtualHost would also work for this and may work better for you as you can host several projects without the need for subdirectories.  Here's how you do it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;httpd.conf:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    NameVirtualHost *:80&#xD;&#xA;    # ...&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;VirtualHost *:80&gt;  &#xD;&#xA;        DocumentRoot C:\projects\transitCalculator\trunk\&#xD;&#xA;        ServerName transitcalculator.localhost&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;Directory C:\projects\transitCalculator\trunk\&gt;  &#xD;&#xA;            Order allow,deny  &#xD;&#xA;            Allow from all  &#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/Directory&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/VirtualHost&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;HOSTS file (c:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts usually):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # localhost entries&#xD;&#xA;    127.0.0.1 localhost transitcalculator.localhost&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now restart XAMPP and you should be able to access http://transitcalculator.localhost/ and it will map straight to that directory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This can be helpful if you're trying to replicate a production environment where you're developing a site that will sit on the root of a domain name.  You can, for example, point to files with absolute paths that will carry over to the server:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;img src=&quot;/images/logo.png&quot; alt=&quot;My Logo&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;whereas in an environment using aliases or subdirectories, you'd need keep track of exactly where the &quot;images&quot; directory was relative to the current file." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="3023" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="2471" RevisionGUID="9db8e3ac-843a-482d-b373-d8d73e4e15c0" CreationDate="2008-08-05T18:06:20.883" UserId="58" Text="A VirtualHost would also work for this and may work better for you as you can host several projects without the need for subdirectories.  Here's how you do it:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;httpd.conf (or extra\httpd-vhosts.conf relative to httpd.conf. Trailing slashes &quot;\&quot; might cause it not to work):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    NameVirtualHost *:80&#xD;&#xA;    # ...&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;VirtualHost *:80&gt;  &#xD;&#xA;        DocumentRoot C:\projects\transitCalculator\trunk\&#xD;&#xA;        ServerName transitcalculator.localhost&#xD;&#xA;        &lt;Directory C:\projects\transitCalculator\trunk\&gt;  &#xD;&#xA;            Order allow,deny  &#xD;&#xA;            Allow from all  &#xD;&#xA;        &lt;/Directory&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/VirtualHost&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;HOSTS file (c:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts usually):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # localhost entries&#xD;&#xA;    127.0.0.1 localhost transitcalculator.localhost&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now restart XAMPP and you should be able to access http://transitcalculator.localhost/ and it will map straight to that directory.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This can be helpful if you're trying to replicate a production environment where you're developing a site that will sit on the root of a domain name.  You can, for example, point to files with absolute paths that will carry over to the server:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;img src=&quot;/images/logo.png&quot; alt=&quot;My Logo&quot; /&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;whereas in an environment using aliases or subdirectories, you'd need keep track of exactly where the &quot;images&quot; directory was relative to the current file." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39357" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29315" RevisionGUID="012f795c-c33b-4c2e-bdbf-e5825cf41cc2" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:25:42.137" UserId="2988" Text="For more than you ever wanted to know about `sort`, read the [specification of `sort`][1] in the [Single Unix Specification v3][2]. It states&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Comparisons [...] shall be performed using the collating sequence of the current locale.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IOW, how `sort` sorts is dependent on the locale (language) settings of the environment that the script is running under.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://OpenGroup.Org/onlinepubs/009695399/utilities/sort.html &quot;sort&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://OpenGroup.Org/onlinepubs/009695399/ &quot;Single Unix Specification v3&quot;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39359" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29317" RevisionGUID="0a1de092-c2c5-4a75-96a0-c1ad46bd16f2" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:27:22.630" UserId="522" Text="Agree with Orion Edwards, pretty much everything new can.   <row Id="39360" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29318" RevisionGUID="bb06ab73-0cb4-44e1-917d-3dddba43c0a4" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:27:23.910" UserId="726" Text="I haven't used Oracle's table clusters myself, but I understand that its index table clusters are very much like MS SQL Server's clustered indexes. That is, the row data is physically organized by the clustered index's key.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That makes one ideal for a heavily-accessed column that has a reasonably small number of possible values (compared to the total number of rows), where most queries want to retrieve all rows with a particular value. Because all such rows are physically stored together, disk I/O, particularly seek time, is reduced.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&quot;Reasonably small&quot; is not easily defined, but postal or zip codes in an address table seems reasonable if you're often querying for all addresses in a single code's region. Province/state/territory codes are likely too small a selection for a country-wide address table.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So, you don't want to use them on columns with few possible values (e.g., M/F for gender) because then the clustering doesn't buy you anything and likely costs you for insertions. You also never want to use clustering on &quot;autonumber&quot; surrogate key columns (from sequences in Oracle) because that will create a &quot;hot spot&quot; in the last extent of the table as all insertions must physically happen there. You also don't want to apply clustering to a column value that will be updated because the RDBMS will have to physically move the record to maintain the clustered ordering." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19841" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15697" RevisionGUID="87780ea1-5ef7-4e94-a31c-5379f01748d9" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:30:35.897" UserId="1043" Text="I'd suggest you pick a fun little product and dive in. If you're looking for a book I'd suggest [Cocoa Programming for Max OSX][1] which is a very good introduction both to Objective-C and Cocoa.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;XCode is pretty much the de facto IDE and free with OSX. It should be on your original install DVD. It's good but not as good as Visual Studio (sorry, it's really not). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As a long-time VS user I found the default XCode config a little odd and hard to adjust to, particularly the way a new floating window would open for every sourcefile. Some tweaks I found particularly helpful;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Settings/General -&gt; All-In-One (unifies editor/debugger window)&#xD;&#xA;  - Settings/General -&gt; Open counterparts in same editor (single-window edit)&#xD;&#xA;  - Settings/Debugging - &quot;In Editor Debugger Controls&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  - Settings/Debugging - &quot;Auto Clear Debug Console&quot;&#xD;&#xA;  - Settings/Key-binding - lots of binding to match VS (Ctrl+F5/Shift+F5,Shift+Home, Shift+End etc)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I find the debugger has some annoying issues such as breakpoints not correctly mapping to lines and exceptions aren't immediately trapped by the debugger. Nothing deal-breaking but a bit cumbersome.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would recommend that you make use of the new property syntax that was introduced for Objective-C 2.0. They make for a heck of a lot less typing in many many places. They're limited to OSX 10.5 only though (yeah, language features are tied to OS versions which is a bit odd). &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also don't be fooled into downplaying the differences between C/C++ and Objective-C. They're very much related but ARE different languages. Try and start Objective-C without thinking about how you'd do X,Y,Z in C/C++. It'll make it a lot easier.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0321503619?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=shinthin-20&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;creativeASIN=0321503619" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19842" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15698" RevisionGUID="b3dd6770-c73c-4dfd-b36a-a622ebb6d5f9" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:31:27.770" UserId="658" Text="Before you start coding, plan out your database schema - everything else will flow from that. Getting the database reasonably correct early on will save you time and headaches later." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19843" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15699" RevisionGUID="51b2b0ef-3e93-451f-871d-0290aadde426" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:32:12.243" UserId="493" Text="I don't know if this is the right way to do it but you could add a prebuild event to your startup projcet (if it's static) to clean the project which will force a rebuild.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    devenv project.csproj /clean&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19845" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15702" RevisionGUID="69182cab-4d46-4c3e-8063-c1bae3b8ad1d" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:32:30.200" UserId="307" Text="Do you know much about OOP?  If so, look into Spring and Hibernate to keep your implementation clean and [orthagonal][1].  If you get that, you should find TDD a good way to keep your design compact and lean, especially since you have &quot;automated testing&quot; up and running.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;UPDATE:&#xD;&#xA;Looking at the first slew of answers, I couldn't disagree more.  Particularly in the Java space, you should find plenty of mentors/resources on working out your application with Objects, **not a database-centric approach**.  Database design is typically the first step for Microsoft folks (which I do daily, but am in a recovery program, er, Alt.Net).  If you keep the focus on what you need to deliver to a customer and let your ORM figure out how to persist your objects, your design should be better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://codebetter.com/blogs/jeremy.miller/archive/2007/01/08/Orthogonal-Code.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49001" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="34780" RevisionGUID="996f357a-843a-4acd-8abd-e8af92538d48" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:23:50.827" UserId="2509" Comment="Found and fixed bug" Text="If the OP is asking about idomatic sorting expressions, then not all languages have a *natural* expression built in. For c I'd go to `&lt;stdlib.h&gt;` and use `qsort`. Something on the lines of :&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    /* non-functional mess deleted */&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;to sort the arguments into lexical order. Unfortunately this idiom is rather hard to parse for those not used the ways of c.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;*Suitably chastened by the downvote, I actually read the linked article. Mea culpa.*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In anycase the original code did not work, except in the single case I tested. Damn. Plain vanilla c does not have this function, nor is it in any of the usual libraries. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The code below sorts the command line arguments in the **natural** way as linked. *Caveat emptor* as it is only lightly tested.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdio.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;string.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    #include &lt;ctype.h&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int naturalstrcmp(const char **s1, const char **s2);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int main(int argc, char **argv){&#xD;&#xA;      /* Sort the command line arguments in place */&#xD;&#xA;      qsort(&amp;argv[1],argc-1,sizeof(char*),&#xD;&#xA;    	(int(*)(const void *, const void *))naturalstrcmp);&#xD;&#xA;      &#xD;&#xA;      while(--argc){&#xD;&#xA;        printf(&quot;%s\n&quot;,(++argv)[0]);&#xD;&#xA;      };&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    int naturalstrcmp(const char **s1p, const char **s2p){&#xD;&#xA;      if ((NULL == s1p) || (NULL == *s1p)) {&#xD;&#xA;        if ((NULL == s2p) || (NULL == *s2p)) return 0;&#xD;&#xA;        return 1;&#xD;&#xA;      };&#xD;&#xA;      if ((NULL == s2p) || (NULL == *s2p)) return -1;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;      const char *s1=*s1p;&#xD;&#xA;      const char *s2=*s2p;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;      do {&#xD;&#xA;        if (isdigit(s1[0]) &amp;&amp; isdigit(s2[0])){ &#xD;&#xA;          /* Compare numbers as numbers */&#xD;&#xA;          int c1 = strspn(s1,&quot;0123456789&quot;); /* Could be more efficient here... */&#xD;&#xA;          int c2 = strspn(s2,&quot;0123456789&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;          if (c1 &gt; c2) {&#xD;&#xA;    	return 1;&#xD;&#xA;          } else if (c1 &lt; c2) {&#xD;&#xA;    	return -1;&#xD;&#xA;          };&#xD;&#xA;          /* the digit strings have equal length, so compare digit by digit */&#xD;&#xA;          while (c1--) {&#xD;&#xA;    	if (s1[0] &gt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;    	  return 1;&#xD;&#xA;    	} else if (s1[0] &lt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;    	  return -1;&#xD;&#xA;    	}; &#xD;&#xA;    	s1++;&#xD;&#xA;    	s2++;&#xD;&#xA;          };&#xD;&#xA;        } else if (s1[0] &gt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;          return 1;&#xD;&#xA;        } else if (s1[0] &lt; s2[0]){&#xD;&#xA;          return -1;&#xD;&#xA;        }; &#xD;&#xA;        s1++;&#xD;&#xA;        s2++;&#xD;&#xA;      } while ( (s1!='\0') || (s2!='\0') );&#xD;&#xA;      return 0;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This approach is pretty brute force, but it is simple and can probably be duplicated in any imperative language." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

However, I haven't seen an example of a full-text search that has three table joins like this, especially since my join condition is not part of the search term.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there a way to do this in full-text search?"   <row Id="148" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="160" RevisionGUID="b4040656-eae1-48fc-8840-38674df69da0" CreationDate="2008-08-01T17:54:08.163" UserId="17" Text="The best way that I have found is the [MySQL Migration Toolkit][1] provided by MySQL.  I have used it successfully for some large migration projects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.mysql.com/products/tools/migration-toolkit/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="149" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="161" RevisionGUID="8f613b6e-de21-4f92-87b2-b01a7610e99c" CreationDate="2008-08-01T17:57:14.117" UserId="33" Text="I would define memory leaks as an object not freeing up all the memory allocated after it has completed. I have found this can happen in your application if you are using Windows API and COM (i.e. unmanaged code that has a bug in it or is not being managed correctly), in the framework and in third party components. I have also found not tiding up after using certain objects like pens can cause the issue.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I personally have suffered Out of Memory Exceptions which can be caused but are not exclusive to memory leaks in dot net applications. (OOM can also come from pinning see [Pinning Artical][1]). If you are not getting OOM errors or need to confirm if it is a memory leak causing it then the only way is to profile your application.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would also try and ensure the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;a) Everything that implements Idisposable is disposed either using a finally block or the using statement these include brushes, pens etc.(some people argue to set everything to nothing in addition) &#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;b)Anything that has a close method is closed again using finally or the using statement (although I have found using does not always close depending if you declared the object outside the using statement)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;c)If you are using unmanaged code/windows API's that these are dealt with correctly after. (some have clean up methods to release resources)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hope this helps.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: https://blogs.msdn.com/yunjin/archive/2004/01/27/63642.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/839047/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="151" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="165" RevisionGUID="d604d7ef-389b-4fb6-b185-0b7d9192c3c9" CreationDate="2008-08-01T18:04:25.023" UserDisplayName="user2189331" Text="You can use a [3rd-party library such as SharpZip](http://sharpdevelop.net/OpenSource/SharpZipLib/) as Tom pointed out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another way (without going 3rd-party) is to use the Windows Shell API. You'll need to set a reference to the Microsoft Shell Controls and Automation COM library in your C# project. Gerald Gibson has an example at:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;http://geraldgibson.net/dnn/Home/CZipFileCompression/tabid/148/Default.aspx&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="156" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="169" RevisionGUID="5e830776-1343-4ae9-9b6a-79188cb93461" CreationDate="2008-08-01T18:23:59.040" UserId="93" Text="Personally, I feel like it's important to remain consistent.  If you have getters and setters, use them.  The only time I would access a field directly is when the accessor has a lot of overhead.  It may feel like you're bloating your code unnecessarily, but it can certainly save a whole lot of headache in the future.  The classic example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Later on, you may desire to change the way that field works.  Maybe it should be calculated on-the-fly or maybe you would like to use a different type for the backing store.  If you are accessing properties directly, a change like that can break an awful lot of code in one swell foop." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54758" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="39525" RevisionGUID="eff21e54-8f25-4827-8072-7f0369bb782d" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:36:26.543" UserId="3832" Text="Error handling / error logging in C++ for library/app combo" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54759" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="39525" RevisionGUID="eff21e54-8f25-4827-8072-7f0369bb782d" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:36:26.543" UserId="3832" Text="|c++|api|error-handling|error-logging|api-design|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54760" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39525" RevisionGUID="eff21e54-8f25-4827-8072-7f0369bb782d" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:36:26.543" UserId="3832" Text="I've encountered the following problem pattern frequently over the years:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* I'm writing complex code for a package comprised of a standalone application and also a library version of the core that people can use from inside other apps.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Both our own app and presumably ones that users create with the core library are likely to be run both in batch mode (off-line, scripted, remote, and/or from command line), as well as interactively.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* The library/app takes complex and large runtime input and there may be a variety of error-like outputs including severe error messages, input syntax warnings, status messages, and run statistics.  Note that these are all *incidental* outputs, not the primary purpose of the application which would be displayed or saved elsewhere and using different methods.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Some of these (probably only the very severe ones) might require a dialog box if run interactively; but it needs to log without stalling for user input if run in batch mode; and if run as a library the client program obviously wants to intercept and/or examine the errors as they occur.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* It all needs to be cross-platform: Linux, Windows, OSX.  And we want the solution to not be weird on any platform.  For example, output to stderr is fine for Linux, but won't work on Windows when linked to a GUI app.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Client programs of the library may create multiple instances of the main class, and it would be nice if the client app could distinguish a separate error stream with each instance.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Let's assume everybody agrees it's good enough for the library methods to log errors via a simple call (error code and/or severity, then printf-like arguments giving an error message).  The contentious part is how this is recorded or retrieved by the client app.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've done this many times over the years, and am never fully satisfied with the solution.  Furthermore, it's the kind of subproblem that's actually not very important to users (they want to see the error log if something goes wrong, but they don't really care about our technique for implementing it), but the topic gets the programmers fired up and they invariably waste inordinate time on this detail and are never quite happy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Anybody have any wisdom for how to integrate this functionality into a C++ API, or is there an accepted paradigm or a good open source solution (not GPL, please, I'd like a solution I can use in commercial closed apps as well as OSS projects)?&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19849" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15703" RevisionGUID="27dbbbfb-6dce-4552-9701-01521b6383c8" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:34:48.277" UserId="486" Text="[AngelScript](http://www.angelcode.com/angelscript/) &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; lets you call standard C functions and C++ methods with no need for proxy functions. The application simply registers the functions, objects, and methods that the scripts should be able to work with and nothing more has to be done with your code. The same functions used by the application internally can also be used by the scripting engine, which eliminates the need to duplicate functionality.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; For the script writer the scripting language follows the widely known syntax of C/C++ (with minor changes), but without the need to worry about pointers and memory leaks. " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19857" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15710" RevisionGUID="f6b3d773-0d47-4c43-9403-cf4188a827f2" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:39:11.963" UserId="372" Text="I do it the other way around. I find that doing it database-schema-first gets the system stuck in a data-driven-design that is difficult to abstract from persistence. We try to do domain model designs first *and then* base the database schema on those.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And then there's the infrastructure design: the team should settle on conventions on how to structure the program first and foremost. And then we work together to agree first on a design for the common functionality of the system (e.g., things everyone needs like persistence, logging, etc.). This becomes the framework of the system.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We all work on that together first before we split the rest of the functionalities amongst ourselves." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19858" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15711" RevisionGUID="57ca2b9b-edc5-4bca-a03d-57851f04f869" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:39:21.107" UserId="611" Text="Add a [pre-commit hook][1] which parses the file content and performs the munging of CRLF/LF/CR/etc for you before it's written to SVN.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://wordaligned.org/articles/a-subversion-pre-commit-hook" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19860" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15713" RevisionGUID="34b39e98-c375-4bce-b624-542ef7973097" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:40:13.680" UserId="615" Text="If you right-click on your &quot;Computer&quot; (or &quot;My Computer&quot;) icon and select &quot;Manage&quot; from the pop-up menu, that'll take you to the Computer Management console.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In there, under System Tools\Shared Folders, you'll find &quot;Open Files&quot;. This is probably close to what you want, but if the file is on a network share then you'd need to do the same thing on the server on which the file lives." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49008" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35955" RevisionGUID="cd0d64e0-a012-4490-859f-caad1ee24bba" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:31:42.163" UserId="3738" Text="I *think* that an unordered_map and hash_map are more or less the same thing. The difference is that the STL doesn't officially have a hash_map (what you're using is probably a compiler specific thing), so unordered_map is the fix for that omission.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;unordered_map is just that... unordered. You can't depend on it preserving any ordering on iteration.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

First, Last, Middle names&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So say I have 3 rows with the following info.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1 - Phillip - J - Fry&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2 - Amy - NULL - Wong&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3 - Leo - NULL - Wong&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the user enters a name such as 'Fry' it will return row 1. However if they enter Phillip Fry, or Fr, or Phil they get nothing.. and I don't understand why its doing this. If they search for Wong they get rows 2 and 3 if they search for Amy Wong they again get nothing.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Currently the query is using CONTAINSTABLE but I have switched that with FREETEXTTABLE, CONTAINS, and FREETEXT without any noticeable differences in the results. The table methods are be preferred because they return the same results but with ranking.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is the query.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ....&#xD;&#xA;    @Name nvarchar(100),&#xD;&#xA;    ....&#xD;&#xA;    --&quot;&quot;s added to prevent crash if searching on more then one word.&#xD;&#xA;    DECLARE @SearchString varchar(100)&#xD;&#xA;    SET @SearchString = '&quot;'+@Name+'&quot;'&#xD;&#xA;    SELECT Per.Lastname, Per.Firstname, Per.MiddleName&#xD;&#xA;    FROM Person as Per&#xD;&#xA;    INNER JOIN CONTAINSTABLE(Person, (LastName, Firstname, MiddleName), @SearchString) &#xD;&#xA;    AS KEYTBL&#xD;&#xA;    ON Per.Person_ID = KEYTBL.[KEY]&#xD;&#xA;    WHERE KEY_TBL.RANK &gt; 2&#xD;&#xA;    ORDER BY KEYTBL.RANK DESC;  &#xD;&#xA;    ....&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any Ideas why this full text search is not working correctly?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49021" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35960" RevisionGUID="89e7f5ff-3376-4660-94fc-e8736c684a99" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:47:51.220" UserId="2199" Text="I can think of a couple of reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - A modicum of security by obscurity - it's slightly more work to tamper with POST submissions than GET&#xD;&#xA;  - Caching and resubmit rules are more restrictive for POST than GET. I'm not entirely sure this would matter for the OpenID use case, though.&#xD;&#xA;  - Bots wouldn't follow the POST form, but would follow the redirect. This could impact server load. &#xD;&#xA;  - Different browsers have different max lengths for GET requests - but none of them are as large as POST.&#xD;&#xA;  - Some browsers will warn on redirect to another domain. They'll also warn if you're submitting POST to a non-HTTPS url.&#xD;&#xA;  - By turning JavaScript off, I can have a relatively secure experience, and not be silently redirected to another domain.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I don't know that any of these are a slam-dunk reason to choose POST - unless the amount of data being sent exceeds the querystring length for some major browser." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54761" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39526" RevisionGUID="b8dc408f-d78e-410b-a262-f3f72e709690" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:36:33.547" UserId="1965" Text="&gt;I don't use VS2008 for C++, only VB &amp; C#, but I find that when intellisense stops working (true for VS2003/2005/2008) it's because something in the project/file is broken - usually a bad reference or code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;VB and C# have much better intellisense support due to the ability to reflect on the referenced assemblies to build the intellisense tree.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;C++ has to walk the include files for function prototypes, and if the paths are not correct it will not find all the prototype headers.&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54767" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="34194" RevisionGUID="df6f93fc-dab9-4ff4-9e05-1dc3c937b54f" CreationDate="2008-08-30T12:08:08.747" UserId="2429" Comment="Updated the question to clarify" Text="Where can I find some good pointers on best practices for running ASP.NET MVC on IIS6?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I haven't seen any realistic options for web-hosts who provide IIS7-hosting yet. Mostly because I don't live in the U.S.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So I was wondering on how you best build applications in ASP.NET MVC and make it easily available to deploy on both IIS6 and IIS7. Keep in mind that this is for standard web-hosts, so there is no access to ISAPI-filters or special settings inside IIS6.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are there anything else one should think about when developing ASP.NET MVC-applications to target IIS6? Any functions that doesn't work?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;UPDATE: One of the bigger issues is the thing with routes. The pattern {controller}/{action} will work on IIS7, but not IIS6 which needs {controller}.mvc/{action}. So how do I make this transparent? Again, **no ISAPI** and **no IIS-settings**, please." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54770" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39529" RevisionGUID="b968074a-b381-4a88-8537-32684f3a6db6" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:37:56.477" UserId="3743" Text="Your logic seems sound, but you might want to consider adding some code to prevent the insert if you had passed in a specific primary key.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Otherwise, if you're always doing an insert if the update didn't affect any records, what happens when someone deletes the record before you &quot;UPSERT&quot; runs?  Now the record you were trying to update doesn't exist, so it'll create a record instead.  That probably isn't the behavior you were looking for.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;-- Kevin Fairchild" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19862" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15715" RevisionGUID="e15ad607-02b5-4a69-946c-8143aed90c97" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:41:58.247" UserId="1886" Text="@lomaxx I also learned the other day (the same time I learned your tip) is that you can now have disparate access levels on the same property:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public string Name { get; private set;}&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That way only the class itself can set the Name property.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public Name(string name) { Name = name; }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19863" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15717" RevisionGUID="c2d06766-bf3b-4b53-91b5-6d14966f5371" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:44:46.087" UserId="615" Text="Just so I'm clear, you've done something like this, right?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public ListView MyListView { get { return this.listView1; } }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So then you are accessing (at design time) the MyListView property on your UserControl?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think if you want proper design-time support you're better off changing the &quot;Modifier&quot; property on the ListView itself (back on the original UserControl) to Public - that way you can modify the ListView directly on instances of the UserControl.   <row Id="19871" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15726" RevisionGUID="8a68c324-4e60-4c8d-be9c-ad10564853f1" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:52:38.520" UserId="1265" Text="Partially. YAML supports the notion of multiple consecutive &quot;documents&quot;. If this is what you are trying to do here, then yes, it is correct - you have two documents (or document fragments). To make it more explicit, you should separate them with three dashes, like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    ---&#xD;&#xA;    heading:&#xD;&#xA;     name: A name&#xD;&#xA;     taco: Yes&#xD;&#xA;     age: 32&#xD;&#xA;    ---&#xD;&#xA;    heading:&#xD;&#xA;     name: Another name&#xD;&#xA;     taco: No&#xD;&#xA;     age: 27&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand if you wish to make them part of the same document (so that deserializing them would result in a list with two elements), you should write it like the following. Take extra care with the indentation level:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    - heading:&#xD;&#xA;      name: A name&#xD;&#xA;      taco: Yes&#xD;&#xA;      age: 32&#xD;&#xA;    - heading:&#xD;&#xA;      name: Another name&#xD;&#xA;      taco: No&#xD;&#xA;      age: 27&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In general YAML is concise and human readable / editable, but not really human writable, so you should always use libraries to generate it. Also, take care that there exists some breaking changes between different versions of YAML, which can bite you if you are using libraries in different languages which conform to different versions of the standard." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49022" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35961" RevisionGUID="9ce00531-4c6d-488f-bbf0-82d30fc35edc" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:49:27.973" UserDisplayName="David Sheeks" Text="You will almost certainly want to use a database for flexible, record based access and to take advantage of the database's ability to handle concurrent data access. If you need to track information that may need to be undone, having it in a structured format is a benefit, as is having the ability to update a row indicating when and by whom a given transaction has been undone. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You likely only want to write to a file if very high performance is an issue, or if you have very unstructured or large amounts of data per record that might be unweidly to store in a database. Note that Unless your application has a very large number of transactions database speed is unlikely to be an issue. Also note that if you are working with a file you'll need to handle concurrent access (read / write / locking) very carefully which is likely not something you want to have to deal with." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49025" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35965" RevisionGUID="f342452c-d4e7-4478-9e71-32e6bb8e06f6" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:53:56.120" UserId="3186" Text="[Boost documentation of unordered containers][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The difference is in the method of how you generate the look up.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the map/set containers the `operator&lt;` is used to generate an ordered tree.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the unordered containers, an `operator( key ) =&gt; index` is used.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See hashing for a description of how that works.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_36_0/doc/html/unordered.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

SGI STL implements it, however GNU g++ doesn't have it (it's located in the __gnu_cxx namespace) as of 4.3.1 anyway. As far as I know, hash_map has always been non-standard, and now tr1 is fixing that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49027" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35967" RevisionGUID="16ccca51-6484-45b0-814d-c31c4ecae9be" CreationDate="2008-08-30T13:57:37.530" UserId="3736" Text="It all depends on your skill level and how much load you are getting on your servers.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you have spare (physical) resources and have the technical skills and experience to maintain production machines running different operating systems, I'd recommend going running lighttpd on either Linux or FreeBSD. A light OS install with a static file optimized server will perform faster than Apache or IIS on a heavy OS.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, unless you are extremely comfortable with these solutions, just stick to IIS on Windows. Move the static files to their own machine if you have sufficient load. If you aren't currently thinking about multiple ASP.Net frontends, there's probably no need to spin off the static files yet unless we're talking multiple gigabytes of files."   <row Id="49034" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35969" RevisionGUID="8d062986-1d96-4add-958e-a51e33c72392" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:02:52.073" UserId="3657" Text="In C++ I use this [example code][1] to do natural sorting.
