  <row Id="49035" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35690" RevisionGUID="13d8ef8a-ad51-4196-9af3-29e62b013cd7" CreationDate="2008-08-30T05:01:59.847" UserId="3153" Text="I have tried both methods with a large commercial C++ application. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**The better method: The trunk should be always stable.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some guidelines and benefits of this method:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Code each task (or related set of tasks) in its own branch, then you will have the flexibility of when you would like to merge these tasks and perform a release.  &#xD;&#xA;  - QA should be done on each branch before it is merged to the trunk. &#xD;&#xA;  - By doing QA on each individual branch, you will know exactly what caused the bug easier.&#xD;&#xA;  - This solution scales to any number of developers.  &#xD;&#xA;  - This method works since branching is an almost instant operation in SVN.&#xD;&#xA;  - Tag each release that you perform.&#xD;&#xA;  - You can develop features that you don't plan to release for a while and decide exactly when to merge them.  &#xD;&#xA;  - For all work you do, you can have the benefit of committing your code.  If you work out of the trunk only, you will probably keep your code uncommitted a lot, and hence unprotected and without automatic history. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you try to do the opposite and do all your development in the trunk you'll be plagged by:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Constant build problems for daily builds&#xD;&#xA;  - Productivity loss when a a developer commits a problem for all other people on the project&#xD;&#xA;  - Longer release cycles, because you need to finally get a stable version&#xD;&#xA;  - Less stable releases&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You simply will not have the flexibility that you need if you try to keep a branch stable and the trunk as the development sandbox.  The reason is that you can't pick and chose from the trunk what you want to put in that stable release.  It would already be all mixed in together in the trunk." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60816" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43520" RevisionGUID="d29877d4-e965-4fa9-b60c-45420a962008" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:31:49.617" UserId="383" Text="For 3.5, you must install this tool:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=4377f86d-c913-4b5c-b87e-ef72e5b4e065&amp;displaylang=en][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And for 3.0 you must use the 2.0 config tool.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Source of Answer][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=4377f86d-c913-4b5c-b87e-ef72e5b4e065&amp;displaylang=en&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://forums.msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/netfxsetup/thread/9aa72b12-3b63-493b-a7d2-596775bd66ea/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60820" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43522" RevisionGUID="97c6cc39-ad61-49fb-8764-cda41db40aab" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:33:18.600" UserId="2084" Text="Yes, you can use the sealed keyword in the B class's implementation of Render:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    class B : A&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        public sealed override void Render()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            // Prepare the object for rendering&#xD;&#xA;            SpecialRender();&#xD;&#xA;            // Do some cleanup&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        protected virtual void SpecialRender()&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60824" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43507" RevisionGUID="4be19d39-a891-4f04-8ff6-978956a17b04" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:23:13.103" UserId="184" Text="I have seen simple example Ajax source codes in many online tutorials. What I want to know is whether using the source code in the examples are perfectly alright or not?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there anything more to be added to the code that goes into a real world application?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What all steps are to be taken to make the application more robust and secure?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a sample source code I got from the web:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    function getChats()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp=GetXmlHttpObject();&#xD;&#xA;        if (xmlHttp==null)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;                return;&#xD;&#xA;        } &#xD;&#xA;        var url=&quot;getchat.php?latest=&quot;+latest;	&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.onreadystatechange=stateChanged;&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.open(&quot;GET&quot;,url,true);&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.send(null);&#xD;&#xA;    } &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    function GetXmlHttpObject()&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        var xmlHttp=null;&#xD;&#xA;        try&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;                xmlHttp=new XMLHttpRequest();&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        catch (e)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;                try&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                        xmlHttp=new ActiveXObject(&quot;Msxml2.XMLHTTP&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;                catch (e)&#xD;&#xA;                {&#xD;&#xA;                        xmlHttp=new ActiveXObject(&quot;Microsoft.XMLHTTP&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        return xmlHttp;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60825" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="43507" RevisionGUID="fdce3cfc-ea49-4ec7-bf46-b42dfd034eec" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:29:15.613" UserId="184" Comment="deleted 52 characters in body" Text="I have seen simple example Ajax source codes in many online tutorials. What I want to know is whether using the source code in the examples are perfectly alright or not?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there anything more to be added to the code that goes into a real world application?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What all steps are to be taken to make the application more robust and secure?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here is a sample source code I got from the web:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    function getChats() {&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp=GetXmlHttpObject();&#xD;&#xA;        if (xmlHttp==null) {&#xD;&#xA;                return;&#xD;&#xA;        } &#xD;&#xA;        var url=&quot;getchat.php?latest=&quot;+latest;	&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.onreadystatechange=stateChanged;&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.open(&quot;GET&quot;,url,true);&#xD;&#xA;        xmlHttp.send(null);&#xD;&#xA;    } &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    function GetXmlHttpObject() {&#xD;&#xA;        var xmlHttp=null;&#xD;&#xA;        try {&#xD;&#xA;                xmlHttp=new XMLHttpRequest();&#xD;&#xA;        } catch (e) {&#xD;&#xA;                try {&#xD;&#xA;                        xmlHttp=new ActiveXObject(&quot;Msxml2.XMLHTTP&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                } catch (e) {&#xD;&#xA;                        xmlHttp=new ActiveXObject(&quot;Microsoft.XMLHTTP&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;                }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;        return xmlHttp;&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10222" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8035" RevisionGUID="3838eece-c355-4626-baba-1387a9c12f33" CreationDate="2008-08-11T18:11:45.697" UserId="737" Text="Danny is mostly right.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;a. unsigned decimal, minimum 4 characters, space padded&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;b. floating point, minimum 16 digits before the decimal (0 padded), 1 digit after the decimal&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;c. hex, minimum 4 characters, 0 padded, letters are printed in upper case&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;d. same as above, but minimum 2 characters&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;e. e is assumed to be an int, converted to an unsigned char and printed&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;f. same as e&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;g. This is likely a typo, the 4 has no effect.  If it were &quot;%.4s&quot;, then a maximum of 4 characters from the string would be printed.  It is interesting to note that in this case, the string does not need to be null terminated." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10223" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="8035" RevisionGUID="608e2f60-ee69-4f12-83da-490bad6dbacd" CreationDate="2008-08-11T23:56:26.127" UserId="737" Comment="" Text="Danny is mostly right.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;a. unsigned decimal, minimum 4 characters, space padded&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;b. floating point, minimum 16 digits before the decimal (0 padded), 1 digit after the decimal&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;c. hex, minimum 4 characters, 0 padded, letters are printed in upper case&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;d. same as above, but minimum 2 characters&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;e. e is assumed to be an int, converted to an unsigned char and printed&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;f. same as e&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;g. This is likely a typo, the 4 has no effect.  If it were &quot;%.4s&quot;, then a maximum of 4 characters from the string would be printed.  It is interesting to note that in this case, the string does not need to be null terminated.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;i&gt;Edit: [jj33][1] points out 2 errors in b and g above [here][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/users/430/jj33&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7981/decoding-printf-statements-in-c-printf-primer#8051" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10224" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8350" RevisionGUID="05940b49-bb36-4f9a-86ba-9b8b952e709c" CreationDate="2008-08-12T00:01:59.110" UserId="55" Text="If, while writing your code, you expect this object to be in the collection, and then during runtime you find that it isn't, I would call that an exceptional case, and it is proper to use an exception.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, if you're simply testing for the existence of an object, and you find that it is not there, this is not exceptional. Using an exception in this case is not proper.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The analysis of the runtime performance depends on the actual collection being used, and the method if searching for it. That shouldn't matter though. Don't let the illusion of optimization fool you into writing confusing code." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10225" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8352" RevisionGUID="ebaf4bcf-4b69-40aa-96fc-d50447156913" CreationDate="2008-08-12T00:03:04.957" UserId="429" Text="The latter is an acceptable solution. Although I would definitely catch on the specific exception (ElementNotFound?) that the collection throws in that case.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Speedwise, it depends on the common case. If you're more likely to find the element than not, the exception solution will be faster. If you're more likely to fail, then it would depend on size of the collection and its iteration speed. Either way, you'd want to measure against normal use to see if this is actually a bottle neck before worrying about speed like this. Go for clarity first, and the latter solution is far more clear than the former." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10226" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8353" RevisionGUID="d8a1d0f2-af71-4949-8d90-1d86a27412c1" CreationDate="2008-08-12T00:04:39.307" UserId="493" Text="&gt; I just confrim, Replicating between&#xD;&#xA;&gt; SqlServer 2005 and Compact Edition is&#xD;&#xA;&gt; something that can be done?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Yes it can definately be done using either Merge Replication or Sync Services" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="10228" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="8356" RevisionGUID="32a34e12-3f01-4fc9-8bc3-379edb8e0db2" CreationDate="2008-08-12T00:07:06.027" UserId="122" Text="I would have to think about it more as to how much I like it... my gut instinct is, eh, not so much...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT: Ryan Fox's comments on the exceptional case is perfect, I concur&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for performance, it depends on the indexer on the collection.  C# lets you override the indexer operator, so if it is doing a for loop like the contains method you would write, then it will be just as slow (with maybe a few nanoseconds slower due to the try/catch... but nothing to worry about unless that code itself is within a huge loop).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the indexer is O(1) (or even O(log(n))... or anything faster than O(n)), then the try/catch solution would be faster of course.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, I am assuming the indexer is throwing the exception, if it is returning null, you could of course just check for null and not use the try/catch." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="3048" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="2652" RevisionGUID="7fd3cada-0969-43ce-9a76-ed6b0568a610" CreationDate="2008-08-05T18:21:31.537" UserId="434" Text="The OBJECT_ID function returns the internal object id for the given object name and type.  'tempdb..#t1' refers to the table #t1 in the tempdb database. 'U' is for user-defined table.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&#xD;&#xA;IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#t1', 'U') IS NOT NULL&#xD;&#xA;  DROP TABLE #t1&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;CREATE TABLE #t1(&#xD;&#xA;  id INT IDENTITY(1,1),&#xD;&#xA;  msg VARCHAR(255)&#xD;&#xA;)&#xD;&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Your program is already reading the CSV file, so arguing that you need XML doesn't work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On the other hand, reading the CSV file, doing _something_ with the values, and then serializing to XML does make sense (well, as much as using XML can make sense... ;)) but you would supposedly already have a means of serializing to XML."   <row Id="184" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="195" RevisionGUID="d5ab0b27-0af9-4c5a-9a0b-6b287dd761ee" CreationDate="2008-08-01T19:28:25.447" UserId="80" Text="This is one of the &quot;hard problems&quot; surrounding development. As far as I know there are no perfect solutions. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you only need to store the database structure and not the data you can export the database as SQL queries. (in Enterprise Manager: Right click on database -&gt; Generate SQL script. I recommend setting the &quot;create one file per object&quot; on the options tab) You can then commit these text files to svn and make use of svn's diff and logging functions. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have this tied together with a Batch script that takes a couple parameters and sets up the database. I also added some additional queries that enter default data like user types and the admin user. (If you want more info on this, post something and I can put the script somewhere accessible)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you need to keep all of the data as well, I recommend keeping a back up of the database and using Redgate (http://www.red-gate.com/) products to do the comparisons. They don't come cheap, but they are worth every penny." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="188" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="197" RevisionGUID="313e2534-f9e0-44ff-b2b8-23e49c5f269c" CreationDate="2008-08-01T19:34:49.067" UserId="71" Text="Hey, I'm still stuck in that camp too. The third party application we have to support is FINALLY going to 2K5, so we're almost out of the wood. But I feel your pain 8^D&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That said, from everything I heard from our DBA, the key is to convert the database to 8.0 format first, and then go to 2005. I believe they used the built in migration/upgrade tools for this. There are some big steps between 6.5 and 8.0 that are better solved there than going from 6.5 to 2005 directly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Your BIGGEST pain, if you didn't know already, is that DTS is gone in favor of SSIS. There is a shell type module that will run your existing DTS packages, but you're going to want to manually recreate them all in SSIS. Ease of this will depend on the complexity of the packages themselves, but I've done a few at work so far and they've been pretty smooth." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19872" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15727" RevisionGUID="6226fc2b-9ee1-4443-9a34-48054e18f707" CreationDate="2008-08-19T04:56:07.750" UserId="1075" Text="The first document to read and digest is [the Mem management guide][1], understand this before moving on. [This][2] is a great guide to objective-c too. Infact the developer site at Apple is very good - but you would probably want to read the Hillegas book first.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In regards to Xcode vs Visual Studio - they are different. I wouldn't say one is better than the other - Windows developers come over from VS and expect it to be the same. This is just an arrogant attitude and please don't fall into this crowd. Having used VS since the AppStudio days and Xcode for a year or so now, both have strengths and weaknesses. Xcode is something that out of the box (and especially when coming from VS) doesn't seem that good, but once you start using and understanding it - it becomes very powerful.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, there are a lot more tools included with Xcode et al, such as Instruments and Shark that you simply can't get with VS, unless you open your wallet, and even then IMHO aren't as good.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Anyway, good luck. I still enjoy C#, but Objective-C/Cocoa somehow makes programming fun again once you get into it...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/MemoryMgmt/MemoryMgmt.html&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/ObjectiveC/Introduction/chapter_1_section_1.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19881" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15733" RevisionGUID="671ab065-a94a-406b-9083-1c31fed7ba91" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:00:04.623" UserId="1370" Text="  - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boxing_(Computer_science)#Boxing][1]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuples][2]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal#Computer_science][3]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_driven_design][4]&#xD;&#xA;  - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_driven_development][5]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Someone may have beat us to it ;)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boxing_(Computer_science)#Boxing&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuples&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal#Computer_science&#xD;&#xA;  [4]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_driven_design&#xD;&#xA;  [5]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_driven_development" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19884" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="15734" RevisionGUID="801b0a6b-15b8-4846-a70f-b6a6006e724d" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:01:52.183" UserId="1890" Text="Google Analytics Access with C#" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49036" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="35690" RevisionGUID="7a93771b-e253-43ef-bf1c-28a2e29061ed" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:02:53.430" UserId="3153" Comment="deleted 4 characters in body" Text="I have tried both methods with a large commercial application. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**The better method: The trunk should be always stable.**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here are some guidelines and benefits of this method:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Code each task (or related set of tasks) in its own branch, then you will have the flexibility of when you would like to merge these tasks and perform a release.  &#xD;&#xA;  - QA should be done on each branch before it is merged to the trunk. &#xD;&#xA;  - By doing QA on each individual branch, you will know exactly what caused the bug easier.&#xD;&#xA;  - This solution scales to any number of developers.  &#xD;&#xA;  - This method works since branching is an almost instant operation in SVN.&#xD;&#xA;  - Tag each release that you perform.&#xD;&#xA;  - You can develop features that you don't plan to release for a while and decide exactly when to merge them.  &#xD;&#xA;  - For all work you do, you can have the benefit of committing your code.  If you work out of the trunk only, you will probably keep your code uncommitted a lot, and hence unprotected and without automatic history. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you try to do the opposite and do all your development in the trunk you'll be plagged by:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - Constant build problems for daily builds&#xD;&#xA;  - Productivity loss when a a developer commits a problem for all other people on the project&#xD;&#xA;  - Longer release cycles, because you need to finally get a stable version&#xD;&#xA;  - Less stable releases&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You simply will not have the flexibility that you need if you try to keep a branch stable and the trunk as the development sandbox.  The reason is that you can't pick and chose from the trunk what you want to put in that stable release.  It would already be all mixed in together in the trunk." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49037" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35970" RevisionGUID="3b38e42a-e96b-46d5-a810-6c2b818f0217" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:04:22.150" UserDisplayName="David Sheeks" Text="NOTE: This isn't really an answer, just an attempt to clarify what might actually be causing the performance problem(s).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;90,000 records is really a fairly small data set and the query is relatively simple with just two join. Do you have indexes on CustomerAddress.CustomerId and CustomerAccount.CustomerId? That seems more likely to be causing performance issues than the where condition LIKE predicates. Are you typically searching to find a match on all of those columns at the same time?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49041" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="16067" RevisionGUID="385fd611-b880-40bb-af90-f7939b964373" CreationDate="2008-08-19T12:38:59.313" UserId="199" Comment="added 77 characters in body" Text="|python|prototyping|swig|ctypes|fortran|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49042" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="16067" RevisionGUID="385fd611-b880-40bb-af90-f7939b964373" CreationDate="2008-08-19T12:38:59.313" UserId="199" Comment="added 77 characters in body" Text="I have been mulling over writing a peak fitting library for a while. I know Python fairly well and plan on implementing everything in Python to begin with but envisage that I may have to re-implement some core routines in a compiled language eventually.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IIRC, one of Python's original remits was as a prototyping language, however Python is pretty liberal in allowing functions, functors, objects to be passed to functions and methods, whereas I suspect the same is not true of say C or Fortran.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What should I know about designing functions/classes which I envisage will have to interface into the compiled language? And how much of these potential problems are dealt with by libraries such as cTypes and [SWIG][1]?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.swig.org/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="190" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="199" RevisionGUID="4dfb0a0b-7f78-4c15-b021-4653e6343fe3" CreationDate="2008-08-01T19:36:46.067" UserId="50" Text="I've read somewhere the human eye can't distinguish between less than 4 values apart. so This is something to keep in mind. The following algorithm does not compensate for this.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm not sure this is exactly what you want, but this is one way to randomly generate non-repeating color values:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(beware, inconsistent pseudo-code ahead)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    //colors entered as 0-255 [R, G, B]&#xD;&#xA;    colors = []; //holds final colors to be used&#xD;&#xA;    rand = new Random();&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    //assumes n is less than 16,777,216&#xD;&#xA;    randomGen(int n){&#xD;&#xA;       while (len(colors) &lt; n){&#xD;&#xA;          //generate a random number between 0,255 for each color&#xD;&#xA;          newRed = rand.next(256);&#xD;&#xA;          newGreen = rand.next(256);&#xD;&#xA;          newBlue = rand.next(256);&#xD;&#xA;          temp = [newRed, newGreen, newBlue];&#xD;&#xA;          //only adds new colors to the array&#xD;&#xA;          if temp not in colors {&#xD;&#xA;             colors.append(temp);&#xD;&#xA;          }&#xD;&#xA;       }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One way you could optimize this for better visibility would be to compare the distance between each new color and all the colors in the array:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    for item in color{&#xD;&#xA;       itemSq = (item[0]^2 + item[1]^2 + item[2]^2])^(.5);&#xD;&#xA;       tempSq = (temp[0]^2 + temp[1]^2 + temp[2]^2])^(.5);&#xD;&#xA;       dist = itemSq - tempSq;&#xD;&#xA;       dist = abs(dist);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    //NUMBER can be your chosen distance apart.&#xD;&#xA;    if dist &lt; NUMBER and temp not in colors {&#xD;&#xA;       colors.append(temp);&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But this approach would significantly slow down your algorithm.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another way would be to scrap the randomness and systematically go through every 4 values and add a color to an array in the above example." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="196" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="206" RevisionGUID="f6497f97-7f26-4688-8fcc-42710c62c908" CreationDate="2008-08-01T19:52:14.227" UserId="35" Text="You can try turning CheckConstraints off on the DataSet (it's in its properties), or altering the properties of that relationship, and change the key to a simple reference - up to you." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="197" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="207" RevisionGUID="b2651dc7-41f3-4978-9be4-130462da27b4" CreationDate="2008-08-01T19:58:45.837" UserId="50" Text="You may already be doing this, but I would think the easiest way to do this would be to do:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;VirtualHost IP:IP&gt;&#xD;&#xA;       Stuff,&#xD;&#xA;       More Stuff,&#xD;&#xA;       ErrorLog /path/where/you/want/it.log&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/VirtualHost&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If there is no leading &quot;/&quot; it is assumed to be relative.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[Apache Error Log Page][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/1.3/mod/core.html#errorlog" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="198" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="210" RevisionGUID="fed70747-1105-4db9-9df9-88f47dddf86d" CreationDate="2008-08-01T20:02:08.357" UserId="39" Text="I don't know the ASP.NET side of the problem but .NET has a pretty powerful class: [System.Globalization.CultureInfo][1]. You can use the following code to parse a string containing a double value:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    double d = double.Parse(&quot;100.20&quot;, CultureInfo.CurrentCulture);&#xD;&#xA;    //  -- OR --&#xD;&#xA;    double d = double.Parse(&quot;100.20&quot;, CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If ASP.NET somehow (i.e. using HTTP Request headers) passes current user's CultureInfo to either CultureInfo.CurrentCulture or CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture, these will work fine.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.globalization.cultureinfo.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="200" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="212" RevisionGUID="7b7c42c2-6bf3-43f2-92e8-e68882669756" CreationDate="2008-08-01T20:05:12.750" UserId="96" Text="You can't please everyone.  If I enter ten as 10.000, and someone enters ten thousand as 10.000, you cannot handle that without some knowledge of the culture of the input.  Detect the culture somehow (browser, system setting - what is the use case?  ASP?  Internal app, or open to the world?), or provide an example of the expected formatting, and use the most lenient parser you can.  Probably something like:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    double d = Double.Parse(&quot;5,000.00&quot;, NumberStyles.Any, CultureInfo.InvariantCulture);" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="217" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="229" RevisionGUID="129e8367-85c5-4d13-95fd-7c488b85a422" CreationDate="2008-08-01T21:46:12.313" UserId="91" Text="Another function, not my me but found on the web and a bit refined:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public static int GetAge(DateTime birthDate)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        DateTime n = DateTime.Now; // To avoid a race condition around midnight&#xD;&#xA;        int age = DateTime.Now.Year - birthDate.Year;&#xD;&#xA;        &#xD;&#xA;        if (n.Month &lt; birthDate.Month || (n.Month == birthDate.Month &amp;&amp; n.Day &lt; birthDate.Day))&#xD;&#xA;        age--;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        return age;&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19893" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15739" RevisionGUID="ef3c52a1-49a4-4cc6-b6dd-a343697ca4ea" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:10:16.537" UserId="1666" Text="You will be wanting [Xerces2][1]. A tutorial for this, [here][2] (req. signup).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, blatently copied from [here][3]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    import org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser;&#xD;&#xA;    import java.io.File;&#xD;&#xA;    import org.w3c.dom.Document;&#xD;&#xA; &#xD;&#xA;    public class SchemaTest &#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;      public static void main (String args[]) &#xD;&#xA;      {&#xD;&#xA;          File docFile = new File(&quot;memory.xml&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;          try&#xD;&#xA;          {&#xD;&#xA;               DOMParser parser = new DOMParser();&#xD;&#xA;               parser.setFeature(&quot;http://xml.org/sax/features/validation&quot;, true);&#xD;&#xA;               parser.setProperty(&#xD;&#xA;                 &quot;http://apache.org/xml/properties/schema/external-noNamespaceSchemaLocation&quot;, &#xD;&#xA;                            &quot;memory.xsd&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;               ErrorChecker errors = new ErrorChecker();&#xD;&#xA;               parser.setErrorHandler(errors);&#xD;&#xA;               parser.parse(&quot;memory.xml&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;         catch (Exception e) &#xD;&#xA;         {&#xD;&#xA;             System.out.print(&quot;Problem parsing the file.&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;      }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://xerces.apache.org/xerces2-j/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/x-dw-xvalid-i.html&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?messageID=3411478" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19895" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15741" RevisionGUID="cc133b45-3f4b-400d-919f-7a875e2b36f7" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:11:15.847" UserId="1366" Text="Are you looking for a tool or a library?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As far as libraries goes, pretty much the de-facto standard is [Xerces2][1] which has both [C++][2] and [Java][3] versions.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Be fore warned though, it is a heavy weight solution.   <row Id="19897" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15746" RevisionGUID="b650487e-1df3-4f45-bb0b-f56d5ddd2916" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:16:56.537" UserId="100" Text="Ultimately, it will not hurt any users if you target the Client Profile. This is because the client profile is a subset of the .net framework v3.5 sp1, and if v3.5 sp1 is already installed you don't need to install anything. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The assemblies in the client profile are the same binaries as the full framework, so unless you're loading assemblies dynamically, then you shouldn't need to do any additional testing. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My thinking is that unless you must use assemblies which are NOT in the client profile, then you should target it. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As for the OS requirements, WPF won't run on pre-XP sp2, so if you need to run on other OSes, then you'll have to use WinForms anyways.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;EDIT:&#xD;&#xA;&gt; On IE, yes. It sends the .NET Framework version as part of the UA string, e.g.:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Actually so does FF3+3.5sp1:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.0.1) Gecko/2008070208 Firefox/3.0.1 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="245" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="253" RevisionGUID="ea09d8ba-0bc8-47cf-87d1-5668c292166f" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:10:56.510" UserId="55" Text="Off the top of my head...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $artist = array(&quot;the roots&quot;,&quot;michael jackson&quot;,&quot;billy idol&quot;,&quot;more&quot;,&quot;and more&quot;,&quot;and_YET_MORE&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    $count = array(5,3,9,1,1,3);&#xD;&#xA;    $highest = max($count);&#xD;&#xA;    for (int $x = 0; x &lt; count($artist); $x++)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        $normalized = $count[$x] / $highest;&#xD;&#xA;        $heading = ceil($normalized * 6); // 6 heading types&#xD;&#xA;        echo &quot;&lt;h&quot;.$heading.&quot;&gt;&quot;.$artist[$x].&quot;&lt;/h&quot;.$heading.&quot;&gt;&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19903" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15749" RevisionGUID="4557d17d-cfb7-4826-b591-f26bcc22a74f" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:23:07.010" UserId="1053" Text="Well, defines are used often for compile time constants and macros.  This can make your code a bit faster as there are really no function calls, the output values of the macros are determined at compile time.  The #if's are very useful.  The most simple example that I can think of is checking for a debug build to add in some extra logging or messaging, maybe even some debugging functions.  You can also check different environment variables this way.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Others with more C/C++ experience can add more I am sure." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49057" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35982" RevisionGUID="7481d91e-676f-4a36-bf6f-ba8bf7dd55dc" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:21:51.483" UserId="3738" Text="Sorry, read your last comment wrong. Yes, hash_map is not in STL, map is. But unordered_map and hash_map are the same from what I've been reading.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;map -&gt; log (n) insertion, retrieval, iteration is efficient (and ordered by key comparison)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;hash_map/unordered_map -&gt; constant time insertion and retrieval, iteration time is not guarantee to be efficient&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Neither of these will work for you by themselves, since the map orders things based on the key content, and not the insertion sequence (unless your key contains info about the insertion sequence in it).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You'll have to do either what you described (list + hash_map), or create a key type that has the insertion sequence number plus an appropriate comparison function.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49059" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="35978" RevisionGUID="736bccbc-330b-4d6c-bcd1-49c8a38601b6" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:22:52.447" UserId="3171" Comment="added 223 characters in body" Text="I'm assuming that the part the doesn't work is `{{ user.item }}`.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Django will be trying a dictionary lookup, but using the string `&quot;item&quot;` and not the value of the `item` loop variable.  Django did the same thing when it resolved `{{ user.name  }}` to the `name` attribute of the `user` object, rather than looking for a variable called `name`.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I think you will need to do some preprocessing of the data in your view before you render it in your template."   <row Id="49060" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35984" RevisionGUID="4a4ea40d-fd8f-4267-8e88-cfb0dd3abe3c" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:24:33.147" UserId="1796" Text="Ditto Stopwatch, it is way better.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Regarding performance measuring you should also check whether your &quot;// Some Execution Process&quot; is a very short process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also bear in mind that the first run of your &quot;// Some Execution Process&quot; might be way slower than subsequent runs.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I typically test a method by running it 1000 times or 1000000 times in a loop and I get much more accurate data than running it once."   <row Id="49061" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35985" RevisionGUID="73e2af68-843a-41bb-8d1b-b5dc9a09f5b8" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:24:51.663" UserId="2600" Text="How large an area are these coordinates spread out over?  What latitude are they at?  How much accuracy do you require?  If they're fairly close together, you can probably ignore the fact that the earth is round and just treat this as a Cartesian plane rather than messing about with spherical geometry and great circle distances.  Of course, as you get further from the equator, degrees of longitute get smaller compared to degrees of latitude, so some sort of scaling factor may be appropriate. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Start with a fairly simple distance formula and a brute force search and see how long that's going to take and if the results are accurate enough before you get fancy.  " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="6667" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="5608" RevisionGUID="fa10f3d3-b5fa-4b0d-b38e-1e0e23df1404" CreationDate="2008-08-08T03:04:55.037" UserId="116" Text="The primary key serves three purposes:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- indicates that the column(s) should be unique&#xD;&#xA;- indicates that the column(s) should be non-null&#xD;&#xA;- document the intent that this is the unique identifier of the row&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The first two can be specified in lots of ways, as you have already done.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The third reason is good:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;- for humans, so they can easily see your intent&#xD;&#xA;- for the computer, so a program that might compare or otherwise process your table can query the database for the table's primary key.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A primary key doesn't have to be an auto-incrementing number field, so I would say that it's a good idea to specify your guid column as the primary key."   <row Id="19917" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15757" RevisionGUID="4fc00268-41b3-4aa7-9219-0204ea4daac6" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:30:12.283" UserId="1398" Text="I often find myself defining some things that are done repetitively in certain functions.   <row Id="19918" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15758" RevisionGUID="628777e9-16cf-48ca-94f6-2050bcfac4c4" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:33:49.390" UserId="100" Text="In C# #define macros, like some of Bernard's examples, are not allowed. The only common use of #define/#ifs in C# is for adding optional debug only code. For example:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;            static void Main(string[] args)&#xD;&#xA;            {&#xD;&#xA;    #if DEBUG&#xD;&#xA;                //this only compiles if in DEBUG&#xD;&#xA;                Console.WriteLine(&quot;DEBUG&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    #endif &#xD;&#xA;    #if !DEBUG&#xD;&#xA;                //this only compiles if not in DEBUG&#xD;&#xA;                Console.WriteLine(&quot;RELEASE&quot;)&#xD;&#xA;    #endif&#xD;&#xA;                //This always compiles&#xD;&#xA;                Console.ReadLine()&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19921" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15761" RevisionGUID="6a3ab84c-07c6-41c4-810d-7d216780b927" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:38:29.210" UserId="1659" Text=" #define is used to define compile-time constants that you can use with #if to include or exclude bits of code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #define USEFOREACH&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #if USEFOREACH&#xD;&#xA;        foreach(var item in items)&#xD;&#xA;         {  &#xD;&#xA;    #else&#xD;&#xA;        for(int i=0; i &lt; items.Length; ++i)&#xD;&#xA;         { var item = item[0];&#xD;&#xA;    #endif&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;           doSomethingWithItem(item);&#xD;&#xA;         }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19922" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15762" RevisionGUID="7906830f-e54e-425c-bebe-49efe6444d6f" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:38:36.900" UserId="1891" Text="I've heard the books currently out there are pretty out of date.   <row Id="4384" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3786" RevisionGUID="40b26872-aff6-440b-b844-b7fee34c5c7a" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:14:14.313" UserId="423" Text="A basic paper version is the way to go for an initial mock-up.  It's been my experience that if you do a &quot;real&quot; mock-up, even if you explain to the customer that it's a non-functional mock-up, they are confused when things don't work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Bottom line: keep it as simple as possible.  If it's on paper, there is no way the customer will confuse it with a working product." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4391" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3782" RevisionGUID="4f15ac66-34cd-4d48-801d-a5bf52b6881c" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:10:56.317" UserId="83" Text="Always start with paper or paper-like mock-ups first.  You do not want to fall into a trap of giving the impression of completeness when the back-end is completely hollow." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4393" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3782" RevisionGUID="d6b7dd94-ac5b-4819-9143-113b40f02f1e" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:17:48.970" UserId="83" Text="Always start with paper or paper-like mock-ups first.  You do not want to fall into a trap of giving the impression of completeness when the back-end is completely hollow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A polished prototype or pixel-perfect example puts too much emphasis on the design.  With an obvious sketch, you have a better shot of discussing desired functionality and content rather than colors, photos, and other stylistic matters.  There will be time for that discussion later in the project.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Jeff discusses paper prototyping in his Coding Horror article [UI-First Software Development][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Click the &quot;Watch a video!&quot; link at [twitter.com][2] to see an interesting take on the idea from [Common Craft][3].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/archives/001091.html&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://twitter.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [3]: http://www.commoncraft.com/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4395" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="3780" RevisionGUID="52da3c2a-afa0-4b40-a38c-4e5728d96e87" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:17:52.183" UserId="35" Text="File paths in the DB is **definitely** the way to go - I've heard story after story from customers with TB of images that it became a nightmare trying to store any significant amount of images in a DB - the performance hit alone is too much." One of them being, under MySQL master/slave configurations, every now and then, some statements drop (!), meaning; some people logging on to the mirror URL don't see data that I know is on the main server and vice versa. Lets say this happens on a meaningful block of data once every month, so I can live with it and assume its a &quot;lost packet&quot; issue (i.e., god knows, but we'll compensate).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The other most important (and annoying) recurring issue is that, when for some reason we do a major upload or update (or reboot) on one end and have to sever the link, then LOAD DATA FROM MASTER doesn't work and I have to manually dump on one end and upload on the other, quite a task nowadays moving some .5TB worth of data.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Is there software for this? I know MySQL (the &quot;corporation&quot;) offers this as a VERY expensive service (full DB replication). Just wondering what people out there do. The way its structured, we run an automatic failover where if one server is not up, then the main URL just resolves to the other server. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Thx.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;/mp" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54788" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39542" RevisionGUID="ad4653e7-842d-41af-99eb-4bfbcebda472" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:45:10.203" UserId="2018" Text="There shouldn't be. Virtual Machines emulate the pieces of hardware you can't access directly, but actual code is executed directly on the host CPU 99.9% of the time. Your best bet is trying to identify known VM environments, but that will give you some false positives and many missed detections.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Identifying the CPU directly will give you the **real** CPU data, since modern VMs don't emulate that part of a computer anymore." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54789" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39543" RevisionGUID="90a68e89-adca-4be1-88f2-ef5bf261f2e4" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:45:10.470" UserId="1908" Text="I can see the main benefit of employing XSLT to transform your data and display it to the user would be the following:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* The data is already in an XML format&#xD;&#xA;* The data follows a well defined schema (this makes using tools like XMLSpy much easier).&#xD;&#xA;* The data needs to be transformed into a number of different output formats, e.g. PDF, WMP and HTML&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If this is to be the only output for your data, and it is not in XML format, then XSLT might not be the best solution.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Likewise if user interaction is required (such as editing of the data) then you will end up employing back-end code anyway to handle updates so might prove one technology too far...&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54793" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="27849" RevisionGUID="1dd8788e-2dae-4937-bfe3-36f31fcb67d0" CreationDate="2008-08-26T12:10:52.343" UserId="905" Text="You can create table variables (in memory), and two different types of temp table:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    --visible only to me, in memory (SQL 2000 and above only)&#xD;&#xA;    declare @test table (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    );&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    --visible only to me, stored in tempDB&#xD;&#xA;    create table #test (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    )&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    --visible to everyone, stored in tempDB&#xD;&#xA;    create table ##test (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    )" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54794" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="27849" RevisionGUID="32e5660c-f20f-4ea3-a8ee-99b161115dfb" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:47:53.317" UserId="905" Comment="Added clarification" Text="You can create table variables (in memory), and two different types of temp table:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    --visible only to me, in memory (SQL 2000 and above only)&#xD;&#xA;    declare @test table (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    );&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    --visible only to me, stored in tempDB&#xD;&#xA;    create table #test (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    )&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    --visible to everyone, stored in tempDB&#xD;&#xA;    create table ##test (&#xD;&#xA;        Field1 int,&#xD;&#xA;        Field2 nvarchar(50)&#xD;&#xA;    )&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;**Edit:**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Following feedback I think this needs a little clarification.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`#table` and `##table` will always be in TempDB.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;`@Table` variables will normally be in memory, but are not guaranteed to be. SQL decides based on the query plan, and uses TempDB if it needs to." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19924" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15764" RevisionGUID="41dcbe14-d349-4998-b22a-c7c52411ac25" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:43:20.307" UserId="1702" Text="You may consider using a command like Linux's [dos2unix][1] for the conversion. Being a Linux command, it is easy to use it in batch mode with scripts etc. I do not know whether there is an equivalent for other operating systems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.linuxcommand.org/man_pages/dos2unix1.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19925" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15766" RevisionGUID="6527caae-4112-4f8b-8b7b-98c4a539739b" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:44:14.220" UserId="1888" Text="SQL injection attacks are on the upswing. It's very easy for someone to find this code and run injection attacks on your website. You must always _**always**_ parameterize your queries. It's best to never run exec(@x) on a dynamic SQL query. It's just not a great idea to use inline SQL ever, IMO.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Stored Procedures, as argued by some, are a hassle because they are another set of items to maintain separate from your code. But they are reusable and if you end up finding a bug in your queries, you can at fix them without recompiling." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19926" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15767" RevisionGUID="8d3660d4-7e2b-49d5-b304-8e192c510253" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:44:15.157" UserId="611" Text="@Ed: When using C++, there is rarely any benefit for using #define over inline functions when creating macros. The idea of &quot;greater speed&quot; is a misconception. With inline functions you get the same speed, but you also get type safey, and no side-effects of preprocessor &quot;pasting&quot; due to the fact that parameters are evaluated before the function is called (for an example, try writing the ubiquitous MAX macro, and call it like this: MAX(x++, y).. you'll see what I'm getting at).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have never had to use #define in my C#, and I very rarely use it for anything other that platform and compiler version checking for conditional compilation in C++." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19937" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15771" RevisionGUID="0c52f7a5-a189-43ae-b2aa-37f20965e1cd" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:50:02.463" UserId="924" Text="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boxing_%28Computer_science%29#Boxing &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;thats the correct link for boxing as related to computer science :D" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19947" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15778" RevisionGUID="a9ca0cd1-5f46-4504-b4da-c0e5a9e2e0d3" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:59:22.117" UserId="716" Text="&gt; Is #define the only thing that&#xD;&#xA;&gt; determines if the code is included&#xD;&#xA;&gt; when compiled? If I have #define&#xD;&#xA;&gt; DEBUGme as a custom symbol, the only&#xD;&#xA;&gt; way to exclude it from compile is to&#xD;&#xA;&gt; remove this #define statement?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can [undefine][1] symbols as well&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    #if defined(DEBUG)&#xD;&#xA;    #undef DEBUG&#xD;&#xA;    #endif&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/wkxst87d(VS.80).aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19948" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15780" RevisionGUID="2500bfc7-7353-4c7c-a337-0de8974a8f4c" CreationDate="2008-08-19T05:59:49.540" UserId="1886" Text="CruiseControl.NET solves a different problem (continuous integration) ... however, I've had great success with NAnt for specifically what you're asking.  There's a learning curve, but once you get proficient you'll wonder how you ever got along w/o it." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19950" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15782" RevisionGUID="266251b1-6bf3-428b-a430-3f9a4d971154" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:00:46.497" UserId="1886" Text="The most important feature I can't live w/o is VS.Net 2008.  :P" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19951" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15783" RevisionGUID="700265ef-30a3-497c-9633-43cf1b1b8eb3" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:03:57.347" UserId="380" Text="The main thing is being able to abstract the complexity of the system so that you don't get bogged down by it as soon as you start off.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* First read the spec like a story (skimming through it). Don't stop at every requirement to analyze it right there and then. This will allow you to get an overall picture of the system without too many details. At this point you would start identifying the major functional components of the system. Start putting these down (use a mindmap tool if you like).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Then take each component and start exploding it (and tying each detail with requirements in the spec document). Do this for all components, till you have covered all requirements.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Now, you should start looking at relationships between the components, and whether there are repetitions of features or functions across the various components (which you can then pull out to create utility components, or such). Around now, you would have a good detailed map of your requirements in your mind.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* NOW, you should think of designing the database, ER diagrams, Class Design, DFDs, deployment, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The problem with doing the last step first is that you can get bogged down in the complexity of your system without really gaining an overall understanding in the first place." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Text="I recently bought a Vista machine for my home and when I use ssh to log in at work Vista pops up a box complaining about a process that died unexpectedly.  Once I dismiss the box, everything is fine.  So I really don't care if some process died.  How do I get Vista to shut up about it?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* * *&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Specifically, the message reads:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    sh.exe has stopped working&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So it's not ssh itself that died, but some sub-process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The problem details textbox reads:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Problem signature:&#xD;&#xA;      Problem Event Name:	APPCRASH&#xD;&#xA;      Application Name:	sh.exe&#xD;&#xA;      Application Version:	0.0.0.0&#xD;&#xA;      Application Timestamp:	48a031a1&#xD;&#xA;      Fault Module Name:	comctl32.dll_unloaded&#xD;&#xA;      Fault Module Version:	0.0.0.0&#xD;&#xA;      Fault Module Timestamp:	4549bcb0&#xD;&#xA;      Exception Code:	c0000005&#xD;&#xA;      Exception Offset:	73dc5b17&#xD;&#xA;      OS Version:	6.0.6000.2.0.0.768.3&#xD;&#xA;      Locale ID:	1033&#xD;&#xA;      Additional Information 1:	fc4d&#xD;&#xA;      Additional Information 2:	d203a7335117760e7b4d2cf9dc2925f9&#xD;&#xA;      Additional Information 3:	1bc1&#xD;&#xA;      Additional Information 4:	7bc0b00964c4a1bd48f87b2415df3372&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Read our privacy statement:&#xD;&#xA;      http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=50163&amp;clcid=0x0409&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I notice the problem occurs when I use the **-Y** option to enable X11 forwarding in an X terminal under Vista.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The dialog box that pops up doesn't automatically gain focus, so pressing Enter serves no purpose.   <row Id="259" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="263" RevisionGUID="58cf73ab-093b-40d8-b587-4692d4bda030" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:27:24.993" UserId="61" Text="I have been trying to implement Win32's MessageBox using GTK.    int MessageBox(HWND hwnd, const char* text, const char* caption, UINT type)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        GtkWidget *window = NULL;&#xD;&#xA;        GtkWidget *dialog = NULL;&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        gtk_init(&amp;gtkArgc, &amp;gtkArgv);&#xD;&#xA;        window = gtk_window_new(GTK_WINDOW_TOPLEVEL);&#xD;&#xA;        g_signal_connect(G_OBJECT(window), &quot;delete_event&quot;, G_CALLBACK(delete_event), NULL);&#xD;&#xA;        g_signal_connect(G_OBJECT(window), &quot;destroy&quot;, G_CALLBACK(destroy), NULL);&#xD;&#xA;        // gcallback calls gtk_main_quit()&#xD;&#xA;        gtk_init_add((GtkFunction)gcallback, NULL);&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        if (type &amp; MB_YESNO) {&#xD;&#xA;            dialog = gtk_message_dialog_new(GTK_WINDOW(window), GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT, GTK_MESSAGE_QUESTION, GTK_BUTTONS_YES_NO, text);&#xD;&#xA;        } else {&#xD;&#xA;            dialog = gtk_message_dialog_new(GTK_WINDOW(window), GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT, GTK_MESSAGE_INFO, GTK_BUTTONS_OK, text);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        gtk_window_set_title(GTK_WINDOW(dialog), caption);&#xD;&#xA;        gint result = gtk_dialog_run(GTK_DIALOG(dialog));&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        gtk_main();&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        gtk_widget_destroy(dialog);&#xD;&#xA;   &#xD;&#xA;        if (type &amp; MB_YESNO) {&#xD;&#xA;            switch (result) {&#xD;&#xA;            default:&#xD;&#xA;            case GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT:&#xD;&#xA;            case GTK_RESPONSE_NO:&#xD;&#xA;                return IDNO;&#xD;&#xA;                break;&#xD;&#xA;            case GTK_RESPONSE_YES:&#xD;&#xA;                return IDYES;&#xD;&#xA;                break;&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;        return IDOK;&#xD;&#xA;    } &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now, I am by no means an experienced GTK programmer, and I realise that I'm probably doing something(s) horribly wrong.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, my problem is that the last dialog popped up with this function stays around until the process exits. Any ideas?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="260" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="263" RevisionGUID="a6d96c94-5f81-4568-a044-8b5f24a60da3" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:33:16.480" UserId="61" Text="|c++|c|linux|unix|gtk|x11|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="261" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="266" RevisionGUID="5a97480d-c1be-49e4-a3ca-a87bab8f6979" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:40:28.463" UserId="34" Text="Any assemblies that are expected to be in the GAC should stay in the GAC. This includes System.web.dll or any other 3rd party dll that you'll deploy to the GAC in production. This means a new developer would have to install these assemblies.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;All other 3rd party assemblies should be references through a relative path. My typical structure is:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    -Project&#xD;&#xA;    --Project.sln&#xD;&#xA;    --References&#xD;&#xA;    ---StructureMap.dll&#xD;&#xA;    ---NUnit.dll&#xD;&#xA;    ---System.Web.Mvc.dll&#xD;&#xA;    --Project.Web&#xD;&#xA;    ---Project.Web.Proj&#xD;&#xA;    ---Project.Web.Proj files&#xD;&#xA;    --Project&#xD;&#xA;    ---Project.Proj&#xD;&#xA;    ---Project.Proj files&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Project.Web and Project reference the assemblies in the root/References folder relatively. These .dlls are checked into subversion.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Aside from that, \*/bin  \*/bin/\* obj  should be in your global ignore path.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With this setup, all references to assemblies are either through the GAC (so should work across all computers), or relative to each project within your solution." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="263" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="268" RevisionGUID="e94571e1-5586-47a3-84b8-715a2aa39dfb" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:44:05.883" UserId="101" Text="Is this a .Net specific question?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Generally the best practice is to not check in anything which is built automatically from files that are already in SCM.  All of that is ideally created as part of your automatic build process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If the `bin` directory you're referring to contains third-party binaries, rather than a build of your project, ignore (downvote?) this advice." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54797" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39551" RevisionGUID="9e4b35db-8ee2-448b-bdf6-a94ec6475ffd" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:50:17.087" UserId="4185" Text="If it VM does the job well, it should be invisible to the client that it's being virtualized.   <row Id="54798" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39553" RevisionGUID="3a059bcc-9ff2-4d31-ae4f-715056f349cd" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:50:54.917" UserId="1968" Text="There are two aspects.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;.NET readily supports arrays of controls, VB6 just had to use a workaround because otherwise, wiring up events was really hard. In .NET, wiring up events dynamically is easy.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, the .NET form designer does not support control arrays for a simple reason: arrays of controls are created/extended at run time. If you know how many controls you need at compile time (the reasoning goes) then you give them different names and don't put them in an array.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I know it's not very useful code&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That's exactly the point. Why have a feature if it's useless?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If needed, you can also access a control by name, resulting in something like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Private Sub Command_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles Command1.Click, Command2.Click …&#xD;&#xA;        Dim name As String = DirectCast(sender, Control).Name&#xD;&#xA;        Dim index As Integer = Integer.Parse(name.Substring(&quot;Command&quot;.Length))&#xD;&#xA;        Controls(String.Format(&quot;Text {0}&quot;, index)).Text = Timer.Value.ToString()&#xD;&#xA;    End Sub" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54806" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39555" RevisionGUID="a9402339-e861-42f0-95de-082c7b8198df" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:51:29.673" UserId="1709" Text="I would create a (Ruby) script to do a &lt;code&gt;SELECT * FROM ...&lt;/code&gt; on all the databases on the server and then do a &lt;code&gt;DROP DATABASE ...&lt;/code&gt; followed by a series of new &lt;code&gt;INSERT&lt;/code&gt;s on the local copy. You can do a &lt;code&gt;SHOW DATABASES&lt;/code&gt; query to list the databases dynamically. Now, this assumes that the table structure doesn't change, but if you want to support table changes also you could add a &lt;code&gt;SHOW CREATE TABLE ...&lt;/code&gt; query and a corresponding &lt;code&gt;CREATE TABLE&lt;/code&gt; statement for each table in each database. To get a list of all the tables in a database you do a &lt;code&gt;SHOW TABLES&lt;/code&gt; query.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Once you have the script you can set it up as a scheduled job to run as often as you need." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54809" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39559" RevisionGUID="cbb6b888-006c-4353-be1e-5331ae8689f5" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:51:57.083" UserId="2418" Text="I agree with Robocopy as a solution...thats why the utility is called *&quot;Robust File Copy&quot;*&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I've used Robocopy for this with excellent results. By default, it will retry every 30 seconds until the file gets across.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;And by default, a million retries. That should be plenty for your intermittent connection. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It also does restartable transfers and you can even throttle transfers with a gap between packets assuing you don't want to use all the bandwidth as other programs are using the same connection (/IPG switch)?." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54810" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39235" RevisionGUID="da515034-e912-45f1-bcef-5ba272a93bc1" CreationDate="2008-09-02T11:10:10.670" UserId="988" Text="Martin's answer is correct on Windows Server 2003:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You will have to assign the &quot;Lock pages in memory&quot; privilege to any user that runs your application. This includes administrators&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;   1. Select Control Panel -&gt; Administrative Tools -&gt; Local Security Policy&#xD;&#xA;   2. Select Local Policies -&gt; User Rights Assignment&#xD;&#xA;   3. Double click &quot;Lock pages in memory&quot;, add users and/or groups&#xD;&#xA;   4. Reboot the machine&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On Windows Vista you need also make sure that the application is run as Administrator (by right-clicking on the application or the shell and choosing &quot;Run as adminstrator&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition, it helps to have a freshly booted machine since the large pages can &quot;run out&quot; due to fragmentation of the heap." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39393" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29326" RevisionGUID="42e5f5a9-597c-4dd2-8347-ab68b925ca4f" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:32:46.220" UserId="1190" Text="We, too, just put the binaries in source control.   <row Id="39403" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29330" RevisionGUID="bfbcce73-ba3a-492b-afc6-c07887560f00" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:35:58.367" UserId="1841" Text="Yes, having art assets in version control is very useful.  You get the ability to track history, roll back changes, and you have a single source to do backups with.   Keep in mind that art assets are MUCH larger so your server needs to have lots of disk space &amp; network bandwidth.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've had success with using [perforce][1] on very large projects (+100 GB), however we had to wrap access to the version control server with something a little more artist friendly.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've heard some good things about [Alienbrain][2] as well, it does seem to have a very slick UI.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.perforce.com/&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://www.softimage.com/products/alienbrain/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39408" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="29335" RevisionGUID="32a84de3-11a9-4ac6-a3f4-0001495e00a4" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:38:54.397" UserId="2228" Text="Best practices for development environment and API dev?" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39409" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="29335" RevisionGUID="32a84de3-11a9-4ac6-a3f4-0001495e00a4" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:38:54.397" UserId="2228" Text="|api|development-environment|pipeline|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39410" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="29335" RevisionGUID="8b4183f2-415d-417a-8106-70d8b2004954" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:40:29.417" UserId="1662" Comment="edited tags" Text="|api|development-environment|pipeline|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39411" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29335" RevisionGUID="32a84de3-11a9-4ac6-a3f4-0001495e00a4" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:38:54.397" UserId="2228" Text="My current employer uses a 3rd party hosted CRM provider and we have a fairly sophisticated integration tier between  the two systems.  Amongst the capabilities of the CRM provider is for developers to author business logic in a  Java like language and on events such as the user clicking a button or submitting a new account into the system, have validation and/or business logic fire off. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;One of the capabilities that we make use of is for that business code running on the hosted provider to invoke web services that we host.  The canonical example is a sales rep entering  in a new sales lead and hitting a button to ping our systems to see if we can identify that new lead based on email address, company/first/last name, etc, and if so, return back an internal GUID that represents that individual.  This all works for us fine, but we've run into a wall again and again in trying to setup a sane dev environment to work against.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So while our use case is a bit nuanced, this can generally apply to any development house that builds APIs for 3rd party consumption:  &lt;b&gt;what are some best practices when designing a development pipeline and environment when  you're building APIs to be consumed by the outside world?&lt;/b&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;At our office, all our devs are behind a firewall, so code in progress can't be hit by the outside world, in our case the CRM provider.  We could poke holes in the firewall but that's less than ideal from a security surface area standpoint.  Especially if the # of devs who need to be in a DMZ like area is high.  We currently are trying a single dev machine in the DMZ and then remoting into it as needed to do dev work, but that's created a resource scarcity issue if multiple devs need the box, let alone they're making potentially conflicting changes (e.g.  different branches).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We've considered just mocking/faking incoming requests by building fake clients for these services, but that's a pretty major overhead in building out feature sets  (though it does by nature reinforce a testability of our APIs).  This also doesn't obviate the fact that sometimes we really do need to diagnose/debug issues coming from the real client itself, not some faked request payload.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What have others done in these types of scenarios?  In this day and age of mashups, there have to be a lot of folks out there w/ experiences of developing APIs--what's worked (and not worked so) well for the folks out there?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60837" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43530" RevisionGUID="3d88eb67-a9ae-4281-aedf-41709ffbc02f" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:36:45.847" UserId="4507" Text="The [section on &quot;Why am I getting no hits?&quot;][1] in the Lucene FAQ has some suggestions you might find useful.  You're using Field.Index.UN_TOKENIZED, so no Analyzer will be used for indexing (I think).  If you're using an Analyzer when you're searching then that might be the root of your problem - the indexing and searching Analyzers should be the same to make sure you get the right hits.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://wiki.apache.org/lucene-java/LuceneFAQ#head-3558e5121806fb4fce80fc022d889484a9248b71" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60848" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43534" RevisionGUID="9bd68949-8d22-4e8a-97d6-a75f1db8e6e3" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:39:19.803" UserId="3583" Text="This is what I used for Excel 2003:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Dictionary&lt;string, string&gt; props = new Dictionary&lt;string, string&gt;();&#xD;&#xA;    props[&quot;Provider&quot;] = &quot;Microsoft.Jet.OLEDB.4.0&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    props[&quot;Data Source&quot;] = repFile;&#xD;&#xA;    props[&quot;Extended Properties&quot;] = &quot;Excel 8.0&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();&#xD;&#xA;    foreach (KeyValuePair&lt;string, string&gt; prop in props)&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        sb.Append(prop.Key);&#xD;&#xA;        sb.Append('=');&#xD;&#xA;        sb.Append(prop.Value);&#xD;&#xA;        sb.Append(';');&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;    string properties = sb.ToString();&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    using (OleDbConnection conn = new OleDbConnection(properties))&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        conn.Open();&#xD;&#xA;        DataSet ds = new DataSet();&#xD;&#xA;        string columns = String.Join(&quot;,&quot;, columnNames.ToArray());&#xD;&#xA;        using (OleDbDataAdapter da = new OleDbDataAdapter(&#xD;&#xA;            &quot;SELECT &quot; + columns + &quot; FROM [&quot; + worksheet + &quot;$]&quot;, conn))&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            DataTable dt = new DataTable(tableName);&#xD;&#xA;            da.Fill(dt);&#xD;&#xA;            ds.Tables.Add(dt);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54811" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="39235" RevisionGUID="915c5e93-114f-41b2-be8e-b0a7164fb98c" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:52:15.693" UserId="988" Comment="added 45 characters in body" Text="Martin's answer is correct on Windows Server 2003:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; You will have to assign the &quot;Lock pages in memory&quot; privilege to any user that runs your &gt; application. This includes administrators&#xD;&#xA;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   1. Select Control Panel -&gt; Administrative Tools -&gt; Local Security Policy&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   2. Select Local Policies -&gt; User Rights Assignment&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   3. Double click &quot;Lock pages in memory&quot;, add users and/or groups&#xD;&#xA;&gt;   4. Reboot the machine&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;On Windows Vista you need also make sure that the application is run as Administrator (by right-clicking on the application or the shell and choosing &quot;Run as adminstrator&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In addition, it helps to have a freshly booted machine since the large pages can &quot;run out&quot; due to fragmentation of the heap."   <row Id="266" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="269" RevisionGUID="eac67d98-3da6-4e15-ada8-4d60280968bf" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:49:57.103" UserId="91" Text="Yes, I thought about that, but I soon figured out that another Domain-Specific-Language (DSL) would be a bit too much.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Essentially, they need to interact with my Gamestate in possibly unpredictable ways. For example, a card could have a rule &quot;When this cards enter play, all your Undead Minions gain +3 Attack against flying enemies, except when the enemy is blessed&quot;. As Trading Card Games are turn based, the GameState Manager will fire OnStageX Events and let the cards modify other cards or the GameState in whatever way the Card needs.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If I try to create a DSL, I have to implement a rather large feature set and possibly constantly update it, which shifts the maintenance work to another part without actually removing it.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That's why I wanted to stay with a &quot;real&quot; .net Language to essentially be able to just fire the Event and let the Card manipulate the Gamestate in whatever way (within the Limits of the Code Access Security)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="272" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="274" RevisionGUID="72272655-148e-49a0-a326-7502feb00489" CreationDate="2008-08-01T23:58:35.650" UserId="40" Text="@Ryan&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That's correct but it actually makes the tags with the least number, larger.  This code has been tested:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    $artist = array(&quot;the roots&quot;,&quot;michael jackson&quot;,&quot;billy idol&quot;,&quot;more&quot;,&quot;and more&quot;,&quot;and_YET_MORE&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    $count = array(5,3,9,1,1,3);&#xD;&#xA;    $highest = max($count);&#xD;&#xA;    for ($x = 0; $x &lt; count($artist); $x++) {&#xD;&#xA;        $normalized =  ($highest - $count[$x]+1) / $highest;&#xD;&#xA;        $heading = ceil($normalized * 6); // 6 heading types&#xD;&#xA;        echo &quot;&lt;h$heading&gt;{$artist[$x]}&lt;/h$heading&gt;&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    }" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="288" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="290" RevisionGUID="5cf25ac5-7022-4a37-831e-613b58b1e908" CreationDate="2008-08-02T00:42:35.310" UserId="106" Text="I know that Visual Studio itself (at least in 2003 version) references the IE dll directly to render the &quot;Design View&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It may be worth looking into that.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Otherwise, I can't think of anything beyond the Web Browser control."   <row Id="289" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="291" RevisionGUID="9d2b8414-a2b0-46fa-bae7-abb3c147ed65" CreationDate="2008-08-02T00:43:38.837" UserId="109" Text="Looking around, and using some C# 3.0 features we can do this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    foreach (KeyValuePair&lt;string, int&gt; item in keywordCounts.OrderBy(key =&gt; key.Value))&#xD;&#xA;            { &#xD;&#xA;                   // do something with item.Key and item.Value&#xD;&#xA;            }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This is the cleanest way I've seen and is similar to the Ruby way of handling hashes." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="290" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="292" RevisionGUID="015ab7de-1924-49c0-bbee-ffa045c71dd7" CreationDate="2008-08-02T00:47:48.797" UserId="91" Text="On a high level, you have no other choice then to walk through the whole Dictionary and look at each value.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Maybe this helps:&#xD;&#xA;http://bytes.com/forum/thread563638.html&#xD;&#xA;Copy/Pasting from John Timney:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Dictionary&lt;string, string&gt; s = new Dictionary&lt;string, string&gt;();&#xD;&#xA;    s.Add(&quot;1&quot;, &quot;a Item&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    s.Add(&quot;2&quot;, &quot;c Item&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;    s.Add(&quot;3&quot;, &quot;b Item&quot;);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    List&lt;KeyValuePair&lt;string, string&gt;myList = new&#xD;&#xA;    List&lt;KeyValuePair&lt;string, string&gt;&gt;(s);&#xD;&#xA;    myList.Sort(&#xD;&#xA;        delegate(KeyValuePair&lt;string, stringfirstPair,&#xD;&#xA;        KeyValuePair&lt;string, stringnextPair)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            return firstPair.Value.CompareTo(nextPair.Value);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    );" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="296" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="297" RevisionGUID="83a9b8d9-891e-4da5-9e22-49fdec57f8a8" CreationDate="2008-08-02T01:10:41.027" UserId="40" Text="I usually just specify this in an .htaccess file _or_ the vhost.conf on the domain I'm working on:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;php_admin_value error_log &quot;/var/www/vhosts/example.com/error_log&quot;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="297" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="298" RevisionGUID="d2244a6e-e334-48d4-bed0-4c1de74acd8c" CreationDate="2008-08-02T01:15:42.123" UserId="49" Text="myList.Sort(&#xD;&#xA;        delegate(KeyValuePair&lt;string, string&gt; firstPair,&#xD;&#xA;        KeyValuePair&lt;string, string&gt; nextPair)&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            return firstPair.Value.CompareTo(nextPair.Value);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    );&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since you're targeting .net 2.0 or above, you can simplify this into lambda syntax -- it's equivalent but shorter. If you're targeting .net 2.0 you can only use this syntax if you're using the compiler from vs2008.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    myList.Sort((firstPair,nextPair) =&gt;&#xD;&#xA;        {&#xD;&#xA;            return firstPair.Value.CompareTo(nextPair.Value);&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    );" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19958" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="15716" RevisionGUID="57dd0c93-8ee3-418c-9bf7-d01a4f92228c" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:06:53.503" UserId="380" Comment="edited tags" Text="|c#|.net-2.0|user-controls|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19959" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15785" RevisionGUID="8189ad84-02b4-471c-a1da-7d6b62e0ed4d" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:08:31.770" UserId="1886" Text="I also disagree about starting with the database.  The DB is simply an artifact of how your business objects are persisted.  I don't know of an equivalent in Java, but .Net has stellar tools such as [SubSonic](http://subsonicproject.com/) that allow your DB design to stay fluid as you iterate through your business objects design.  I'd say first and foremost (even before deciding on what technologies to introduce) focus on the process and identify your nouns and verbs ... then build out from those abstractions.  Hey, it really does work in the &quot;real world&quot;, just like OOP 101 taught you!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19972" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15793" RevisionGUID="c9880332-bf4d-4d3f-abc9-80a550bbdf00" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:19:37.910" UserId="224" Text="I previously organised my DDL code organised by one file per entity and made a tool that combined this into a single DDL script.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My former employer used a scheme where all table DDL was in one file (stored in oracle syntax), indicies in another, constraints in a third and static data in a fourth. I actually wrote a handy tool that will convert Oracle DDL to SQL Server (it worked 99.9% of the time).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have recently switched to using [Visual Studio Team System for Database professionals][1]. The graph paper is great for helping to maintain proportions.  Once the client and I have come to a conclusion I'll usually fill in the drawing with pen since pencil is prone to fading.    &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When I actually get around to building the digital prototype, I'll scan in the hand-drawn one and use it as a background template.  Seems to work pretty well for me." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4407" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3804" RevisionGUID="e3220325-f2a7-462c-b176-6bb8aba936e9" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:30:45.950" UserId="116" Text="[GoldenGate][1] is a very good solution, but probably as expensive as the MySQL replicator.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It basically tails the journal, and applies changes based on what's committed.  They support bi-directional replication (a hard task), and replication between heterogenous systems.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Since they work by processing the journal file, they can do large-scale distributed replication without affecting performance on the source machine(s).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.goldengate.com/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4409" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3806" RevisionGUID="cc2c07b7-c1ce-48f2-8882-94fc07a408d4" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:31:21.300" UserId="394" Text="Besides the already mentioned Robocopy, [XXCOPY](http://www.xxcopy.com) has a free version. Its syntax is backwards compatible with XCOPY, but has tons of additional options (XXCOPY /HELP &gt; x create a 42kb file with all the options available). For instance, you can delete files with it, include or exclude a list of directories for the copy, use it as a &quot;touch&quot; utility, etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I've been using it for years, it's 2 thumbs up."
