  <row Id="49082" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="34687" RevisionGUID="bd47c4db-8243-4f36-bae2-5685d935579f" CreationDate="2008-08-29T18:05:27.820" UserId="3625" Comment="Provided addtional information in response to Thomas Mayfield's answer (http://beta.stackoverflow.com/questions/34687/subversion-ignoring-password-and-username-options#34755)" Text="When I try to do any svn command and supply the &quot;--username&quot; and/or &quot;--password&quot; options, it prompts me for my password anyways, and always will attempt to use my current user instead of the one specified in &quot;--username&quot;. And why is it asking for user1's password instead of user2's?  I'm 99% sure all of my permissions are set correctly.  Is there some config option for svn that switches off command-line passwords? None of them seem to apply to SVN:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # HOSTNAME=XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;    # TERM=xterm&#xD;&#xA;    # SHELL=/bin/sh&#xD;&#xA;    # HISTSIZE=1000&#xD;&#xA;    # KDE_NO_IPV6=1&#xD;&#xA;    # SSH_CLIENT=XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX XXXXX XX&#xD;&#xA;    # QTDIR=/usr/lib/qt-3.3&#xD;&#xA;    # QTINC=/usr/lib/qt-3.3/include&#xD;&#xA;    # SSH_TTY=/dev/pts/2&#xD;&#xA;    # USER=XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;    # LS_COLORS=no=00:fi=00:di=00;34:ln=00;36:pi=40;33:so=00;35:bd=40;33;01:cd=40;33;01:or=01;05;37;41:mi=01;05;37;41:ex=00;32:*.cmd=00;32:*.exe=00;32:*.com=00;32:*.btm=00;32:*.bat=00;32:*.sh=00;32:*.csh=00;32:*.tar=00;31:*.tgz=00;31:*.arj=00;31:*.taz=00;31:*.lzh=00;31:*.zip=00;31:*.z=00;31:*.Z=00;31:*.gz=00;31:*.bz2=00;31:*.bz=00;31:*.tz=00;31:*.rpm=00;31:*.cpio=00;31:*.jpg=00;35:*.gif=00;35:*.bmp=00;35:*.xbm=00;35:*.xpm=00;35:*.png=00;35:*.tif=00;35:&#xD;&#xA;    # KDEDIR=/usr&#xD;&#xA;    # MAIL=/var/spool/mail/XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;    # PATH=/usr/lib/qt-3.3/bin:/usr/kerberos/bin:/usr/local/bin:/bin:/usr/bin&#xD;&#xA;    # INPUTRC=/etc/inputrc&#xD;&#xA;    # PWD=/home/users/XXXXXX/my_repository&#xD;&#xA;    # KDE_IS_PRELINKED=1&#xD;&#xA;    # LANG=en_US.UTF-8&#xD;&#xA;    # SSH_ASKPASS=/usr/libexec/openssh/gnome-ssh-askpass&#xD;&#xA;    # SHLVL=1&#xD;&#xA;    # HOME=/home/users/XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;    # LOGNAME=XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;    # QTLIB=/usr/lib/qt-3.3/lib&#xD;&#xA;    # CVS_RSH=ssh&#xD;&#xA;    # SSH_CONNECTION=69.202.73.122 60998 216.7.19.47 22&#xD;&#xA;    # LESSOPEN=|/usr/bin/lesspipe.sh %s&#xD;&#xA;    # G_BROKEN_FILENAMES=1&#xD;&#xA;    # _=/bin/env&#xD;&#xA;    # OLDPWD=/home/users/XXXXXX&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="39414" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29340" RevisionGUID="6812ab3f-d1ea-465c-98c1-3034e2875c37" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:43:01.250" UserId="1875" Text="@Damian - Good point about the tagging and cross referencing.  That's true; while I haven't working with many designers on a software development project, I have worked for a company that had a design department and know that this is an issue.  Designers are still (perpetually) looking for the perfect system to handle this sort of thing.  I think this is more suited to a design department for shared access, searching and versioning, etc to all assets -- where there is a business incentive to not reinvent the wheel wherever/whenever possible.  I don't think it would apply for a project-oriented manner as tagging and cross referencing wouldn't be quite as applicable.  " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

Which of the following should I use?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* APC - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/apc-php5-apache2-debian-etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;* eAccelerator - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/eaccelerator_php5_debian_etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;* XCache - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/xcache-php5-apache2-debian-etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm also open to any other alternatives that have slipped under my radar.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Currently running on a stock Debian Etch with Apache 2 and PHP 5.2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**[Update 1]**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;HowtoForge installation links added&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**[Update 2]**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on the answers and feedback given, I have tested all 3 implementations using the following Apache JMeter test plan on my application:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Login&#xD;&#xA;* Access Home Page&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With 50 concurrent connections, the results are as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;No Opcode Caching&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/nocache.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;APC&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/apc.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;eAccelerator&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/eaccelerator.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/xcache.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From the above results, eAccelerator has a slight edge in performance compared to APC and XCache. However, what matters most from the above data is that any sort of opcode caching gives a tremendous boost in performance.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have decided to use APC due to the following 2 reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Package is available in official Debian repository&#xD;&#xA;* More functional control panel&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To summarize my experience:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ease of Installation: APC &gt; eAccelerator &gt; XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Performance: eAccelerator &gt; APC, XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Control Panel: APC &gt; XCache &gt; eAccelerator" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="310" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="304" RevisionGUID="ee0386fb-5302-4ea9-8d34-8ba4181c27fd" CreationDate="2008-08-02T01:41:26.800" UserId="91" Text="Try removing the 0x first and then Encoding.UTF8.GetString, I think that may work.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Essentially:&#xD;&#xA;0x44004500&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;remove the 0x, and then always 2 Bytes are one Character:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;44 00 = D&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;45 00 = E&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;6F 00 = o&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;72 00 = r&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So it's definitely a Unicode/UTF Format with 2 Bytes/Character."   <row Id="312" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="307" RevisionGUID="8b35dbc8-0fcc-4218-9e74-0dfa4eaf7a18" CreationDate="2008-08-02T01:49:46.220" UserId="49" Text="Oleg Shilo's C# Script solution (at codeproject) really is a great introduction to providing script abilities in your application.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A different approach would be to consider a language that is specifically built for scripting, such as IronRuby, IronPython, or Lua.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;IronPython and IronRuby are both available today.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For a guide to embedding IronPython read&#xD;&#xA;[How to embed IronPython script support in your existing app in 10 easy steps][1]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Lua is a scripting language commonly used in games.   <row Id="54824" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39566" RevisionGUID="96ed0161-9681-4f72-8a36-643f2cae525f" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:53:47.577" UserId="3619" Text="Regarding...&#xD;&#xA;&gt; ... how to go about it from a learning point of view.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Are you trying to learning to program scientific methods? or to produce production software?   <row Id="54825" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39568" RevisionGUID="ed6df071-968b-44f9-a714-bbfce84b00a6" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:54:29.247" UserId="3832" Text="It can certainly be done, has been done, and is a hot topic currently among the raytracing and Cuda gurus.  I'd start by perusing http://www.nvidia.com/object/cuda_home.html&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But it's basically a research problem.  People who are doing it well are getting peer-reviewed research papers out of it.  But *well* at this point still means that the best GPU/Cuda results are approximately competitive with best-of-class solutions on CPU/multi-core/SSE.  So I think that it's a little early to assume that using Cuda is going to accelerate a ray tracer.  The problem is that although ray tracing is &quot;embarrassingly parallel&quot; (as they say), it is not the kind of &quot;fixed input and output size&quot; problem that maps straightforwardly to GPUs -- you want trees, stacks, dynamic data structures, etc.  It can be done with Cuda/GPU, but it's tricky.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Your question wasn't clear about your experience level or the goals of your project.  If this is your first ray tracer and you're just trying to learn, I'd avoid Cuda -- it'll take you 10x longer to develop and you probably won't get good speed.  If you're a moderately experienced Cuda programmer and are looking for a challenging project and ray tracing is just a fun thing to learn, by all means, try to do it in Cuda.  If you're making a commercial app and you're looking to get a competitive speed edge -- well, it's probably a crap shoot at this point... you might get a performance edge, but at the expense of more difficult development and dependence on particular hardware.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Check back in a year, the answer may be different after another generation or two of GPU speed, Cuda compiler development, and research community experience.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54826" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39569" RevisionGUID="7c1345b0-4250-461d-b659-3d25ddb0dcfe" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:54:44.050" UserId="4050" Text="I once ran across an assembly code snippet that told you if you were in a VM....I googled but couldn't find the original article.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I did find this though: [Detect if your program is running inside a Virtual Machine][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hope it helps.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.codeproject.com/KB/system/VmDetect.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54827" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39570" RevisionGUID="a5d29162-643b-4449-a7d8-64b8e3bb9460" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:54:51.680" UserId="1908" Text="The same click event can handle the button presses from multiple buttons in .Net. You could then add the the text box to find in the Tag property?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    Private Sub AllButton_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles Button1.Click, Button2.Click, Button3.Click&#xD;&#xA;      Dim c As Control = CType(sender, Control)&#xD;&#xA;      Dim t As TextBox = FindControl(CType(c.Tag, String))&#xD;&#xA;      If t Is Not Nothing Then&#xD;&#xA;         t.Text = &quot;Clicked&quot;&#xD;&#xA;      End If&#xD;&#xA;    End Sub" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54828" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39571" RevisionGUID="6d5d289d-9559-49ef-97b9-ea681c8cf240" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:54:57.030" UserId="1060" Text="These days, any &quot;unique&quot; or &quot;cool&quot; feature in a DBMS makes me incredibly nervous. I break out in a rash and have to stop work until the itching goes away.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I just hate to be locked in to a platform unnecessarily. Suppose you build a big chunk of your system in PL/Perl inside the database. Or in C# within SQL Server, or PL/SQL within Oracle, there are plenty of examples*.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Now you suddenly discover that your chosen platform doesn't scale. Or isn't fast enough. Or something. Worse, there's a new kid on the database block (something like MonetDB, CouchDB, Cache, say but much cooler) that would solve all your problems (even if your only problem, like mine, is having an uncool databse platform). And you can't switch to it without recoding half your application.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(*Admittedly, the paid-for products are to some extent seeking to lock you in by persuading you to use their unique features, which is not an accusation that can directly be levelled at the free providers, but the effect is the same).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So that's a rant on the first part of the question. Heart-felt, though.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; is there any valid reason to use an&#xD;&#xA;&gt; untrusted language? It seems like&#xD;&#xA;&gt; making it so that any user can execute&#xD;&#xA;&gt; any operation would be a bad idea&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My goodness, yes it does! A sort of &quot;Perl injection attack&quot;? Almost worth doing it just to see what happens, I'd have thought.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For philosophical reasons outlined above I think I'll pass on the PL/LOLCODE challenge. Although I was somewhat amazed to discover it was a link to something extant." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49083" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="34687" RevisionGUID="4baf3d52-4983-43b5-a059-d8ad34b56824" CreationDate="2008-08-29T18:51:01.047" UserId="3625" Comment="added clarification to show that other long options still work" Text="When I try to do any svn command and supply the &quot;--username&quot; and/or &quot;--password&quot; options, it prompts me for my password anyways, and always will attempt to use my current user instead of the one specified in &quot;--username&quot;.  Neither &quot;--no-auth-cache&quot; nor &quot;--non-interactive&quot; have any effect on this.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For example, logged in as user1:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # $ svn update --username 'user2' --password 'password'&#xD;&#xA;    # user1@domain.com's password: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Other options work correctly:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    # $ svn --version --quiet&#xD;&#xA;    # 1.3.2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Why does it prompt me?  And why is it asking for user1's password instead of user2's?  I'm 99% sure all of my permissions are set correctly.  Is there some config option for svn that switches off command-line passwords?  Or is it something else entirely?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm running svn 1.3.2 (r19776) on Fedora Core 5 (Bordeaux).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;----------&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Here's a list of my environment variables (with sensitive information X'ed out).   <row Id="60849" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43535" RevisionGUID="28d5a092-e4ad-43a9-9d9e-a69a29374162" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:39:19.897" UserId="968" Text="We are using one-way replications, but not from the same application. Our applications are reading-writing to the master database, the data gets synchronized to the replca database, and the reporting tools are using this replica.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;We don't want our application to read from a different database, so in this scenario I would suggest using file groups and partitioning on the master database. Using file groups (especially on different drives) and partitioning of files and indexes can help on performance a lot." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

You would need to use a a profiler.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This won't show you directly how much time is spent with exception handling but with a little bit of research you will find out which methods of the runtime methods deal with exceptions (for example vor VC++.NET it's __cxx_exc[...]).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Add their times up and you have the overhead. In our project we used vTunes from Intel which works with both Visual C++ and gcc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Edit: Well, if you just need a generic number that might work. Thought you had an actual application to profile where you can't just turn off exceptions." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19981" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15789" RevisionGUID="8ba75cae-0c5d-4499-bdce-1933953b99c1" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:15:18.667" UserId="1886" Text="I think you need to reorganize the responsibilities.  Each component should be responsible for itself and therefore copy its generated goodness where it needs to go.  That way it doesn't matter if/who/what/when/where got built.  Whatever is updated will put itself into the proper place." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19982" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="15789" RevisionGUID="3ac6bcaa-37a5-47be-a198-dc5a21831c42" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:24:42.533" UserId="1886" Comment="Added additional info after reading other suggestions." Text="I think you need to reorganize the responsibilities.  Each component should be responsible for itself and therefore copy its generated goodness where it needs to go.  That way it doesn't matter if/who/what/when/where got built.  Whatever is updated will put itself into the proper place.&#xD;&#xA;***&#xD;&#xA;IMO the other suggestions are no-nos since they'll circumvent the compiler's smarts to know when a rebuild is necessary for the main project.  And hence killing any compile time-savings.  If your &quot;plugin&quot; projects are assemblies (and not just project-references from the main project), then you do not need to rebuild the main project each time a plugin is rebuilt.  The new assembly will get selected into the process / debugger w/o the main project needing a rebuild." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

They can be pretty much any other object." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49090" PostHistoryTypeId="1" PostId="35991" RevisionGUID="e11a7c72-ac1c-4784-839e-a7597b5df474" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:36:39.030" UserId="2841" Text="Altering database tables in Django" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49091" PostHistoryTypeId="3" PostId="35991" RevisionGUID="e11a7c72-ac1c-4784-839e-a7597b5df474" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:36:39.030" UserId="2841" Text="|database|django|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49092" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35991" RevisionGUID="e11a7c72-ac1c-4784-839e-a7597b5df474" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:36:39.030" UserId="2841" Text="I'm considering using Django for a project I'm starting (fyi, a browser-based game) and one of the features I'm liking the most is using `syncdb` to automatically create the database tables based on the Django models I define (a feature that I can't seem to find in any other framework).&#xD;&#xA;I was already thinking this was too good to be true when I saw this in the [documentation][1]:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; Syncdb will not alter existing tables&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; syncdb will only create tables for models which have not yet been installed. It will never issue ALTER TABLE statements to match changes made to a model class after installation. Changes to model classes and database schemas often involve some form of ambiguity and, in those cases, Django would have to guess at the correct changes to make. There is a risk that critical data would be lost in the process.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; If you have made changes to a model and wish to alter the database tables to match, use the sql command to display the new SQL structure and compare that to your existing table schema to work out the changes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It seems that altering existing tables will have to be done &quot;by hand&quot;.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What I would like to know is the best way to do this. Two solutions come to mind:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  - As the documentation suggests, make the changes manually in the DB;&#xD;&#xA;  - Do a backup of the database, wipe it, create the tables again (with syncdb, since now it's creating the tables from scratch) and import the backed-up data (this might take too long if the database is big)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Any ideas?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://www.djangoproject.com/documentation/django-admin/" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49099" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35994" RevisionGUID="3444728a-6237-4653-8145-786d69facb35" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:38:57.730" UserId="2150" Text="That's kind of an open ended question, but one suggestion would be to use a map with the enum as the key type and the extra information in the value. (If your indices are continuous, unlike the example, you can use a sequence container instead of a map)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49100" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="35995" RevisionGUID="1e0cb1ff-1a17-40f5-a880-179340189266" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:39:30.363" UserId="1606" Text="There is at least one definite reason to go for storing in the database. You can use INSERT DELAYED in MySQL (or similar constructs in other databases), which returns immediately. You won't get any return data from the database with these kinds of queries, and they are not guaranteed to be applied.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;By using INSERT DELAYED, you won't slow down your app to much because of the logging. The database is free to write the INSERTs to disk at any time, so it can bundle a bunch of inserts together.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You need to watch out for using MySQL's built in timestamp function (like CURRENT_TIMESTAMP or CUR_DATE()), because they will be called whenever the query is actually executed. So you should make sure that any time data is generated in your programming language, and not by the database. (This paragraph might be MySQL-specific)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39425" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="28716" RevisionGUID="1e60e1c9-8d1a-43be-bf96-b91876246d82" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:48:08.603" UserId="234" Comment="Add graph courtesy of google charts. Yay!" Text="I'm trying to improve performance under high load and would like to implement opcode caching. Which of the following should I use?&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* APC - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/apc-php5-apache2-debian-etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;* eAccelerator - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/eaccelerator_php5_debian_etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;* XCache - &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.howtoforge.com/xcache-php5-apache2-debian-etch&quot;&gt;Installation Guide&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'm also open to any other alternatives that have slipped under my radar.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Currently running on a stock Debian Etch with Apache 2 and PHP 5.2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**[Update 1]**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;HowtoForge installation links added&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;**[Update 2]**&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on the answers and feedback given, I have tested all 3 implementations using the following Apache JMeter test plan on my application:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Login&#xD;&#xA;* Access Home Page&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;With 50 concurrent connections, the results are as follows:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;No Opcode Caching&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/nocache.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;APC&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/apc.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;eAccelerator&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/eaccelerator.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://edmundtay.com/stackoverflow/28716/xcache.jpg&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Performance Graph (smaller is better)&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=bhs&amp;chco=454545|008866|880066|ff8000&amp;chs=620x125&amp;chd=t:13337,2901,2687,2997&amp;chds=0,15000&amp;chdl=No%20Opcodes|APC|eAcellerator|XCache&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;From the above results, eAccelerator has a slight edge in performance compared to APC and XCache. However, what matters most from the above data is that any sort of opcode caching gives a tremendous boost in performance.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I have decided to use APC due to the following 2 reasons:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* Package is available in official Debian repository&#xD;&#xA;* More functional control panel&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;To summarize my experience:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ease of Installation: APC &gt; eAccelerator &gt; XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Performance: eAccelerator &gt; APC, XCache&lt;br&gt;&#xD;&#xA;Control Panel: APC &gt; XCache &gt; eAccelerator" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54835" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39576" RevisionGUID="ba7e8513-e832-4e63-8bdf-eb2465e563f6" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:56:19.413" UserId="3734" Text="I'm looking for a good way to perform multi-row inserts into an Oracle 9 database.  The following works in MySQL but doesn't seem to be supported in Oracle.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    INSERT INTO TMP_DIM_EXCH_RT &#xD;&#xA;	(EXCH_WH_KEY, &#xD;&#xA;     EXCH_NAT_KEY, &#xD;&#xA;     EXCH_DATE, EXCH_RATE, &#xD;&#xA;     FROM_CURCY_CD, &#xD;&#xA;     TO_CURCY_CD, &#xD;&#xA;     EXCH_EFF_DATE, &#xD;&#xA;     EXCH_EFF_END_DATE, &#xD;&#xA;     EXCH_LAST_UPDATED_DATE) &#xD;&#xA;	VALUES&#xD;&#xA;		(1, 1, '28-AUG-2008', 109.49, 'USD', 'JPY', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008'),&#xD;&#xA;		(2, 1, '28-AUG-2008', .54, 'USD', 'GBP', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008'),&#xD;&#xA;		(3, 1, '28-AUG-2008', 1.05, 'USD', 'CAD', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008'),&#xD;&#xA;		(4, 1, '28-AUG-2008', .68, 'USD', 'EUR', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008'),&#xD;&#xA;		(5, 1, '28-AUG-2008', 1.16, 'USD', 'AUD', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008'),&#xD;&#xA;		(6, 1, '28-AUG-2008', 7.81, 'USD', 'HKD', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008', '28-AUG-2008');&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54837" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39579" RevisionGUID="8f005ce0-f0de-4d86-97db-510e8a4615a8" CreationDate="2008-09-02T13:57:49.377" UserId="3525" Text="Here's a nice approach (from [the main Wikipedia entry on pi][1]); it converges much faster than the simple formula discussed above, and is quite amenable to a recursive solution if your intent is to pursue recursion as a learning exercise.  (Assuming that you're after the learning experience, I'm not giving any actual code.)&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The underlying formula is the same as above, but this approach averages the partial sums to accelerate the convergence.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Define a two parameter function, pie(h, w), such that:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    pie(0,1) = 4/1&#xD;&#xA;    pie(0,2) = 4/1 - 4/3&#xD;&#xA;    pie(0,3) = 4/1 - 4/3 + 4/5&#xD;&#xA;    pie(0,4) = 4/1 - 4/3 + 4/5 - 4/7&#xD;&#xA;    ... and so on&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So your first opportunity to explore recursion is to code that &quot;horizontal&quot; computation as the &quot;width&quot; parameter increases (for &quot;height&quot; of zero).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then add the second dimension with this formula:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    pie(h, w) = (pie(h-1,w) + pie(h-1,w+1)) / 2&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;which is used, of course, only for values of h greater than zero.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The nice thing about this algorithm is that you can easily mock it up with a spreadsheet to check your code as you explore the results produced by progressively larger parameters. By the time you compute pie(10,10), you'll have an approximate value for pi that's good enough for most engineering purposes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

This is what the upgrade wizard uses to replace the current VB6 control arrays.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, A control array in VB6 is just a collection of objects with VB6 doing some syntax magic on the surface. In the .NET world, by removing this, they are forcing better practices.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In closing, with the advent of generics, there is nothing stopping you from using List&lt;YourControl&gt; MyControlArray.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

This is what the upgrade wizard uses to replace the current VB6 control arrays.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;However, A control array in VB6 is just a collection of objects with VB6 doing some syntax magic on the surface. In the .NET world, by removing this, they are forcing better practices.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In closing, with the advent of generics, there is nothing stopping you from using &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    List&lt;YourControl&gt; MyControlArray.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60858" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43542" RevisionGUID="ce5daf4c-3c77-4964-8ea4-1bb0573b7f97" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:42:23.133" UserId="615" Text="Yeah, I've found manually layout out controls (incrementing their Top property by the height of the control plus a margin as I go) to be reasonably effective.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Another approach is to place your controls in Panels with Dock set to Top, so that each successive panel docks up against the one above. Then you can toggle the visibility of individual panels and the controls underneath will snap up to fill the available space. Be aware that this can be a bit unpredictable: showing a hidden panel that's docked can sometimes change its position relative to other docked controls." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="19992" PostHistoryTypeId="6" PostId="4541" RevisionGUID="cd228d93-226e-44c1-a617-9a5b1dce43f6" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:33:47.770" UserId="380" Comment="edited tags" Text="|database|logging|olap|text-files|hacks|" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="19996" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15808" RevisionGUID="98ee327e-50af-4f88-8da5-8d8946eb2ebd" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:43:55.987" UserId="1596" Text="This is the effect of a new feature in Vista called &quot;Boxing&quot;:&#xD;&#xA;Windows has several mechanisms that allow the user/admin to set up applications to automatically run when windows starts. This feature is mostly used for one of these purposes:&#xD;&#xA;1. Programs that are part of the basic work environment of the user, such that the first action the user would usually take when starting the computer is to start them.&#xD;&#xA;2. All sorts of background &quot;agents&quot; - skype, messenger, winamp etc.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;When too many (or too heavy) programs are registered to run on startup the end result is that the user can't actually do anything for the first few seconds/minutes after login, which can be really annoying. In comes Vista's &quot;Boxing&quot; feature:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Briefly, Vista forces all programs invoked through the Run key to operate at low priority for the first 60 seconds after login. This affects both **I/O priority (which is set to Very Low) and CPU priority**. Very Low priority I/O requests do not pass through the file cache, but go directly to disk. Thus, they are much slower than regular I/O. &#xD;&#xA;The length of the boxing period is set by the registry value: &#xD;&#xA;&quot;HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Advanced\DelayedApps\Delay_Sec&quot;. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;For a more detailed explanation see [here][1] and [here][2]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://blogs.technet.com/askperf/archive/2008/03/28/startup-programs-on-windows-vista-inside-the-box.aspx&#xD;&#xA;  [2]: http://myitforum.com/cs2/blogs/scassells/archive/2008/02/05/boxing-and-the-case-of-the-slow-or-hanging-logon-script-in-vista.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="20000" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15810" RevisionGUID="0655efcb-ec70-4c2e-bc3f-5360aa8fdba1" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:51:24.757" UserId="1710" Text="You can set the Build Action/Copy to Output Directory property on individual files (select the file and hit F4 to open the properties window) to control what happens to them during build, but not for folders. This could probably be automated with a (pre) build task if you don't want to do it manually.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Alternatively, you can exclude these folders from the project (right click and 'exclude from project'); they'll still be there (&quot;show all files&quot; in solution explorer), but they won't be included when building the project." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="20001" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15811" RevisionGUID="4cd5fc7f-785b-4785-9c47-7f55b0e34cc4" CreationDate="2008-08-19T06:51:46.643" UserId="699" Text="I am one of the authors of Drools, I will avoid pimping my wares. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;But some other options are Jess (not open source) but uses the clips syntax (which we also support a subset of) - which is kinda a lisp dialect. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;It really depends what you want it for, Haley have strong Natural language tech (and they recently aquired RuleBurst - who has also interesting natural language tech which could deal with word documents with embedded rules - eg legal documentation). RuleBurst was able to target .Net runtimes as well (there is a Drools.net &quot;port&quot; available as well - I haven't seen what it has been up to lately, alas, not enough time). Ok I will put my pimp bling away now... sorry about that. " ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="39433" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="29349" RevisionGUID="7cff7e02-95ff-4ab2-a4a2-0967b575e642" CreationDate="2008-08-27T01:54:13.033" UserId="392" Text="I've had no problems connecting to network shares transparently as if they were local drives. The only issue you may have is what you mentioned: having the `aspnet` account gain access to the share. Impersonation is probably the best way to do this.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You should be able to use any filestream objects to access the network share as long as it has a drive letter on the server machine." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49121" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="36010" RevisionGUID="6f34c997-f89b-4bc4-8d19-b8ed26a97d58" CreationDate="2008-08-30T14:54:16.723" UserId="3187" Text="One way to separate the MXML and ActionScript for a component into separate files is by doing something similar to the ASP.Net 1.x code behind model. In this model the declarative part (the MXML in this case) is a subclass of the imperative part (the ActionScript). So I might declare the code behind for a class like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    package CustomComponents&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;    	import mx.containers.*;&#xD;&#xA;    	import mx.controls.*;&#xD;&#xA;    	import flash.events.Event;&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    	public class MyCanvasCode extends Canvas&#xD;&#xA;    	{&#xD;&#xA;    		public var myLabel : Label;&#xD;&#xA;    		&#xD;&#xA;    		protected function onInitialize(event : Event):void&#xD;&#xA;    		{&#xD;&#xA;    			MyLabel.text = &quot;Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit.&quot;;&#xD;&#xA;    		}&#xD;&#xA;    	}&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;...and the markup like this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;utf-8&quot;?&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;MyCanvasCode xmlns=&quot;CustomComponents.*&quot; &#xD;&#xA;    	xmlns:mx=&quot;http://www.adobe.com/2006/mxml&quot;&#xD;&#xA;    	initialize=&quot;onInitialize(event)&quot;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    	&lt;mx:Label id=&quot;myLabel&quot;/&gt;	&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/MyCanvasCode&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As you can see from this example, a disadvatage of this approach is that you have to declare controls like **myLabel** in both files." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54842" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39584" RevisionGUID="71bca1dd-6951-4b4c-bc9f-3572200d2472" CreationDate="2008-09-02T14:00:06.207" UserDisplayName="ho" Text="The main difference I noticed in moving from SQL Server to Oracle was that in Oracle you need to use cursors in the SELECT statements.&#xD;&#xA;Also, temporary tables are used differently. In SQL Server you can create one in a procedure and then DROP it at the end, but in Oracle you're supposed to already have a temporary table created before the procedure is executed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I'd look at datatypes too since they're quite different." And at last you have a Language-table that has LanguageID(int) and LanguageName(varchar).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then, when you want to show your users the news-page you do:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    SELECT NewsText FROM News INNER JOIN NewsText ON News.NewsID = NewsText.NewsID&#xD;&#xA;    WHERE NewsText.NewsLanguageID = &lt;&lt;Session[&quot;UserLanguageID&quot;]&gt;&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;That Session-bit is a local variable where you store the users language when they log in or enters the site for the first time."   <row Id="330" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="48" RevisionGUID="68631143-ecbd-485f-bf6f-d1587b1c569e" CreationDate="2008-08-01T13:01:17.303" UserId="40" Text="Let's say you create a Wizard in an HTML form.  One button goes back and one goes forward.  Since the &quot;back&quot; button appears first in the markup, when you press Enter it will use that button to submit the form. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Ex:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;form&gt;&#xD;&#xA;       &lt;input type=&quot;text&quot; name=&quot;field1&quot; /&gt; &lt;!-- put your cursor in this field and press Enter --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;       &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;prev&quot; value=&quot;Previous Page&quot; /&gt; &lt;!-- This is the button that will submit --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;       &lt;input type=&quot;submit&quot; name=&quot;next&quot; value=&quot;Next Page&quot; /&gt; &lt;!-- But this is the button that I WANT to submit --&gt;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;/form&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What I would LIKE to do, is get to decide which button is used to submit the form when a user presses Enter.   <row Id="341" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="328" RevisionGUID="093fb620-4e92-421f-9246-05591df4381e" CreationDate="2008-08-02T02:41:34.493" UserId="59" Text="What are some guidelines for maintaining responsible session security with PHP?  There's information all over the web, so it's about time it all landed in one place!" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="342" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="329" RevisionGUID="9715e57b-bd5f-4f90-9443-4a68d35a5eef" CreationDate="2008-08-02T02:43:42.790" UserId="59" Text="One guideline is to call [session_regenerate_id][1] every time a session's security level changes.  This helps prevent session hijacking.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]:http://www.php.net/session_regenerate_id" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="343" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="331" RevisionGUID="afc5c2cd-fe47-4eef-aef9-7def0646e244" CreationDate="2008-08-02T02:55:07.743" UserId="58" Text="I think one of the major problems (which is being addressed in PHP 6) is register_globals. Right now one of the standard methods used to avoid register_globals is to use the $_REQUEST, $_GET or $_POST arrays.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The &quot;correct&quot; way to do it (as of 5.2, although it's a little buggy there, but stable as of 6, which is coming soon) is through [filters][1].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So instead of:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;$username = $_POST[&quot;username&quot;];&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;you would do:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;$username = filter_input(INPUT_POST, 'username', FILTER_SANITIZE_STRING);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;or even just:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;$username = filter_input(INPUT_POST, 'username');&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://us.php.net/filter" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="344" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="332" RevisionGUID="66565ae8-817d-49f9-9d2f-c82adcdf3417" CreationDate="2008-08-02T03:00:24.613" UserId="59" Text="I would be a bit reluctant to use nested classes here.  What if you created an abstract base class for a &quot;multimedia driver&quot; to handle the back-end stuff (workhorse), and a separate class for the front-end work?  The front-end class could take a pointer/reference to an implemented driver class (for the appropriate media type and situation) and perform the abstract operations on the workhorse structure.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;My philosophy would be to go ahead and make both structures accessible to the client in a polished way, just under the assumption they would be used in tandem.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I would reference something like a [QTextDocument][1] in Qt.  You provide a direct interface to the bare metal data handling, but pass the authority along to an object like a QTextEdit to do the manipulation.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://doc.trolltech.com/4.4/qtextdocument.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="20018" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15824" RevisionGUID="e190a0cc-9c18-48f1-af60-eef02359af8b" CreationDate="2008-08-19T07:13:31.733" UserId="999" Text="As far as I know there's no way to change the client's resolution just using VNC, as it is just a &quot;monitor mirroring&quot; application.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[TightVNC][1] however (which is a VNC client and server application) can resize the screen on the client side, i.e. making everything a little smaller (similar to image resizing techniques in graphics programs).   <row Id="20027" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="15832" RevisionGUID="3247b40f-7466-4b32-9135-328c391623cc" CreationDate="2008-08-19T07:25:54.517" UserId="832" Text="[Fredrik](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15716/design-problems-with-net-usercontrol#15803) is right, basically, when you need to enable the designer to persist the property to page so it can be instantiated at run time. There is only one way to do this, and that is to write its values to the ASPX page, which is then picked up by the runtime.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Otherwise, the control will simply revert to its default state each and every time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Always keep in the back of your mind that the Page (and its contents) and the code are completely seperate in ASP.NET, they are hooked up at run time. This means that you dont get the nice code-behind designer support like you do in a WinForms app (where the form is an instance of an object)." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60878" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43547" RevisionGUID="9a450afb-c755-45fa-b7de-e2f6f42f6847" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:45:14.390" UserId="4227" Text="An other (better ?) way is probablby using the new keyword to prevent a particular method from being overiden:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;	class A&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		public virtual void Render()&#xD;&#xA;		{&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;	class B : A&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		public override void Render()&#xD;&#xA;		{&#xD;&#xA;			// Prepare the object for rendering       &#xD;&#xA;			SpecialRender();&#xD;&#xA;			// Do some cleanup    &#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;		protected virtual void SpecialRender()&#xD;&#xA;		{&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;	class B2 : B&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		public new void Render()&#xD;&#xA;		{&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;	}&#xD;&#xA;	class C : B2&#xD;&#xA;	{&#xD;&#xA;		protected override void SpecialRender()&#xD;&#xA;		{&#xD;&#xA;		}&#xD;&#xA;		//public override void Render() // compiler error &#xD;&#xA;		//{&#xD;&#xA;		//}&#xD;&#xA;	}" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60883" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="43506" RevisionGUID="34469b6e-6a04-402d-a3ee-6ba413aade98" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:55:20.263" UserId="1196" Comment="added 304 characters in body" Text="Take a look at the [Enumerable.SequenceEqual][1]  method&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    var dictionary = new Dictionary&lt;int, string&gt;() {{1, &quot;a&quot;}, {2, &quot;b&quot;}};&#xD;&#xA;    var intList = new List&lt;int&gt; {1, 2};&#xD;&#xA;    var stringList = new List&lt;string&gt; {&quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;};&#xD;&#xA;    var test1 = dictionary.Keys.SequenceEqual(intList);&#xD;&#xA;    var test2 = dictionary.Values.SequenceEqual(stringList);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb348567.aspx" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="60884" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43560" RevisionGUID="caaf2449-88ba-4d74-873b-9bbcf593d88f" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:55:20.763" UserId="4495" Text="Dispose does call DestroyHandle, but not always. If I close the parent window, then Windows will destroy all child windows. In this situation Dispose won't call DestroyHandle (since it is already destroyed). In other words, DestroyHandle is called to destroy the window, it is not called when the window is destroyed.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The solution is to override either OnHandleDestroyed, or Dispose. I'm opting for Dispose.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="60895" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="43557" RevisionGUID="0d6fa915-0990-41f4-ad3d-1cbd371f1b66" CreationDate="2008-09-04T11:52:32.050" UserId="905" Text="Partial methods have been introduced for similar reasons to why partial classes were in .Net 2.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A partial class is one that can be split across multiple files - the compiler builds them all into one file as it runs.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The advantage for this is that Visual Studio can provide a graphical designer for part of the class while coders work on the other.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The most common example is the Form designer. Developers don't want to be positioning  buttons, input boxes, etc by hand most of the time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;* In .Net 1 it was auto-generated code in a `#region` block&#xD;&#xA;* In .Net 2 these became separate designer classes - the form is still one class, it's just split into one file edited by the developers and one by the form designer&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This makes maintaining both much easier.  Merges are simpler and there's less risk of the VS form designer accidentally undoing coders' manual changes.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In .Net 3.5 Linq has been introduced.  Linq has a DBML designer for building your data structures, and that generates auto-code.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The extra bit here is that code needed to provide methods that developers might want to fill in.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;As developers will extend these classes (with extra partial files) they couldn't use abstract methods here.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The other issue is that most of the time these methods wont be called, and calling empty methods is a waste of time.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Empty methods [are not optimised out](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11783/in-net-will-empty-method-calls-be-optimized-out).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So Linq generates empty partial methods. If you don't create your own partial to complete them the C# compiler will just optimise them out.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;So that it can do this partial methods always return void.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you create a new Linq DBML file it will auto-generate a partial class, something like&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    [System.Data.Linq.Mapping.DatabaseAttribute(Name=&quot;MyDB&quot;)]&#xD;&#xA;    public partial class MyDataContext : System.Data.Linq.DataContext&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        ...&#xD;&#xA;		&#xD;&#xA;        partial void OnCreated();&#xD;&#xA;        partial void InsertMyTable(MyTable instance);&#xD;&#xA;        partial void UpdateMyTable(MyTable instance);&#xD;&#xA;        partial void DeleteMyTable(MyTable instance);&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;        ...&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Then in your own partial file you can extend this:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    public partial class MyDataContext&#xD;&#xA;    {&#xD;&#xA;        partial void OnCreated() {&#xD;&#xA;            //do something on data context creation&#xD;&#xA;        }&#xD;&#xA;    }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you don't extend these methods they get optimised right out." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="4427" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3818" RevisionGUID="19f7aae6-187b-4b82-9e72-b34285100634" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:37:17.573" UserId="342" Text="At a company where I used to work we stored 155 million images in an Oracle 8i (then 9i) database. 7.5TB worth." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4432" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3824" RevisionGUID="1ee52ada-7a74-45b2-ac9a-684735e474ac" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:40:08.393" UserId="194" Text="For something like a webserver, dividing up the tasks of handling each connection is (relatively) easy.  I say it's safe to say that web servers is one of the most common (and ironed out) uses of parallel code.  And since you are able to split up much of the processing into multiple discrete threads, more cores actually does benefit you.  This is one of the big reasons why shared hosting is even possible.  If server software like IIS and Apache couldn't run requests in parallel it would mean that every page request would have to be dished out in a queue fashion...likely making load times unbearably slow.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;This also why high end server Operating Systems like Windows 2008 Server Enterprise support something like 64 cores and 2TB of RAM.  These are applications that can actually take advantage of that many cores.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Also, since each request is likely has low CPU load, you can probably (for some applications) get away with more slower cores.  But obviously having each core faster can mean being able to get each task done quicker and, in theory, handle more tasks and more server requests." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4433" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3825" RevisionGUID="68c4c61f-4f03-4911-88ec-4fdbfe72e72d" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:40:39.813" UserId="35" Text="Mark Harrison said:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;&gt; I don't have much experience with IIS, but I imagine the same scenario applies with its thread pool.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Indeed - more cores = more threads running concurrently.  IIS is inherently multithreaded, and takes easy advantage of this." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="4435" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="3827" RevisionGUID="7052498c-704f-4184-9d6e-c58db27f980a" CreationDate="2008-08-06T18:41:13.057" UserId="430" Text="I'm not sure if I can solve this in one go, but we can go back and forth as necessary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;First, I want to repeat what I think you are saying and make sure I'm clear.  You want to disallow requests to servlet1 and servlet2 is the request doesn't have the proper referer and it **does** have a query string?  I'm not sure I understand (servlet1|servlet2)/.+\?.+ because it looks like you are requiring a file under servlet1 and 2.  I think maybe you are combining PATH_INFO (before the &quot;?&quot;) with a GET query string (after the &quot;?&quot;).  It appears that the PATH_INFO part will work but the GET query test will not.  I made a quick test on my server using script1.cgi and script2.cgi and the following rules worked to accomplish what you are asking for.  They are obviously edited a little to match my environment:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^http://(www.)?example.(com|org) [NC]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{QUERY_STRING} ^.+$&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteRule ^(script1|script2)\.cgi - [F]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;The above caught all wrong-referer requests to script1.cgi and script2.cgi that tried to submit data using a query string.  However, you can also submit data using a path_info and by posting data.  I used this form to protect against any of the three methods being used with incorrect referer:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^http://(www.)?example.(com|org) [NC]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{QUERY_STRING} ^.+$ [OR]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_METHOD} ^POST$ [OR]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{PATH_INFO} ^.+$&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteRule ^(script1|script2)\.cgi - [F]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Based on the example you were trying to get working, I think this is what you want:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^http://mywebaddress(.cl)?/.* [NC]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{QUERY_STRING} ^.+$ [OR]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_METHOD} ^POST$ [OR]&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteCond %{PATH_INFO} ^.+$&#xD;&#xA;    RewriteRule (servlet1|servlet2)\b - [F]&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Hopefully this at least gets you closer to your goal.  Please let us know how it works, I'm interested in your problem.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;(BTW, I agree that referer blocking is poor security, but I also understand that relaity forces imperfect and partial solutions sometimes, which you seem to already acknowledge.)" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="54861" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39594" RevisionGUID="37fda575-dd52-4ac2-8688-f5ad6db3c18d" CreationDate="2008-09-02T14:04:09.347" UserId="1220" Text="I use transactions on every write operation to the database.  &#xD;&#xA;So there are quite a few small &quot;transactions&quot; wrapped in a larger transaction and basically there is an outstanding transaction count in the nesting code. If there are any outstanding children when you end the parent, its all rolled back.  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;I prefer client-side transaction handling where available. If you are relegated to doing sps or other server side logical units of work, server side transactions are fine." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="54862" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="39595" RevisionGUID="fe37245c-0f53-422c-9485-005df723b89b" CreationDate="2008-09-02T14:05:26.397" UserId="1726" Text="I don't know how to share the session cookies, but you can easily share the same login. &#xD;&#xA;i.e. People will need to log separately into both sites, but will be able to use the same username and password. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In the mediawiki file &quot;LocalSettings.PHP&quot;, you can tell it to use a different (wordpress) database for authentication: &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;e.g. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    require_once('includes/AuthPlugin.php');&#xD;&#xA;    require_once('extensions/AuthPress.php');&#xD;&#xA;    &#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth = new AuthPress();&#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth-&gt;setAuthPressTablePrefix('evo_');&#xD;&#xA;    # Only include the following if you aren't using the same db as  MediaWiki&#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth-&gt;setAuthPressDBServer ('localhost');&#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth-&gt;setAuthPressDBName('yourWordPressDB');&#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth-&gt;setAuthPressUser('mySQL user for same');&#xD;&#xA;    $wgAuth-&gt;setAuthPressPassword('The password');&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;See http://bbpress.org/forums/topic/mediawiki-bbpress-and-wordpress-integration&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="49130" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="36026" RevisionGUID="13d915d2-6707-4624-ae7c-599ee42eb8dc" CreationDate="2008-08-30T15:08:25.020" UserId="3734" Text="If your goal is to have user-friendly URLs throughout your application, use the following approach:&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;1) Create a routing rule for your module/action in the application's routing.yml file.  The following example is a routing rule for an action that shows the most recent questions in an application, defaulting to page 1 (using a pager):&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    recent_questions:&#xD;&#xA;       url:    questions/recent/:page&#xD;&#xA;       param:  { module: questions, action: recent, page: 1 }&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;2) Once the routing rule is set, use the `url_for()` helper in your template to format outgoing URLs.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;    &lt;a href=&quot;&lt;?php echo url_for('questions/recent?page=1') ?&gt;&quot;&gt;Recent Questions&lt;/a&gt;&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In this example, the following URL will be constructed: `http://myapp/questions/recent/1.html`.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;3) Incoming URLs (requests) will be analyzed by the routing system, and if a pattern match is found in the routing rule configuration, the named wildcards (ie. the `:/page` portion of the URL) will become request parameters.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can also use the `link_to()` helper to output a URL without using the HTML `&lt;a&gt;` tag.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49131" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="36027" RevisionGUID="f9a5f1e4-a56b-469c-ba2d-44f06d389833" CreationDate="2008-08-30T15:08:31.073" UserId="61" Text="&gt;Apparently, gcc doesn't behave like the one described in The C Programming language, where it says that the command cc helloworld.c produces a file called a.out which can be run by typing a.out on the prompt.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;A Unix hasn't behaved in that way by default (so you can just write the executable name without ./ at the front) in a long time. It's called a.exe, because else Windows won't execute it, as it gets file types from the extension." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="49140" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="36034" RevisionGUID="c093fcd1-a5c2-4e7f-81f9-afd1926706a1" CreationDate="2008-08-30T15:20:15.150" UserId="4381" Text="&gt; dF: that's pretty cool... I didn't&#xD;&#xA;&gt; know that I could access the fields in&#xD;&#xA;&gt; a class using dict.&#xD;&#xA;&gt; &#xD;&#xA;&gt; Mark: the situations that I wish I had&#xD;&#xA;&gt; this are precisely when I want a tuple&#xD;&#xA;&gt; but nothing as &quot;heavy&quot; as a&#xD;&#xA;&gt; dictionary.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You can access the fields of a class using a dictionary because the fields of a class, its methods and all its properties are stored internally using dicts (at least in Cython).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;...Which leads us to your second comment. Believing that Python dicts are &quot;heavy&quot; is an extremely non-pythonistic concept. And reading such comments kills my Python Zen. That's not good.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;You see, when you declare a class you are actually creating a pretty complex wrapper around a dictionary - so, if anything, you are adding more overhead than by using a simple dictionary. An overhead which, by the way, is meaningless in any case. If you are working on performance critical applications, use C or something." ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="352" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="339" RevisionGUID="87c47614-0089-4998-b836-39979e86f1f4" CreationDate="2008-08-02T03:49:21.987" UserId="59" Text="I was glad to find [a good conversation][1] on this subject, as I hadn't really given it much thought before.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;In summary, signed is a good general choice - even when you're dead sure all the numbers are positive - if you're going to do arithmetic on the variable (like in a typical for loop case).  &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you're going to do bitwise things like masks, unsigned starts to make more sense.  Or, if you're desperate to get that extra positive range by taking advantage of the sign bit.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Personally, I like signed because I don't trust myself to stay consistent and avoid mixing the two types (like the article warns against).&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: http://coding.derkeiler.com/Archive/C_CPP/comp.lang.c/2004-02/1382.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />
  <row Id="355" PostHistoryTypeId="2" PostId="342" RevisionGUID="1b39ddf7-a3da-4156-b129-8c0fbffee170" CreationDate="2008-08-02T04:01:34.600" UserId="59" Text="Personally, I've played with several of the built-in options on an XML-heavy project and have settled on [pulldom][1] as the best choice for less complex documents.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Especially for small simple stuff, I like the event-driven theory of parsing rather than setting up a whole slew of callbacks for a relatively simple structure.  [Here is a good quick discussion of how to use the API][2].&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;What I like: you can handle the parsing in a `for` loop rather than using callbacks.  You also delay full parsing (the &quot;pull&quot; part) and only get additional detail when you call `expandNode()`.  This satisfies my general requirement for &quot;responsible&quot; efficiency without sacrificing ease of use and simplicity.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;[1]: http://docs.python.org/lib/module-xml.dom.pulldom.html&#xD;&#xA;[2]: http://www.prescod.net/python/pulldom.html" ContentLicense="CC BY-SA 2.5" />

  <row Id="360" PostHistoryTypeId="5" PostId="344" RevisionGUID="e0077ee5-f7c4-45a6-ab95-7020165ffb6a" CreationDate="2008-08-02T04:23:02.043" UserId="100" Text="You might be able to use IronRuby for that. &#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;Otherwise I'd suggest you have a directory where you place precompiled assemblies. Then you could have a reference in the DB to the assembly and class, and use reflection to load the proper assemblies at runtime.&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;If you really want to compile at run-time you could use the CodeDOM, then you could use reflection to load the dynamic assembly.
